Sir,

1. Further to my letter of August 2nd 1937, re requirements for the Indian Residential School at Carcross Y.K., the following are the most outstanding needs, namely a new lighting plant and a new bake oven, both of which are absolutely necessary, and which I would request should be given serious consideration, even although it would be necessary for the Department to curtail expenditure in some other direction.

2. I paid a visit to the School on January 24th and 25th 1938, and the Principal brought to my attention the fact that with the old lighting plant now in use the electric light was costing an average of $87.06 per month, throughout the whole year.

3. He also showed me a letter he had received from the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, the following being an abstract:

"The figures you give seem to me to indicate that the cost of operating the lighting plant at present is very much too high, and we may find it necessary to revert to the use of oil or gasoline lamps."

4. A Lister Diesel Lighting Plant, Direct Current, 4 K.W.Unit, V belt driven at a cost of $355.00 F.O.B. Carcross is required. In addition the estimated cost of having this plant installed would not be much in excess of $100.00, and according to Hoffer's Ltd., Vancouver, who are agents for this type of plant, the cost of operating would be only about one sixth of that of the present Delco plant. For your information I would state that electric current is used at this School for lighting purposes only, the use of electrical appliances are forbidden.

5. The Bake Oven now in use is practically useless resulting in many batches of poor bread being baked and all being more or less smoked.

6. I would refer you to my previous report from which it will be seen that a suitable bake oven can be obtained from the Brantford Oven and Rack Co Ltd., Brantford Ont for the sum of $548.59.

7. As these articles are absolutely necessary I would request that serious consideration be given to supplying them to this School.

The Secretary,
Department Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

G. Binning A/Supt.
Dept Indian Affairs.
Ottawa
March 4, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 1st ultimo in which you state that a new lighting plant and a new bake oven are absolutely necessary at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

Provision has been made in our estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39 for sufficient funds to cover the cost of the above equipment. The money, however, will not be available until after April 1 and as soon after that date as regulations will permit an order will be placed for the lighting plant and bake oven.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

G. Binning, Esq.,

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant present regulations require our securing an Order-in-Council when making special payments to Church owned Residential Schools. I expect to secure in the near future the necessary Order-in-Council in connection with the equipment purchased for the Aklavik School. As soon as this is received payment of the grant promised will be made.

I understand that all Provinces in Canada allow a rebate of the gasoline tax when the gasoline is used for other purposes than the operation of automobiles or trucks. I believe each of your Principals can secure this rebate by making application to the Government of the Province in which the Indian Residential School is located. However, it is not possible for us to secure any rebate for gasoline used in automobiles or trucks operated by Indian Residential Schools.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter No. 141-1-5
of the 26th January, 1938, re rebate for gasoline used by Indian
Residential Schools.

We are recently in receipt of a letter from the Rev.
H. C. M. Grant, Principal of our School at Carcross, Y. T., in
which he writes as follows:

"During the course of a year this school uses approximately
2,000 gallons of gasoline none of which is used in a car or truck.
This gasoline is purchased from Mr. Matthew Watson of Carcross
who imports it from Skagway, Alaska. I have made inquiries and
beg to report that the Yukon Territorial Government does not levy
any tax on gasoline but that a Federal Tax is assessed as follows:

Duty - 1¢ per gallon.
Sales Tax - 5% of duty paid value
Excise Tax 3¢

The question of a rebate on the foregoing would no doubt have
to be taken up with the Department at Ottawa so I will not take
any action in the matter until I hear from you again."

I beg therefore to enclose accounts for 2,000 gallons
gasoline purchased during the year 1937, at a price of .55¢ per
gallon - $1,100.00, and to request that the Commission may be
refunded the sum of $132.00 as follows:
Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant requesting rebate of duty, sales tax and excise tax on gasoline used by the Carcross Indian Residential School. As this Department is required to pay sales tax and excise tax on any goods that we purchase you will readily understand that it would not be possible to secure a refund of these taxes for a purchase made by the Principal of the Carcross School. From inquiries made I understand that it would not be possible to secure refund of the 1¢ a gallon duty on gasoline. It appears from your letter that the gasoline used at Carcross is purchased at Skagway and brought into Canada.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

It was a great pleasure to note from your letter of February 10th 1938 that the Department has authorized the purchase of a new lighting unit for our school and bear the expense of having all electric wiring placed in conduit pipe. The information concerning the undertakings which you request and which was forwarded by the Department through the Indian Agent some time ago is as follows:

K.W. Lister full diesel cold starting V-belt driven lighting unit, 110 volt, direct current, battery charging generator. Engine and generator mounted on a substantial base and the unit complete with switchboard. In this plant would be required one cooling tank.

The above information was supplied to me by Hoffer's Ltd., 1790 Georgia Street, West, Vancouver, B.C. The cost of this unit is given as follows:

K.W. Unit, f.o.b. our warehouse Vancouver.............$875.00
Freight to Carcross, Y.T..........................$60.00
Total..............................................$935.00

Hoffer's Ltd., in their letter, dated January 26th, 1937, state as follows: "Delivery approximately 3 weeks from receipt of order". In view of this I would
like to place an order for this unit right away but feel that it would be advisable to wait until authority was received from Captain G. Binning, R.C.M.P., Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Yukon, Dawson, Y.T. During the past few years in matters of this nature Captain Binning writes authorizing and instructing me to order any item of equipment the purchase of which has been approved by the Department he represents. It is likely that I will hear from him about this matter in the course of a few weeks.

2. In connection with the placing of all wiring in this school in conduit pipe I may say that last summer I requested the Yukon Electrical Company Limited, Whitehorse, Yukon, to send their electrician over to the school so that they could let me have an estimate in regard to this matter. On July 26th they wrote me as follows:

"We beg to submit the following estimate for wiring the Chootla School:-

78 Outlets complete, fitted with cord drops and snap wall switches. Wires to be run in Conduit Pipe and outlet boxes. Fuse Blocks to be in boxes located one on each floor, in accordance with plan submitted. Work to be done in compliance with Canadian Underwriters Code.

Price $974.00

This price applies only between April 1st and September 30th, during other months of the year owing to early darkness, there would be an additional charge of 15% on the above price."

In my letter to Captain G. Binning, R.C.M.P. dated November 2nd, 1937 I told him that I thought that the cost of having an electrician supervise the installation of a new lighting unit would be approximately $100.00 and that a considerable amount of the work of installation could be done by the male members of the staff. Such being the case then the total cost of all electrical work etc. during the next fiscal year can be summarized as follows:-
One 4 K.W. Lister Diesel Lighting Unit........................................... $875.00
Freight charges on above......................................................... 80.00
Estimated cost of Wiring the School.............................................. 974.00
Estimated cost of Installation of Lighting Unit............................... 100.00

Total Estimated Cost................................................................. $2029.00

Trusting that the particulars as given in this letter are what you require,

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

(Sgd) H.C.M. Grant
R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In keeping with the understanding reached at the time of my interview with you in Ottawa at the beginning of last month, about a lighting plant for our Carcross School, I wrote to the Principal of that institution for the information you desired, and enclosed herewith you will find a copy of his reply. It is my understanding that authority to purchase this item of equipment, and to have all the wiring placed in conduits, would be granted immediately after April 1st next, and I will be obliged if you will advise me if the order for the plant recommended by the Rev. Principal Grant will be placed by your Department, or if it is your desire that it be placed by our Commission.

Yours very truly,

T.B.R. Westgate

Secretary of the Commission.

Memorandum

Mr. Jackson

Tenders were called for supplying and installing certain electrical equipment requisitioned by the Indian Affairs Branch for the electric light plant at the Indian Residential School at Carcross, Yukon, with results as shown on attached schedule of tenders, from which it will be noted that only two quotations were received, and that Canadian General Electric Co., Vancouver, are the lower.

I recommend that authority be granted to place the order with the above Company at a net cost f.o.b. Carcross, of $1,292.00, this being the lower, and more complete tender received.

Dr. McGill states in his memorandum of March 18th that new electric wiring throughout the building is required, and that the Principal of the School has obtained a quotation on same from the Yukon Electrical Co., Whitehorse, of $974.00. This wiring should be completed before the lighting plant equipment is installed. As specifications with requisition to arrange for this contract were not supplied this office, I would suggest that Indian Affairs Branch be authorized to take the necessary action to have this wiring completed locally at the earliest possible date, and when it is completed to submit vouchers to this office, to enable us to encumber same by Purchase Order.

W.M. Bailey
Departmental Purchasing Agent.

For your information I visited the Indian Residential School at Carcross during the month of June, and as this will be my last visit to this school, I being transferred from the Yukon on July 16th, I am forwarding a list of the needs so that you may have an idea of the requirements in preparing your appropriations for the coming fiscal year.

The Principal's residence requires extensive repairs, as per my telegram to you dated June 13th, it was not possible to include this in last year's estimates as most of the damage was done during the break-up and thaw this spring. This house is in a deplorable condition and something should be done as soon as possible to make it more comfortable.

Addition to present school building, as mentioned in my report last year, this school is too small for the number of pupils, there are quite a number of children who have to be refused admission owing to there being no accommodation for them. The question of an addition to the school has already been drawn to your attention and I understand that the Department have plans for this work at an estimated cost of $8,000.00. If it is not possible to go ahead with these plans perhaps consideration might be given to building a separate class room for the school and then the present class room could be turned into a dormitory.

One of the most pressing needs is a Diesel Caterpillar Tractor to be used for the hauling of cord wood. Since 1929 approximately 2,000 cords of wood have been cut in the vicinity of the school, this means that every year they have to go further afield to obtain the 250 cords required each year. Last year the team had to haul the wood 6 miles over mountainous trails and the most that could be hauled at a time was 11 cords, so that if a tractor was in use it would be possible to haul on the lake from a distance of 10 or 12 miles from the school and get it done in a comparatively short time, as it would be possible to haul 10 cords at a time. I am not able to give the price of a Tractor but doubtless you could obtain that easily.

One 2 Ton Ford Truck V8 Chassis with Cab, Dual wheel drive, 157 inch Wheel base 10 ply dual rear tires at a cost of $1,480.00 F.O.B. Carcross. The above price is quoted by the Northern Commercial Co. Whitehorse Y.T.

In the spring when the horses are being used for the preparing of the land for crop or are away from the school hauling hay, there is no means of hauling freight or getting back and forward to town and a Ford Truck would be extremely useful at the school.
6. There are not sufficient beds in the school. In some cases two children have to sleep in the same bed. In view of this and the fact that some of the beds now in use are in poor state of repair, six new three-quarter size beds, springs and mattresses are urgently needed. The cost of six beds etc would be in the neighbourhood of $100.00 F.O.B. Carcross.

7. One Windsor Bungalow Hot Water Supply Boiler No. 15G. This can be supplied by McLennan McFeely and Prior Ltd of Vancouver B.C. the cost would be $142.75 F.O.B. Carcross. The present hot water supply boiler is not large enough for the amount of hot water required.

8. A building for storing Ice is required as during the last few years the raising of pigs has been undertaken at the School and found to be both profitable and successful. These efforts would be augmented if a suitable place for the curing of bacon was provided. At present the building used for storing ice is not suitable and the suggestion is made that this ice house be used for the curing of bacon and a new ice building erected. It is estimated that a suitable building could be erected for $600.00.

9. A suitable floor covering is needed for the main hall of the school. This is fir flooring and if something is not done to preserve it a new floor will be required in the near future. To cover the main hall with Battleship Linoleum would be most suitable and give years of wear and the following is the data in this respect:
   Brown Battleship Linoleum 60 squares yards, 6ft wide at $4.00 per square yard.
   Heavy wall felt to place under linoleum, 2 rolls at $2.00 each
   Freight charges from Vancouver to Carcross

Total $76.40

10. One Ice Refrigerator for use in kitchen. This is a very urgent need for the staff find great difficulty in keeping milk, butter and meat during the hot summer months. The cost of this item would be approximately $50.00 F.O.B. Carcross.

11. In order to keep the building in good repair the following paint is required:
   2 gals. White Enamel at $4.25
   4 Gals Dark Oak Varnish Stain at $4.00
   Estimated Freight Charges

Total $28.35

12. Painting the outside of the Main School building, wood work only. Two years ago the Department allowed a grant for the staining of the shingles on the outside of the buildings, and now it is necessary that the siding, window frames etc should be painted in the near future. The cost of having this done would be around $450.00 and would include all paint and oil required to give two coats of paint.

13. The above submitted for your information and approval.

Dept Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Memorandum

Mr. R. A. Grey:

Re Lighting Plant,
Carcross Indian Residential School

Replying to your memorandum of the 26th ultimo, relative to the above, with copy of letter from the Principal and invoices attached, I have gone quite fully into the matter and find as follows:

Original requisition specified a Lister engine. Canadian General Electric Company Limited quoted on a Petters engine, and order issued accordingly. The Company supplied a Lister engine, giving as the reason that after consultation with their engineers it was decided it would be better to supply the type of engine originally requisitioned for, a type more favourably known and more extensively used by Government Departments than the Petters.

With reference to the Principal's remark that a 7 H.P. engine had been installed, the Company points out that the engine supplied develops 7 H.P. at 1000 r.p.m., and 8 H.P. at 1200 r.p.m. This unit was worked out so that the engine would operate at 1200 r.p.m., and the governor was set accordingly.

It is understood that there is no difference in the cost of the unit supplied and Petters unit quoted on.

In view of the information and explanation furnished by the Company, I am of the opinion that the unit supplied will give satisfactory service and that the accounts, therefore, might be approved for payment.

The invoices are returned herewith.

W. M. Bailey,
Departmental Purchasing Agent

1. Addition to the present school building. This school is by no means large enough to accommodate the number of children who need our care and attention. At the present time I know of eight children in the Carcross district whose parents want them placed in this school. All these applications for admission and several others have had to be turned down on account of lack of accommodation. The question of an addition to the school has, I believe, been already drawn to the attention of the Department and no doubt they have the plans and specifications on file. These were submitted some years ago by two local builders and contractors. The estimated cost of the proposed addition has been given as $8,000.00.

If the building of this addition cannot be carried out in the near future it would be greatly appreciated if you would recommend that the Department pay us a per capita grant for 50 children instead of 40. During the winter 1937-38 we had 47 children in residence which meant that seven children have been without a per capita grant and consequently the question of financing has been very difficult. Our financial difficulties would be considerably lessened if we had 50 grant earning pupils for certain overhead expenses remain the same whether there are 50 or 40 pupils in residence. The problem of accommodating 50 pupils could be met by the erection of a detached classroom at an estimated cost of $2,500.00. The present classroom could be used as a dormitory.

2. Without a doubt one of the most pressing needs is a Diesel Caterpillar to be used for hauling wood. The Northern Commercial Company of Whitehorse, Y.T. have submitted the following quotation etc. on this requested item of equipment:

D2 Diesel Caterpillar Tractor, 50 inch gauge Model.
Top seat.
13" Heat Treated Semi-Skeleton Shoes.
Snow Sprockets
Front Pull Hook
Front Bumper
Hood Doors
Electric Lighting System. F.O.B. Carcross $2,485.20

The Northern Commercial Company have assured the writer that the foregoing caterpillar has been built suitable for Northern Climates.

Since my appointment to this school in 1930 approximately 2,000 cords of wood have been cut in the vicinity of the school. This means that each year we have to go further afield in order to obtain the 250 cords of wood required each year. The trouble with which we are faced now is not getting the wood cut but getting it hauled. Last winter our teams had to haul wood a distance of 6 miles over bad mountainous trails and the most that could be hauled in one load was a cord and a half. As the years go by the length of haul becomes greater and the time has arrived when it is practically impossible for the wood hauling to be done by a team of horses. In the past we have more or less avoided cutting wood along the shores of the lake in front of the school for two reasons. In the first place, hauling wood here with a team of horses any distance over a lake in winter is a hard and cold undertaking not only for the horses but also for the teamster and his helpers. We tried it one year with the result that the horses played out and it was all the teamsters contd:-
could do to face the cold and biting winds.

In the second place, we have avoided having wood cut along the lake shores because of the short time in which the ice is really safe. Some years there are only three months in the winter in which hauling on the ice can be safely undertaken. Making allowance for the number of days when the inclemency of the weather makes it impossible to send teams out on the lake, it is easily seen that a team hauling a cord and a half per trip per half day cannot get all the wood hauled before the break-up.

The wood situation here now may be summarized as follows:

(a) All areas within six or seven miles of the school from which wood can be hauled along sheltered roads from the wind, have been cut out. Wood might be obtained by going further inland but this would mean too long a haul for horses and the use of a caterpillar tractor on the mountainous trails in the woods should not be attempted.

(b) There is practically an unlimited supply along the lake shores which for reasons given cannot be hauled by a team.

(c) With a caterpillar tractor it would be possible to haul on the lake, wood from a distance of ten or twelve miles from the school and get it in in a comparatively short time. This method of hauling wood has been put to the test. On one occasion we were allowed the use of a caterpillar, the property of the Northern Airways Ltd., In one half day ten cords were hauled on the lake ice in one trip from a place about four miles from the school. Would you please inform the Department that this is a pressing need and recommend that authority be given to make this purchase as soon as possible.

3. One 2 Ton Ford V8 Truck with cab. Dual wheel drive, 157 inch wheel base, 10 ply dual rear tires at a cost of $1,480.00 F.O.B. Carcross. This price was quoted last year by the Northern Commercial Company of Whitehorse, Y.T.

In the spring of every year when the horses are needed to put in the crops and when the horses are away from the school putting up hay we have no means of conveyance by which freight can be brought over the road from Carcross station to the school. Several times already this year we have had to request the Northern Airways Ltd. of Carcross to put their conveyance at our disposal. Sometimes they are in the position to render us the necessary help at the time it is needed; other times they are forced to give their own work prior consideration. Such a state of affairs is most unsatisfactory and a 2 Ton Ford Truck would solve all our Transportation problems. Another aspect of the matter must be mentioned. This item of equipment was requested last year. In my letter to you of June 25th, 1937 I stated as follows:

"This spring difficulty was experienced in getting an injured child (broken bone in the chest) into Carcross. The roughness of a wagon trip and the length of time such a trip would take in addition to the fact that we only had a limited time in which to get the injured child to the station made the use of a wagon decidedly inadvisable."

The school possesses a launch but this can only be used for a very limited time each year, 3 months at the most.
3 (Contd) Nearly every year, owing to low water, the school launch cannot be put into service much before the middle of July. If this launch can be operated by the middle or end of June we consider ourselves lucky. This is a great difficulty that has to be faced nearly every year and until the water reaches a navigable height we have to depend upon the road between the school and the town of Carcross. We trust that a realization of our need will prompt you to recommend that a truck be supplied at the earliest opportunity.

4. One New Bake Oven. The present one has been in use for a good many years and besides blackening the bread with smoke and soot is liable at any time to become a fire menace. In this connection the following data concerning a new bake oven is respectfully submitted:

The Brantford No.3 New Homestead Oven - floor space required 4' 10" x 3' 10" - $390.00 less 10% plus a Sales Tax of 8%.................$379.08 Freight charges - Brantford, Ont. to Carcross including Terminal Charges...........169.51

It is sincerely hoped that the Department will supply this much needed item of equipment in the very near future.

5. We have not by any means sufficient beds in the school. In many cases two children have to sleep in the same bed. In view of this and the fact that some of the beds now in use are in a poor state of repair six new - three-quarter size beds, springs and mattresses are urgently needed. The cost of six new beds etc. would be in the neighbourhood of $100.00 F.O.B. Carcross.

6. One Windsor Bungalow and Hot Water Supply Boiler No.18 G. This can be supplied by McLennan, McFeely and Prior Ltd. of Vancouver, B.C. The cost of this item of equipment, according to a quotation received several months ago, was $142.70 F.O.B. Carcross. The present Hot Water Supply Boiler is by no means large enough to give us the amount of hot water required. In addition it is very difficult to use wood as fuel in a jacket heater designed for coal. The one now in use at the school was designed for coal as a fuel and consequently has a very small fire box. The Hot Water Supply Boiler No.18G requested has a fire box of much larger dimensions than the one now in use and consequently the use of wood as fuel will present no difficulties.

7. Building for Storing Ice. During the last few years we have undertaken the raising of pigs and found it a very profitable and successful enterprise. Our efforts in this respect would be greatly augmented by having a suitable building for curing bacon. The present building used for storing ice is by no means suitable so the suggestion is made that this building be used for curing bacon and a new ice house be erected. It is felt that a suitable building could be erected at an estimated cost of $600.00. The storage of ice here is a great necessity for not only is it needed by the School Nurse in cases of accidents and sickness but to preserve milk, butter and meat during the hot summer months. The building that has been used for this purpose now does not give the ice the protection it requires.

Arthur Perfitt,
Night Watchman at the Carcross Indian Residential School,
states:-

1. At about 12.00 noon on 17th instant I was in the staff dining room when one of the boys pointed out a small blaze a few feet from the building in the kindling pile. I went outside and then saw smoke pouring from the roof of the building and sparks flying. I immediately rang the fire alarm, called to the staff, got a fire extinguisher and ran up to the attic. This was full of smoke. I could not see where the fire was but turned the extinguisher in its general direction. Then Mr. Oke and Titley arrived and I got the hose from Mr. Oke and turned it on. There was a good head of water. Then I was overcome with smoke and Mr. Oke took the hose and Mr. Titley the fire extinguisher. Then I went downstairs to see all the children outside. One of the bigger boys, Charlie Edwards, took an axe and I took an extinguisher and we went up the permanent ladder to the roof. I tore off the tin capping in several places and tried the extinguisher but after a few minutes the roof was too hot and we had to come down. I then assisted saving the effects and extinguishing the fire in the wood pile.

I went up into the attic and inspected the stove's main chimney which was cool. The smoke from the big chimney had stopped.

Sir:

Re: Fire - Carcross Indian Residential School.

I have the honour to make the following report.

1. On the evening of 17th instant I received a wire from Mr. Grant, Principal of the above school, that it and a workshop had been completely destroyed by fire that day.

2. On 18th instant I went to Carcross and made a thorough investigation, taking statements (attached) from those immediately concerned.

3. I am of the opinion that the fire started in the main chimney; creosote had evidently collected and became ignited when there was a small fire in the kitchen stove pipes. This smouldered for awhile and then penetrated into the attic and started burning in the roof.

4. I attach no blame to anyone and consider that Mr. Grant and the Staff behaved very well. There was no loss of life or injury and a great deal of bedding, food supplies, etc., were saved.

5. There was a heavy wind at the time and only the assistance from the inhabitants of Carcross saved the other buildings and the wood supply, which became ignited from sparks.

6. Separate report is being submitted regarding present accommodation of Staff and children.

I have the honour to be,

sir,

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum for file:

Mr. Rogers, Vice President of the Whitehorse and Yukon Railway, visited the Department today and in discussing with him the situation that has arisen in connection with the destruction of the Carcross school he supplied the following information:

1. In Mr. Rogers' opinion Carcross is the most suitable location for an Indian residential school. He stated that the site of the school is as good as can be secured anywhere in the Yukon Territory.

2. Carcross is located approximately 67 miles from Skagway and approximately 500 miles from Dawson.

3. Mr. Rogers stated that there were no buildings of fireproof construction in the Yukon Territory.

4. He also stated that all lumber used by the railway is brought from Vancouver.

5. He suggested that it might be worth while considering the construction of a log building as he considered this type of building most suitable for the Yukon. He further advised that in his opinion the logs could be secured at a reasonable distance from the site of the Carcross school.

6. He further stated that Mr. L. Higgins, who has been one of the Government officials in the Yukon for several years, would be a responsible party to consult regarding the re-erection of the school.

7. He mentioned that two reputable builders in the Yukon are Mr. Dan Gillis of Whitehorse and Mr. J.E. French of Carcross.
8. Mr. Rogers stated that the Whitehorse and Yukon railway would be willing to co-operate with the Department in any way either in the erection of a new building or in assisting in the housing of the children until a new building is constructed. As a matter of fact the Company has a large section house at Carcross (this is mentioned in letter of April 21 from Superintendent T.V. Sandys-Wunsch). The Company uses this building almost continuously from the latter part of May to the first of September. If necessary they might be prepared to place it at our disposal during the winter.

Dear Mr. Hoey:-

With further reference to my telegrams of April 18th and 21st, re the burning of the Carcross School, and your reply to the former on April 21st, No. 166-1-5, I beg to state that I have just received the following further information in this connexion in a letter from the Principal, dated Carcross, April 24th:-

"While it is my intention to put in later a full report on the fire (there is no time to prepare such a report now for the mail closes shortly) certain points in connection with articles saved from the burning buildings will no doubt be of the greatest interest to you. These are as follows:-

1. All mattresses and bedding from the Girl's Dormitory and nearly all from the Boy's Dormitory was saved. In the latter Dormitory fire drove us out before all mattresses and bedding could be saved. No complaint of any shortage of bedding has been made to me so I presume none exists.

2. All the girls' leather boots which had just been received were saved. The boys were burnt.

3. Practically all sewing room supplies were saved."
4. Quite a few drugs were taken out of the building.

5. I am practically sure that the school has enough food supplies to last until the end of this quarter. Later I will send you a complete list of food supplies saved. To give you some idea of the amount saved I may say that an inventory taken the day after the fire revealed the fact that we had on hand 52 - 100 lb. sacks of flour.

6. Practically all the desks were taken from the classroom to a place of safety and are now in use.

7. The Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Yukon authorized me to order through Matthew Watson any dishes, etc., that might be needed. At the present time we are using crockery loaned by the White Pass and Yukon Railway. The Superintendent of Indian Affairs is attending to the matter of bunks, washing machines, etc.

In closing may I say that even though the main school building is burnt and the Workshop, the school still goes on. The staff are to be commended upon the way in which they met a difficult situation. As I stated in my wire the classroom was in session 24 hours after the fire started, the children losing only ½ day schooling. The children are comfortably housed in different buildings in Carcross which have been rented from Mr. Matthew Watson by the Department of Indian Affairs. They are being well fed, and there is no immediate shortage of clothing. With the exception of a few children whose homes are in Carcross there has been no need to send any children home and it is planned to provide board and lodging for the few that are at home so that in a few days all children will be under our care. Right after the fire ten or twelve of the Carcross children were sent home. It was only a matter of a day or so before we had to take back eight because their parents could not provide for them. This certainly shows the need of a school.

Yours respectfully,

At about 10:15 a.m. on April 17th 1933, Mr. C.A. Oke, who has held the position of Engineer here since August 1926, came to my residence and reported that the stove pipes in the school kitchen and the chimney were on fire. This news was not regarded as being of serious import for on an average of once a year during the last eight years the same thing had happened with no damage by fire to the building. However, to be on the safe side, I went up to the School immediately and found that whilst the stove pipes in the kitchen had burnt out a deposit of creosote in the chimney was on fire. It was felt that as in the past the chimney would give all the protection necessary. The chimney itself was constructed of brick and in the centre was a heavy steel casing through which the smoke passed. This steel casing was put in some years ago after a fire broke out in the attic the cause believed to be due to a faulty chimney. Between the outside of the steel casing and the bricks there was an air space. It is hard to understand why a flue lining was not put into this chimney when the school was built. Such a lining would have been a safeguard to the building in the event of the chimney settling. It seems almost certain that in the course of years the chimney settled with the exception of that part which protrudes above the roof. This part would be held up by the flashings and so there would naturally be a crack or opening in the bricks where the chimney came into contact with the roof. The writer had examined the chimney on several occasions but it is just possible that a crack could be hidden by woodwork. It was felt that even if there was a crack the steel casing would provide all the safety necessary. I am positive that if proper flue lining, the usual non-metallic kind used in chimneys, had been installed when the school was built, the fire of fifteen years ago and the recent ones would never have occurred. The steel casing was the next best thing but through the several joints, six in number, creosote could quite easily leak into the space between the outside of the steel casing and the bricks. At the joints in the steel casing the various lengths were merely butted together and there was no overlapping as it is felt there should have been. I am inclined to think that the matter of a flue lining should be taken up with the Department for it is hard to understand how such an important item could have been left out of the specifications.

As a precautionary measure I asked Mr. Oke if he had been up to the attic to see if everything was alright. He said, "No". Instructions were then given for him to do so and after awhile he came back and reported that there was no sign of fire and that, on feeling right round the chimney where it came into contact with the roof, it was found to be just warm. By this time it was about 10:30 a.m. At eleven o'clock Mr. Oke and I inspected the chimney again and to all appearances the fire seemed to have burnt itself out.

As there seemed to be no need for me to stay around the school any longer I gave Mr. Oke a small job to do and went back to my residence. Mr. Oke accompanied me in order to get some tools and electrical fitting he needed and which I had in my own work shop. As Mr. Oke was leaving to go back to the school at about 11:30 a.m. I said to him, "Whatever you do watch that chimney. To be on the safe side it is advisable for you to keep an eye on it all day."

At about 12:30 p.m. Miss A.E. Hall telephoned me to say that the school was on fire. On my way up to the school I noticed three things:- (1) That the children were lined up outside the building. (2) That the water pump was in operation. (3) That smoke was coming from almost every portion of the roof. Judging from the smoke it was felt then that the building was doomed. After ascertaining that all the children were in a place of safety I went into the school and up to the top floor. It was found impossible to get up
into the attic on account of the dense smoke. Mr. Perfitt, Mr. Oke and Mr. Titley had, prior to my arrival, succeeded in getting into the attic but could not see anything in the way of fire nor stay there for more than a minute or two because of the smoke. To fight the fire in the attic was a physical impossibility especially when I arrived. The only place it could be fought was by directing a stream of water from the floor below up through the trap-door which led into the attic. This was the way a similar fire was extinguished some fifteen years ago. It was right here though that all our efforts were doomed to failure.

For some reason or other after the fire of approximately 15 years ago, someone built in the attic of the school a room with walls and ceiling. In this room was the water tank which supplied the school. The only opening into the main attic was through this room. As one stood on the floor below and looked up through the trap-door all that could be seen was the ceiling of this room. This was the barrier which prevented us from seeing the chimney rafters of the roof and from directing any stream of water or chemicals where it was needed. In discussing this fire with Mr. Matthew Watson who helped extinguish the one of about fifteen years ago he said that this room was not there when they fought the previous fire and that it was undoubtedly the presence of this room which prevented anyone from putting out the fire which ultimately destroyed the school. Why this room was built no one seems to know, naturally thought that it was part of the original building but apparently not. I feel sure that since its erection no principal or male member of the staff ever thought it would be a menace. Three things we have learned from this fire: (1) that brick chimneys such as the one put up in the school are not safe; (2) that the brick work should be inspected periodically by someone competent to do so. It seems strange that most chimneys should be encased from almost the top to the bottom with a combination of woodwork, lath and plaster, the woodwork coming into close contact with the bricks. Such an arrangement makes periodic inspection of the bricks and the chimney an impossibility without tearing down part of the building; (3) that wherever a brick chimney goes into an attic there should be two trap doors at least in the ceiling through which, when open, one can have an unrestricted view of both sides of the chimney where it goes through the roof. This I consider is of the greatest importance.

Now as to the cause of the fire. It could not have been electrical for the school building was rewired last summer, all the wires being placed in conduit. There were absolutely no exposed wires in the attic and each circuit in the building was guarded by fuses of the correct amperage. It was not likely caused by a spark from the chimney because the roof was of corrugated galvanized iron and any sparks or burning embers coming from the chimney in the morning would have been carried clear of the building by the fairly strong wind that was blowing. There is no question but that the fire started in the attic.

After the building was burnt to the ground the chimney, which was still standing, was examined as closely as possible. There were several openings in the brick and these it was found were places where ventilators entered the chimney. Apparently this chimney was used as a ventilating shaft as well as for a chimney. One theory advanced as to the cause of the fire was that creosote, having seeped through the butt joints in the steel casing, ran into the ventilators and caught on fire. As these shafts were not insulated from the woodwork a fire could easily be caused in this way.

After the Superintendent of the Indian Affairs for the Yukon had made his inspection he gave us orders to have the chimney brought down. This we did with the use of dynamite. On examining the steel casing it was noticed that on the outside were marks of burnt creosote. Evidently creosote had seeped through the joints of this casing and had ignited when the chimney caught on fire.
As there was an air space between the round steel casing and the bricks of the chimney quite a fire could burn in there without our knowledge. The fire either broke into the building through the ventilating shafts or through a crack in the bricks where the chimney went through the roof. I am inclined to the latter theory because when the fire of fifteen years ago started there was no steel casing. This pointed to the fact that the brickwork of the chimney was faulty. As far as I can remember only one ventilating shaft went into the chimney in the attic and that did not come into contact with wood until it reached the ceiling of the floor below. I am fairly certain that the fire started where the chimney went through the roof.

When it was found that the fire could not be fought through the trap door Mr. A. Perfitt and one of the senior boys went up on the roof with fire extinguishers. Mr. Perfitt, who had only just been relieved of the duties of Night Watchman, tore part of the galvanized roofing off and did his best to extinguish the blaze. He stayed on the roof until the metal sheeting was too hot to stand on. By that time the fire had such a hold that only thing to do was to save as much of the contents of the building as possible. To give you some idea of the rapidity with which the fire spread I may say that shortly after my arrival at the scene I telephoned to Carcross Village for assistance. Some of the employees of the Northern Airways Ltd. came over in a car at once but by the time they reached the school, situated only 1½ miles from town, the fire was out of control.

A great and magnificent work was done by the residents of Carcross. Nearly every able bodied man who could leave his post came to our assistance. You can form some conception of their work from the attached lists of food supplies and articles saved. The work of removing the contents of the school building and the workshop went on until it was not safe to be in either building. I would like to make special mention of the work of Mr. A. Perfitt. He certainly deserves great credit not only for the efforts he made to put out the fire but for the way in which he worked afterwards. The energy he displayed and the cool-headed way in which he acted was an inspiration to us all. It was not a question of someone working for a salary for two days previous to the fire he ceased to be Night Watchman and was staying on for three days more or less as a guest of the school. The staff who were saved or had saved most of their belongings but apparently Mr. Perfitt gave his not a thought. He was more concerned with saving the goods of others. His greatest loss was an Arctic Sleeping Robe or Bed worth approximately $60.00. I wish something could be done to reimburse him for his loss. He certainly deserves it.

In about two hours the school and workshop were nothing more than a mass of ruins. The question then arose as to what should be done to provide accommodation for the children and staff. Mr. Matthew Watson offered the use of any empty houses he had in the village and the White Pass and Yukon Railway placed at our disposal the Section House in Carcross. It was finally decided to use the Section House as a cook house and dining hall, the Rectory for a Girl's Residence with Miss Hall and Miss Shepherd in charge and the largest of Mr. Watson's Houses as a Boys' Dormitory with Mrs. Butler and Miss Moulton in charge.

As soon as this plan was decided on all the bedding (it was practically all saved) food supplies, children and staff were loaded on three sleighs and towed over to Carcross on the ice in one trip by a caterpillar belonging to the Northern Airways Ltd. The sleds were deposited at the section house and the children taken to their place of abode. As soon as they were more or less settled Miss Moulton was instructed to proceed over to the Section House and get supper. Great was her surprise to find that the Section Foreman, Mr. J. McMurphy and his crew had not only set the tables but had supper all ready for the children and staff. Mrs. McMurphy
sent over to our new dining hall enough milk made out of Klim to supply all needs that evening and I believe the next morning. I cannot speak too highly of the assistance rendered by Mr. and Mrs. J. McMurphy of Carcross. It is really wonderful to think that in spite of what had happened the children and staff never missed a meal.

After supper, Mr. George Simmone, President of the Northern Airways Ltd., placed at our disposal his caterpillar and its driver to help get under cover food supplies and other articles which had been saved and which might spoil if left outside during the night. Besides the caterpillar driver many willing hands helped us until darkness intervened. When forced to stop nothing remained outside which should have been under cover.

As you can imagine there was no sleep for some of us that night. Besides the crumbling ruins to watch there were many things to think of. In the hours of darkness it occurred to me that the only way to meet this catastrophe was to make an effort to carry on as if nothing had happened. As far as the children were concerned they had to be kept occupied and as far as the future was concerned it was felt that our chances of having the school rebuilt were strengthened greatly if we could show the Department's representative and others that even though the school may be burnt Chootla Indian Residential School still goes on.

It was with these two ends in view that at daybreak Messrs. Oke, Tittley and myself loaded on to the wagon (Mr. Perfitt also gave valuable assistance) the school desks, scribblers etc., which were saved from the conflagration. These were taken over to Carcross and placed in a house which Mr. Matthew Watson had kindly placed at our disposal and which we decided to use as a classroom. It took most of the morning to get things arranged but here again we were fortunate in having the services of the White Pass Section Crew which the Station Agent, Mr. J. Bowie, placed at our disposal. By noon the classroom reopened, twenty four hours after the fire started. Great credit is due Miss Hall for carrying on in the classroom so soon after a nerve wracking experience and with so little equipment.

If any question arises as to the need of a residential school in this part of Canada I think that this incident should convince the most skeptical. In order to cut down the amount of sleeping accommodation required all those children who had homes in Carcross were allowed to go to their parents. About 10 or 12 pupils were dealt with in this way. It was only a matter of about two days before it was necessary to take 6 back. This I was requested to do by those responsible for them. The plan was that they had not the wherewithal to provide for these children.

The day after the fire Bishop Geddes and Indian Agent Major Sandys-Wunsch, R.C.M.P., arrived in Carcross. In dealing with the situation Major Sandys-Wunsch acted as follows:

1. Tried to rent for an indefinite period the White Pass and Yukon Railway Section House. This he was unable to do.

2. Made arrangements with Mr. Matthew Watson for the rental, by the Department of certain houses in Carcross some of which we were then occupying. I may say here that Mr. Matthew Watson offered to let the school have the use of these buildings rent free but to this arrangement the Indian Agent would not agree.

3. Stated that he would get Mr. J.E. French, Builder and Contractor at Whitehorse to come to Carcross and do any carpentry work necessary. One of the jobs he is to do is to cover over the basement of the Workshop so that it can be used as a place to store vegetables during next winter. Mr. French at present is making table tops, trestles, benches, etc. In connection with these I may say that in a few days...
time we will have to move out of the W.P. and Y.R. Section House. The Railway company will need the use of this building for their employees about May 6th. Our Kitchen and Dining Hall will then be located in one of Mr. Matthew Watson's largest houses. Into this place has already been put a good size range loaned to us by the White Pass and Yukon Railway, the table tops, trestles and benches which Mr. French has made. This building will make an admirable Kitchen and Dining Room.

4. Major Sandys-Wunsch authorized me to purchase such items as kitchen utensils, dishes, etc., from the local store. These are being charged to the Department of Indian Affairs. The order for these things was placed and the goods have arrived with the exception of dishes for the children. These are expected to arrive in a day or so. In the meantime the White Pass and Yukon Railway have loaned us what is needed.

5. Statements were taken by the Indian Agent from all the men agents on the staff and also from Mr. A. Perfit. These were taken down in writing by Major Sandys-Wunsch and signed by the person concerned. These statements were mainly in connection with the cause of the fire and steps taken to extinguish same. The Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Yukon (Mr. Bennett) kindly allowed Bishop Geddes and myself to read the several statements and there was no disagreement nor was anyone incriminated. Before leaving Carcross Major Sandys-Wunsch also let me read a telegram he was sending to the Commissioner, R.C.M.P., asking him to inform the minister that a full investigation had been conducted and that the cause of the fire was accidental.

6. The Indian Agent before leaving, asked me to wire him as soon as possible regarding certain needs which were discussed during his visit. My telegram to him reads as follows:

"Kindly request Department to supply soon two H and P washing machines four steel bath tubs six only wash tubs two only wash boilers twenty two double deck bunks six wash boards and six Coleman gasoline lamps at total estimated cost of seven hundred dollars stop kindly ask Department of Public Printing and Stationery to supply soon following school supplies five only Friend's Primer five only Primer's School book nine only Grade two Readers seven only Grade three Readers one large box letter tickets one large box number tickets twelve Composition work books for Grade four eight senior nature and language work books and twelve only boxes ink powder."

Apparently the Indian Agent is writing by Air Mail from Dawson to Ottawa regarding these matters. In this telegram is mentioned Double Deck Bunks. These will be admirable when one considers the limited amount of floor space in the buildings now occupied. I may say that at the present time we have the use of a limited number of double deck bunks and springs loaned to the school by the White Pass and Yukon Railway.

7. The Indian Agent spoke of a possible change of site for the school should the Department decide to rebuild. Ten Mile was mentioned as being most suitable. There would be many advantages in connection with such a move the chief ones being the nearness to an abundant supply of hay and the ease with which wood could be procured. It is said that the soil, from an agriculture point of view, is far better at Ten Mile than it is here. There are of course certain disadvantages so that matters would have to be gone into very carefully before any definite decision to move is made. Two disadvantages might be mentioned here:- (1) The difficulty in getting a doctor when one was needed. In the Spring and Fall of the year, communication between Carcross and Ten Mile is very difficult. (2) It would not be so costly to rebuild on the old site as it would be at Ten Mile. Here we have most of the outbuildings, the sewerage system and the excavation. It is possible that a building could be erected on the
old foundation. Whether the Department decides to build on the old site or move to another what is needed is a modern fireproof structure, or several smaller buildings (see next paragraph) with accommodation for at least 80 pupils.

In approaching the question of rebuilding I feel that careful consideration should be given to what might be called the "Cottage System". Instead of putting up one large building have several small buildings. These could be as follows:

1. Boy's Residence. In this building provide accommodation for at least two or more workers.

2. Girl's Residence. with staff accommodation as above.

3. Laundry

4. Class Room and Chapel

5. Cook House and Dining Room combined.

6. Principal's Residence.

Two very great advantages would be derived from such a system:

1. If one building was destroyed by fire the loss would not be so great. The buildings could be so arranged in relation to one another that a destruction by fire of one would not menace another. In a one building school the destruction of that building by fire means practically the loss of everything.

2. The life of the children in such surroundings would be more nearly that which they will have to accustom themselves to when they go home. I would recommend that these buildings be heated by stoves, lighted by lamps and have no running water or sewerage systems. One of the significant things that arose out of the recent fire was that the children, when moved to their new quarters (which is practically the "Cottage System") for a few days were quite at a loss how to act.

I am convinced that the best way to fit the Indian children for the life they will have to live when they leave school is to have their life in school as similar as possible to the life they will have to live at home.

In closing this report I would like to give the following information concerning the staff:

1. Each member of the staff has a room of their own and a comfortable bed to sleep on. No doubling up has been necessary.

2. Staff members saved practically all of their personal effects.

3. The staff have even their own dining room, which is situated in the same building in which the children eat.

4. Both the Girl's and Boy's Supervisor have the use of washing machines operated by a gasoline engine. The Girls Supervisor uses one loaned by Mrs. Matthew Watson and the Boy's Supervisor has the use of one at the Principal's residence.

5. Miss P.E. Shepherd, R.N., and Miss A.E. Hall have separate accommodation in the Girl's Residence.

6. Miss W. Moulton has her own room in the building used for a Dining Hall and Kitchen. Mr. C.A. Oke has quarters in this building also.
7. Mr. G. Titley, the Farm Instructor is staying with us at the Principal's Residence. At one time Mrs. Grant and myself thought of moving over to Carcross Village. Two things, however, made it necessary and advisable for us to remain where we are. In the first place no suitable house is available in Carcross. In the second place I will have to be here during the haying season. During that time all men agents are needed to put up hay and someone has to be on the school premises to look after the cows, chickens, gardens, etc. It is not possible living here to keep in touch with the work in Carcross Village. The distance is only about 1½ miles and telephonic communication can be entered into at any time. At night time Mr. O.A. Oke is in Carcross and can be easily called if needed.

Trusting that the foregoing report proves to be satisfactory. The same is respectfully submitted by
