REPORT ON THE FIRE WHICH DESTROYED THE CHOOUTLA INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL BUILDING AND WORKSHOP ON APRIL 17th, 1939.

At about 10.15 a.m. on April 17th 1939, Mr. G.A. Oke, who has held the position of Engineer here since August 1936, came to my residence and reported that the stove pipes in the school kitchen and the chimney were on fire. This news was not regarded as being of much import for on an average of once a year during the last eight years the same thing had happened with the danger by fire to the building. However, to be on the safe side, I went up to the School immediately and found that whilst the stove pipes in the kitchen had burnt out a deposit of creosote in the chimney was on fire. It was felt that as in the past the chimney would give all the protection necessary. The chimney I may say was constructed of brick and in the centre was a heavy steel casing through which the smoke passed. This steel casing was put in some years ago after fire broke out in the attic the cause believed to be due to a faulty chimney. Between the outside of the steel casing and the bricks there was an air space. It is hard to understand why a flue lining was not put into this chimney when the school was built. Such a lining would have been a safeguard to the building in the event of the chimney settling. It seems almost certain that in the course of years the chimney settled with the exception of that part which protrudes above the roof. This part would be held up by the flashings and so there would naturally be a crack or opening in the brickwork where the chimney came into contact with the roof. The writer had examined the chimney on several occasions but it is just possible that a crack could be hidden by woodwork. It was felt that even if there was a crack the steel casing would provide all the safety necessary. I am positive that if a proper flue lining, the usual non-metallic kind used in chimneys, had been installed when the school was built, the fire of fifteen years ago and the recent one would never have occurred. The steel casing was the next best thing but through the several joints, six in number, creosote could quite easily leak into the space between the outside of the steel casing and the bricks. At the joints of the steel casing the various lengths were merely butted together and there was no overlapping as it is felt there should have been. I am inclined to think that the matter of a flue lining should be taken up with the Department for it is hard to understand how such an important item could have been left out of the specifications.

As a precautionary measure I asked Mr. Oke if he had been up to the attic to see if everything was alright. He said, "No". Instructions were then given for him to do so and after awhile he came back and reported that there was no sign of fire and that, on feeling right around the chimney where it came into contact with the roof it was found to be just warm. By this time it was about 10.30 a.m. At eleven o'clock Mr. Oke and I inspected the chimney again and to all appearances the fire seemed to have burnt itself out.

As there seemed to be no need for me to stay around the school any longer I gave Mr. Oke a small job to do and went back to my residence. Mr. Oke accompanied me in order to get some tools and electrical fittings he needed and which I had in my own work shop. As Mr. Oke was leaving to go back to the school at about 11.30 a.m. I said to him, "Whatever you do watch that chimney. To be on the safe side it is advisable for you to keep an eye on it all day."

At about 12.30 p.m. Miss A.E. Hall telephoned me to say that the school was on fire. On my way up to the school I noticed three things—(1) That the children were lined up outside the building. (2) That the water pump was in operation. (3) That smoke was coming from almost every portion of the roof. Judging from the smoke it was felt then that the building was doomed. After ascertaining that all the children were in a place of safety I went into the school and up to the top floor. It was found impossible to get up
into the attic on account of the dense smoke. Mr. Perfitt, Mr. Oke and Mr. Titley had, prior to my arrival, succeeded in getting into the attic but could not see anything in the way of fire nor stay there for more than a minute or two because of the smoke. To fight the fire in the attic was a physical impossibility especially when I arrived. The only place it could be fought was by directing a stream of water from the floor below up through the trap-door which led into the attic. This was the way a similar fire was extinguished some fifteen years ago. It was right here though that all our efforts were doomed to failure.

For some reason or other after the fire of approximately 15 years ago, someone built in the attic of the school a room with walls and ceiling. In this room was the water tank which supplied the school. The only opening into the main attic was through this room. As one stood on the floor below and looked up through the trap-door all that could be seen was the ceiling of this room. This was the barrier which prevented us from seeing the chimney, rafters of the roof and from directing any stream of water or chemicals where it was needed. In discussing this fire with Mr. Matthews Watson who helped extinguish the one of about fifteen years ago he said that this room was not there when they fought the previous fire and that it was undoubtedly the presence of this room which prevented anyone from putting out the fire which ultimately destroyed the school. Why this room was built no one seems to know. I naturally thought that it was part of the original building but apparently not. I feel sure that since its erection no Principal or male member of the staff ever thought it would be a menace. Three things we have learned from this fire: (1) that brick chimneys, such as the one put up in the school, are not safe. (2) that the brick work should be inspected periodically by someone competent to do so. It seems strange that most chimneys should be enclosed from almost the top to the bottom with a combination of woodwork, lath and plaster, the woodwork coming into close contact with the bricks. Such an arrangement makes terrific inspection of the bricks in the chimney impossible without tearing down part of the building. (3) that wherever a brick chimney goes into an attic there should be two fire doors at least in the ceiling through which, when open, one can have an unrestricted view of both sides of the chimney where it goes through the roof. This I consider is of the greatest importance.

Now as to the cause of the fire. It could not have been electrical for the school building was rewired last summer, all the wires being placed in conduit. There were absolutely no exposed wires in the attic and each circuit in the building was guarded by fuses of the correct amperage. It was not likely caused by a spark from the chimney because the roof was of corrugated galvanized iron and any sparks or burning creosote coming from the chimney in the morning would have been carried clear of the building by the fairly strong wind that was blowing. There is no question but that the fire started in the attic.

After the building was burnt to the ground the chimney, which was still standing, was examined as closely as possible. There were several openings in the brick and these it was found were places where ventilators entered the chimney. Apparently this chimney was used as a ventilating shaft as well as for a chimney. One theory advanced as to the cause of the fire was that creosote, having seeped through the butt joints in the steel casing, ran into the ventilators and caught on fire. As these shafts were not insulated from the woodwork a fire could easily be caused in this way.

After the Superintendent of the Indian Affairs for the Yukon had made his inspection he gave us orders to have the chimney brought down. This we did with the use of dynamite. On examining the steel casing it was noticed that on the outside were marks of burnt creosote. Evidently creosote had seeped through the joints of this casing and had ignited when the chimney caught on fire.
As there was an air space between the round steel casing and the bricks of the chimney quite a fire could burn in there without our knowledge. The fire either broke into the building through the ventilating shafts or through a crack in the bricks where the chimney went through them. I am inclined to the latter theory because when the fire of fifteen years ago started there was no steel casing. This pointed to the fact that the brickwork of the chimney was faulty. As far as I can remember only one ventilating shaft went into the chimney in the attic and that did not come into contact with wood until it reached the ceiling of the floor below. I am fairly certain that the fire started where the chimney went through the roof.

When it was found that the fire could not be fought through the trap door Mr. A. Perfitt and one of the senior boys went up on the roof with fire extinguishers. Mr. Perfitt, who had only just been relieved of the duties of Night Watchman, tore part of the galvanized roofing off and did his best to extinguish the blaze. He stayed on the roof until the metal sheathing was too hot to stand on. By that time the fire had such a hold the only thing to do was to save as much of the contents of the building as possible. To give you some idea of the rapidity with which the fire spread I may say that shortly after Mr. and Mrs. at the school I telephoned to Carcross Village for assistance. Some of the employees of the Northern Airways Ltd., came over in a car at once but by the time they reached the school, situated only 1½ miles from town, the fire was out of control.

A great and magnificent work was done by the residents of Carcross. Nearly every able bodied man who could leave his post came to our assistance. You can form some conception of their work from the attached lists of food supplies and articles saved. The work of removing the contents of the school building and the workshop went on until it was not safe to be in either building. I would like to make special mention of the work of Mr. A. Perfitt. He certainly deserves great credit not only for the efforts he made to put out the fire but for the way in which he worked afterwards. The energy he displayed and the cool-headed way in which he acted was an inspiration to us all. It was not a question of someone working for a salary for two days previous to the fire he ceased to be Night Watchman and was staying on for a few days more or less as a guest of the school. The staff members saved or had saved most of their belongings but apparently Mr. Perfitt gave his not a thought. He was more concerned with saving the goods of others. His greatest loss was an Arctic Sleeping Robe or Bed worth approximately $60.00. I wish something could be done to reimburse him for his loss. He certainly deserves it.

In about two hours the school and workshop were nothing more than a mass of ruins. The question then arose as to what should be done to provide accommodation for the children and staff. Mr. Matthew Watson offered the use of the empty houses he had in the village and the White Pass and Yukon Railway placed at our disposal the section house in Carcross. It was finally decided to use the Section House as a cook house and dining hall, the Rectory for a Girl's Residence with Miss Hall and Miss Shepherd in charge and the largest of Mr. Watson's Houses as a Boys' Dormitory with Mrs. Butler and Miss Moulton in charge.

As soon as this plan was decided on all the bedding (it was practically all saved) food supplies, children and staff were loaded on three sleighs and toed over to Carcross on the ice in one trip by a caterpillar tractor belonging to the Northern Airways Ltd. The food was deposited at the section house and the children taken to their place of abode. As soon as they were more or less settled Miss Moulton was instructed to proceed over to the Section House and get supper. Great was her surprise to find that the Section Foreman, Mr. J. McMurphy and his crew had not only set the tables but had supper all ready for the children and staff. Mrs. McMurphy
sent over to our new dining hall enough milk made out of Klim to supply all needs that evening and I believe the next morning. I cannot speak too highly of the assistance rendered by Mr. and Mrs. J. McMurphy of Carcross. It is really wonderful to think that in spite of what had happened the children and staff never missed a meal.

After supper, Mr. George Simmons, President of the Northern Airways Ltd., placed at our disposal his caterpillar and its driver to help get under cover food supplies and other articles which had been saved and which might spoil if left outside during the night. Besides the caterpillar driver many willing hands helped us until darkness intervened. When forced to stop nothing remained outside which should have been under cover.

As you can imagine there was no sleep for some of us that night. Besides the smouldering ruins to watch there were many things to think of. In the hours of darkness it occurred to me that the only way to meet this catastrophe was to make an effort to carry on as if nothing had happened. As far as the children were concerned they had to be kept occupied and as far as the future was concerned it was felt that our chances of having the school rebuilt were strengthened greatly if we could show the Department's representative and others that even though the school may be burnt Chootla Indian Residential School still goes on.

It was with these two ends in view that at daybreak Messrs. Oke, Titley and myself loaded on to the wagon (Mr. Perfitt also gave valuable assistance) the school desks, scribblers, etc., which were saved from the conflagration. These were taken over to Carcross and placed in a house which Mr. Matthew Watson had kindly placed at our disposal and which we decided to use as a classroom. It took most of the morning to get things arranged but here again we were fortunate in having the services of the White Pass Section Crew which the Station Agent, Mr. J. Bowie, placed at our disposal. By noon the classroom reopened twenty four hours after the fire started. Great credit is due Miss Hall for carrying on in the classroom so soon after a nerve wracking experience and with so little equipment.

If any question arises as to the need of a residential school in this part of Canada I think that this incident should convince the most skeptical. In order to cut down the amount of sleeping accommodation required all those children who had homes in Carcross were allowed to go to their parents. About 10 or 12 pupils were dealt with in this way. It was only a matter of about two days before it was necessary to take 8 back. This I was requested to do by those responsible for them. The plea was that they had not the wherewithal to provide for these children.

The day after the fire Bishop Geddes and Indian Agent Major Sandys-Wunsch, R.C.M.P., arrived in Carcross. In dealing with the situation Major Sandys-Wunsch acted as follows:

1. Tried to rent for an indefinite period the White Pass and Yukon Railway Section House. This he was unable to do.

2. Made arrangements with Mr. Matthew Watson for the rental, by the Department of certain houses in Carcross some of which we were then occupying. I may say here that Mr. Matthew Watson offered to let the school have the use of these buildings rent free but to this arrangement the Indian Agent would not agree.

3. Stated that he would get Mr. J.E. French, Builder and Contractor at Whitehorse to come to Carcross and do any carpentry work necessary. One of the jobs he is to do is to cover over the basement of the Workshop so that it can be used as a place to store vegetables during next winter. Mr. French at present is making table tops, trestles, benches, etc. In connection with these I may say that in a few days...
time we will have to move out of the W.P. and Y.R. Section House. The Railway company will need the use of this building for their employees about May 6th. Our Kitchen and Dining Hall will then be located in one of Mr. Matthew Watson's largest houses. Into this place has already been put a good size range loaned to us by the White Pass and Yukon Railway, the table tops, trestles and benches which Mr. French has made. This building will make an admirable Kitchen and Dining Room.

4. Major Sandys-Wunsch authorized me to purchase such items as kitchen utensils, dishes, etc., from the local store. These are being charged to the Department of Indian Affairs. The order for these things was placed and the goods have arrived with the exception of dishes for the children. These are expected to arrive in a day or so. In the meantime the White Pass and Yukon Railway have loaned us what is needed.

5. Statements were taken by the Indian Agent from all the men agents on the staff and also from Mr. A. Perfitt. These were taken down in writing by Major Sandys-Wunsch and signed by the person concerned. These statements were mainly in connection with the cause of the fire and steps taken to extinguish same. The Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Yukon (Indian Agent) kindly allowed Bishop Goddes and myself to read the several statements and there was no disagreement nor was anyone incriminated. Before leaving Carcross Major Sandys-Wunsch also let me read a telegram he was sending to the Commissioner, R.C.M.P., asking him to inform the minister that a full investigation had been conducted and that the cause of the fire was accidental.

6. The Indian Agent before leaving, asked me to wire him as soon as possible regarding certain needs which were discussed during his visit. My telegram to him reads as follows:

"Kindly request Department to supply soon two H and P washing machines four steel bath tubs six only wash tubs two only wash boilers twenty two double deck bunks six wash boards and six Coleman gasoline lamps at total estimated cost of seven hundred dollars stop Kindly ask Department of Public Printing and Stationery to supply soon following school supplies five only Friend's Primer five only Friend's Work book nine only Grade two Readers seven only Grade three Readers one large box letter tickets one large box number tickets twelve Composition work books for Grade four eight senior nature and language work books and twelve only boxes ink powder."

Apparently the Indian Agent is writing by Air Mail from Dawson to Ottawa regarding these matters. In this telegram is mentioned Double Deck Bunks. These will be admirable when one considers the limited amount of floor space in the buildings now occupied. I may say that at the present time we have the use of a limited number of double deck bunks and springs loaned to the school by the White Pass and Yukon Railway.

7. The Indian Agent spoke of a possible change of site for the school should the Department decide to rebuild. Ten Mile was mentioned as being most suitable. There would be many advantages in connection with such a move; the chief ones being the nearness to an abundant supply of hay and the ease with which wood could be procured. It is said that the soil, from an agriculture point of view, is far better at Ten Mile than it is here. There are of course certain disadvantages so the matter would have to be gone into very carefully before any definite decision to move is made. Two disadvantages might be mentioned here:-(1) The difficulty in getting a doctor when one was needed. In the Spring and Fall of the year communication between Carcross and Ten Mile is very difficult. (2) It would not be so costly to rebuild on the old site as it would be at Ten Mile. Here we have most of the outbuildings, the sewerage system and the excavation. It is possible that a building could be erected on the
old foundation. Whether the Department decides to build on the old site or move to another what is needed is a modern fireproof structure, or several smaller buildings (See next paragraph) with accommodation for at least 80 pupils.

In approaching the question of rebuilding I feel that careful consideration should be given to what might be called the "Cottage System". Instead of putting up one large building have several small buildings. These could be as follows:-

1. Boy's Residence. In this building provide accommodation for at least two or more workers.

2. Girl's Residence. with staff accommodation as above.

3. Laundry

4. Class Room and Chapel

5. Cook House and Dining Room combined.

6. Principal's Residence.

Two very great advantages would be derived from such a system:-

1. If one building was destroyed by fire the loss would not be so great. The buildings could be so arranged in relation to one another that a destruction by fire of one would not menace another. In a one building school the destruction of that building by fire means practically the loss of everything.

2. The life of the children in such surroundings would be more nearly that which they will have to accustom themselves to when they go home. I would recommend that these buildings be heated by stoves, lighted by lamps and have no running water or sewerage systems. One of the significant things that arose out of the recent fire was that the children, when moved to their new quarters (which is practically the "Cottage System") for a few days were quite at a loss how to act.

I am convinced that the best way to fit the Indian children for the life they will have to live when they leave school is to have their life in school as similar as possible to the life they will have to live at home.

In closing this report I would like to give the following information concerning the staff:-

1. Each member of the staff has a room of their own and a comfortable bed to sleep on. No doubling up has been necessary.

2. Staff members saved practically all of their personal effects.

3. The staff have even their own dining room, which is situated in the same building in which the children eat.

4. Both the Girl's and Boy's Supervisor have the use of washing machines operated by a gasoline engine. The Girls Supervisor uses one loaned by Mrs. Matthew Watson and the Boy's Supervisor has the use of one at the Principal's residence.

5. Miss P.E. Shepherd, R.N., and Miss A.E. Hall have separate accommodation in the Girl's Residence.

6. Miss W. Moulton has her own room in the building used for a Dining Hall and Kitchen. Mr. C.A. Oke has quarters in this building also.
7. Mr. G. Titley, the Farm Instructor is staying with us at the Principal's Residence. At one time Mrs. Grant and myself thought of moving over to Carcross Village. Two things, however, made it necessary and advisable for us to remain where we are. In the first place no suitable house is available in Carcross. In the second place I will have to be here during the haying season. During that time all men agents are needed to put up hay and someone has to be on the school premises to look after the cows, chickens, garden, etc. It is not hard, living here, to keep in touch with the work in Carcross Village. The distance is only about 1½ miles and telephonic communication can be entered into at any time. At night time Mr. C.A. Oke is in Carcross and can be easily called if needed.

Trusting that the foregoing report proves to be satisfactory. The same is respectfully submitted by

(Sgd) H.C.M. Grant, Principal.

Ottawa, May 27, 1939.

MEMO FOR FILE:

Re: Carcross Residential School

Yesterday the following representatives of the Church of England visited the Department:

Archbishop Roper, Ottawa,
Archdeacon Snowden, Ottawa,
Reverend L. A. Dixon, Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dr. McGill and I discussed with them the situation that has arisen due to the destruction by fire of the Carcross Residential School.

Reverend Mr. Dixon stated that it was the opinion of the M. S. C. C. that when the Carcross school is rebuilt it should provide accommodation for at least 50 pupils. At the time of the destruction of the school by fire, per capita allowance was only being paid for 40 pupils.

All those mentioned above urged the immediate rebuilding of the school, but it was pointed out to them that this could not be done during the current fiscal year. They were promised, however, that the Department would give every possible assistance in keeping the school in operation in the temporary buildings that have been rented for that purpose. Reverend Mr. Dixon expressed some doubt as to whether the rented buildings would be suitable for winter occupancy, and he was promised that the Principal of the school would be written for further information regarding this phase of the situation. It was suggested to them that possibly we could secure for the winter the section house owned by the White Horse and Yukon Railway.

Rev. Mr. Dixon promised to obtain further information regarding the reserves from which pupils are recruited for the Carcross School and to submit detailed information regarding this and also other information that might be necessary in connection with the erection of a new school. He was requested to let us have his report by August 1, in order that the matter could be studied before preparing the estimates for the fiscal year 1940-41.

Reverend Sir:

The Department has received a letter from Reverend T. B. R. Westgate, Secretary of the M. S. C. C., enclosing copy of your report on the destruction by fire of the Carcross Indian Residential School.

Yesterday, Reverend L. A. Dixon, Field Secretary of the M. S. C. C., visited the Department. He appeared to be under the impression that the buildings at present rented would not be suitable for next winter's occupancy. You did not mention this matter in your report, and I would appreciate having detailed information from you as soon as possible.

If the buildings that you have recently rented would not be suitable, could any other building be secured? The Department recently had an interview with Mr. Rogers, an official of the Whitehorse and Yukon Railway. While he did not state definitely that the large section house owned by this company could be used during the winter months, it is possible that such an arrangement could be made with the company. If you consider that this building would be an improvement on the ones that you have rented, you might take up the matter with the officials of the Whitehorse and Yukon Railway and, if possible, obtain some definite decision from them, which you should forward for our consideration.

An early reply would be appreciated.

1. A full statement of the requirements for the building to replace the one that was burned, as regards size, capacity, site, equipment, etc.

2. A statement of what is immediately needed to enable the school to carry on its work in the present emergency quarters.

Regarding the first of these statements, it is our understanding that its purpose is to enable you to include provision for the replacement of the school building in next year's estimates.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of the 16th Inst., in which you state a set of batteries for the Carcross School, Yukon Territory, has been supplied by MacKinnon Sales & Service, Ltd., Vancouver.

Of course, this is a Globelite product, manufactured in Winnipeg at an advertised price of $630.00, f.o.b. Winnipeg. Our quotation on this battery was $530.00, f.o.b. Vancouver.

Several COYLE battery sets are in use in Indian schools throughout this province, from which excellent results have been obtained; our product has been on the market for more than 16 years, and enjoys a first-class reputation. In view of this we feel that when the Dominion government has battery requirements in the west and north-west, preference should be given to the manufacturer in the field; particularly when the price is equal, or better, as in this case.

A very interesting solution of the economic problem came to our notice the other day. The suggestion was brought forward that legislation should be enacted whereby the banks would loan money for industrial purposes entirely without interest, and that the eight per cent. sales tax now going to the government should be handed instead to the banks, as their return for money invested. It was predicted that industrial expansion under these circumstances would take place so rapidly as to actually repay the government in income tax within a few years for the loss of the sales tax.

A suggestion such as this is worthy of grave consideration. It is certain that we in the west, at least, receive very little assistance or encouragement from the Federal government in the development of our industrial activities, in return for the millions of dollars that go to Ottawa annually in duties and taxes; to say nothing of the splendid co-operation extended by the west in any plans to benefit the Dominion as a whole.

While we have no animosity whatever toward the Globelite Company, we shall appreciate an opportunity to quote on future government requirements in British Columbia, and the courtesy of a serious consideration of our tender when submitted.

Yours very truly,

COYLE BATTERIES LIMITED.

Manager.

Dr. H. W. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

The Rev. L. A. Dixon, Field Secretary of our Society has informed me that when he and Archbishop Roper and Archdeacon Snowdon had an interview with you on May 26th last, regarding the building of a new School at Carcross for our Society, you requested:

(a) A statement of what is immediately needed to enable the School to carry on its work in the present emergency quarters.

(b) A full statement of the requirements for the new building.

With regard to (a), the immediate needs -- it is my understanding that most, if not all, of these have already been supplied by your Department at a cost, according to a statement received from the Principal (Rev. H. C. M. Grant), of $653.31. Should there be other requirements I do not think that they would be very costly.

With regard to (b), the requirements for the new School building, I beg to state that the Field Secretary of our Society and I had a conference with Bishop Geddes, Bishop of the Yukon, on the 13th inst., when we carefully considered this question, and agreed to submit certain specific recommendations to our Commission. Our Commission met yesterday and adopted the recommendations which were as follows:

(1) The site of the new building -- To be erected on or adjacent to the site occupied by the building destroyed by fire.

Very careful consideration was given to the question of having the site at either Whitehorse, approximately 40 miles
away, or at a place called Ten Mile, which is about that distance from Carcross, and from which the School now secures its hay supply. After carefully weighing the advantages and disadvantages of all three sites, we were agreed that the site on which the former School stood was the best.

(2) Style of Building -- As the Rev. Principal Grant had recommended, careful consideration of the adoption of what he called the "Cottage System", his suggestion was not overlooked.

However, our unanimous opinion was that the adoption of the "Cottage System" might be tried in a warmer climate, but would be quite unsuitable for one in that northern latitude. As the adoption of the "Cottage System" would require one separate building for the bigger boys, one for the smaller boys, one for the bigger girls, and one for the smaller girls, a kitchen and refectory combined, a classroom, two separate recreation rooms, a residence for the Principal, a Chapel, a laundry and bakery combined, a workshop and tool shop combined, toilets, etc., it was not thought that the provision of such would cost less than that of one large building. It was therefore definitely agreed to recommend that one large building be provided.

With regard to the building material and the making of the building as nearly fireproof as possible, it was thought that stone, of which there is an abundance in that part, might be used for the walls and partitions, with a galvanized iron roof, stone or brick chimneys, and fireproof lining for insulation on the inside of the walls and under the roof.

(3) With regard to the capacity of the new School building, it was decided to recommend that this should not be less than eighty (80).

The Indian population of the Yukon according to the latest census is 1,359, and of these, 1,282 are classed as Anglicans. While our Church operates seven Indian Day Schools in the Yukon, we learned from our Bishop that most of these are located in the Interior or the northern part of the territory, and that recruits for the Carcross School come mostly from the southern part. It was also felt that, as no School has been provided, though frequently requested, to take the place of the School once operated by our Church at Metlakahtla, that a number of children, especially those who are orphans or destitute, might be recruited for this School from northern British Columbia. As the Principal has never had any difficulty in securing the present official capacity of 40, and has sometimes been unable to take others who desired admission, it was felt that it would be a mistake when building a new school, not to provide sufficient capacity for a larger enrollment, and the number suggested was eighty (80).

A BRIEF HISTORY OF THE CHOOUTLA INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
(By the Rev. H. C. M. Grant)

OUR FIRST HOME—
The Chooutla Indian Residential School was first established at Carcross in the spring of 1903. It then consisted of two shacks one of which was constructed of logs.

For some years previous a small school was conducted at Forty-mile under Bishop Bompass, who made it a matter of personal concern. Mrs. Bompass also took a deep interest in the work.

For several years it was carried on rather as a home for orphans and neglected children. After Bishop Bompass had visited Caribou Crossing (now called Carcross) and had resided here for some time, in 1901 and 1902, he realized that this place had many advantages as a location for the school and in the spring of 1903 he removed the inmates from Forty-mile to Carcross. Miss Ellis, who was in charge of the school at the time, accompanied the children up the river there being eight or ten children in the school.

OUR SECOND HOME—
A small house in Carcross was procured from Mr. P. R. Peel and here the school was comfortably established. In 1903 the staff was composed of Bishop Bompass as teacher, and Miss Ellis Matson. Bishop and Mrs. Bompass lived in a log building, on the opposite side of the water, formerly erected as a road-house.

In order that the school children might be closer to the Mission, the Bishop in 1904 exchanged the school building for a log house occupied by the Police Detachment, and originally erected for a telegraph office. This remained the home of the school until the removal to a newly erected commodious building situated two miles away from the former location. Miss Ellis remained in charge until 1909 when Miss Collins became matron, and up to the end of 1911 the latter continued energetically to carry on the work so effectively inaugurated by Miss Ellis. The Rev. J. Hawskley and Archdeacon Canham have each in turn acted in the capacity of Principal during the time they were in charge of the Mission.

At different times Miss Dorothy Bindley and Miss Myrtle Purse assisted Miss Ellis. Afterwards, Miss Hutchison joined the staff as teacher. For a short time Miss Emily M. Dutton also assisted with the children, while Miss Edith Thompson (now Mrs. W. S. Watson) and Miss Maude Bell (now Mrs. Lauderdale) gave several years of faithful and diligent work to the school.

In 1911 Mr. E. D. Evans, who had considerable experience in Indian school work was appointed Principal.

OUR THIRD HOME—
In the spring of 1911 there was placed at the disposal of the Church of England in Canada a new building situated about 2 miles from the village of Carcross.

In spite of some discouragements in connection with Indian education, only those closely connected with an institution can fully understand the joy and satisfaction of knowing that in this home as well as in the first two...
many lives were uplifted, brightened and bettered.

On April 17th, 1939, the school building and workshop were completely destroyed by fire. This fire was believed to have been caused by an defective chimney. The material used has been good but we are indeed thankful to Almighty God that there were no casualties nor was anyone injured in any way.

OUR FOURTH HOME—

The difficulties in re-establishing ourselves after the fire were lessened to a considerable degree by the kindness and co-operation of many friends in Carcross. Our new quarters consist of a number of buildings in Carcross Village. The girls occupy one and the boys another. One house is used as a Kitchen and Dining Room and another as a Classroom. One of the greatest difficulties in connection with our new home is that there is no playground nearby for the children especially for the boys. This reason and other similar problems with which we are faced make it evident that our fourth home can only be regarded as one of a temporary nature. Here though we will likely have to remain until the Department of Indian Affairs provide us with new quarters.

OUR FIFTH HOME—

In this connection we often ask ourselves these questions: where will it be, and what form will it take?

A change of site has been suggested. The question of building at Ten Mile instead of on the site occupied by the third home should not be dismissed without careful consideration. Ten Mile is a place about fifteen miles from Carcross where there are remarkably good hay lands, good soil, plenty of fine wood and an adequate supply of water. Isolation from the Indian village commends itself also to those who have had experience in residential school work. It would seem that the advantages derived from a change of site outweigh the disadvantages.

In approaching the question of re-building I feel that careful consideration should be given to what might be called the 'Cottage System'. Instead of putting up one large building have several smaller buildings. These could be as follows:

1. Boys' Residence. In this building provide accommodation for at least two or more workers.
2. Girls' Residence. With staff accommodation as above.
3. Laundry.
4. Class Room and Chapel.
5. Cook House and Dining Room combined.
6. Principal's Residence.
7. Recreation Room & Gymnasium.

Two very great advantages would be derived from such a system:

1. If one building was destroyed by fire the loss would not be so great. The buildings could be so arranged in relation to one another that a destruction of one would not menace another. In one-building schools the destruction of that building by fire means practically the loss of everything.

2. The life of the children in such surroundings would be more nearly that which they will have to accustom themselves to when they go home. I would recommend that these buildings be heated by stoves, lighted by lamps and have no running water or sewerage systems. One of the significant things that arose out of the recent fire was that the children, when moved to their new quarters (which is practically the "Cottage System") for a few days, were quite at a loss how to act.

I am convinced that the best way to fit the Indian children for the life they will have to live when they leave school is to have their life in school as similar as possible to the life they will have to live at home.

The writer, who first entered Indian School work about 20 years ago, feels that the "Cottage System" should be given a fair trial. The cost of operating a school on the "Cottage System" might be more and might be less than the cost of operating a one-building school. The writer feels that it would be less. After all the matter of cost should not be the deciding factor. The welfare of the Indian child and his ability to adapt himself or herself to home conditions after leaving school are the most important considerations.

The education of the Indian child must go on. The writer feels that the following points will convince even the most sceptical that a new school building or buildings should be provided as soon as possible for the Indian children in the Yukon:

1. Every child whether White or Indian is entitled to an education.
2. It would be a terrible thing in this day and age if anyone could point to a certain group of people living in Canada and say there is a group of people who have been deprived of an education. There is absolutely no foundation for the common belief that the Indians of Canada are a vanishing race. While their numbers have varied considerably during the last thirty years, declining from 110,000 in 1907 to 104,000 in 1924 latest returns issued by the Department of Mines and Resources show that there are now approximately 114,000 Indians resident in the Dominion.

3. Hunting and trapping, the natural life of the Indian, will soon be a thing of the past. The Indians will then have to turn to some other means of livelihood. The education that is now being given them is partly for the purpose of enabling them to meet changing conditions. We must prepare the Indian in some way for the time when he can no longer depend upon hunting and trapping as a means of livelihood.

4. In our school at the present time there are several orphans. What would become of them if there was no residential school?

5. A few days ago the Medical Officer of our school requested the writer to take in as soon as possible two children who were practically starving. For cases such as these a residential school of some kind or other renders a signal service to those who are in need.

We look forward with hope and faith, not only to the time when the new school buildings will be provided by a kind and beneficial government but to the years of usefulness and promise, which under God's blessing, we are assured are in store for our "Chootin Indian Residential School."

CHILDREN OF CHOOUTLA INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL HOMELESS

It was a sad day on April 17th for 44 Indian children when the Chooutla Indian Residential School burned to the ground. The tall brick chimney alone remained as a monument to the late Bishop Bompas, who first saw the great need for such a school.

Some of the orphaned and neglected children shed tears as they saw their home burning; for some of these it has meant home for as long as six to twelve years.

A few hours after the fire teams travelled into Carcross with loads of mattresses, bedding, school desks, supplies and an assortment of goods which had been hurriedly thrown through the windows of the burning school. The White Pass and Yukon Railway offered the Section House as a temporary shelter. Mr. Matthew Watson, General Merchant at Carcross, offered three of his houses to be used until the new building is constructed. The Carcross Rectory is being remodelled to be used as the Girls' Dormitory and living quarters for Miss Sheppard, R.N., Girls' Supervisor and Miss Hall, the Teacher. One of Mr. Watson's houses is to be used as a Boys' Dormitory and quarters for Mrs. Butler, Boys' Supervisor. Yet another house serves as kitchen and dining room.

Much credit is due the Reverend H. C. M. Grant, Principal, who within twenty-four hours after the fire had the children attending their regular classes in the former R.C.M.P. Barracks in Carcross. Mr. Grant has been tireless in his efforts to make the Chooutla School efficient in every way.

Contrary to the belief of most Canadians the Indian Race is not becoming extinct, for its population shows an increase of over four thousand over the previous year. If such is the case, the Canadian people must continue their efforts in educating the Indians to our own standards of living. Their former mode of life, viz. Hunting, Trapping and Fishing is fast becoming an inadequate means of livelihood for this increasing population. Nothing remains but to help them find a new way to live in their quickly changing conditions of life.

It is therefore sincerely hoped that the Department of Indian Affairs, along with the help of the Missionary Society of the Church of England, will see fit to rebuild the Chooutla School at Carcross.

(Signed) J. R. BOWIE,
Correspondent.

DAWSON—St. Paul's Pro-Cathedral—Space will not permit a detailed account of all the items of interest which have taken place since the last issue of Northern Lights, but viewing the more recent activities of the work here, I would like to mention the very great joy it has given us to have had Sergt. C. B. Tidd, help with the services as organist. All have appreciated the music and the very great help it has been to have him once again with us.

All the organizations of the Church are going along splendidly, the Church Boys' League have been busy at their meetings selling waste baskets, door stops and similar useful articles to raise money for their pledges, etc. This is a most interesting and delightful branch. The Junior and Girls' W.A. are particularly busy preparing and planning to have a tea and sale of work this coming week. Both these branches have a large attendance and are very active.

The Senior W.A. raised Talent Money during Lent and realized the sum of over fifty dollars. This branch attended Corporate Communion Service on Mother's Day, at which service the Lord Bishop of the Diocese gave a very fine address.

On St. George's Day, a special service was held in the morning at which the collection was sent to the Seaman's Institute of Greenwich, England. This custom has been observed in St. Paul's for many years.

The Cathedral held holy services on Sunday, April 28th, with gifts toward the Relief of Western Clergy.

Friends of St. Paul's will be pleased to learn that we have paid off all debt and have this year assumed more obligations than we have had for many years. We ask your prayers on behalf of the Church work and those who are responsible for administering the affairs of our Parish. There is a very worth while work to be done and we do hope you will remember us.

Whenever possible services have been taken the first Sunday in each month at Bear Creek.

Mention might be made of the various organizations which have attended services recently, the Masonic Lodge, the Oddfellows' Lodge and the Eagles. We are also members of the Curling Club. These services were very well attended indeed, and we were happy to welcome them to our church.

The Easter services were splendid, and well attended, and the Church was beautifully decorated by the Chancel Guild. It was again possible for us to have fresh cut flowers to adorn the Communion table. The eleven o'clock Holy Communion service was fully choral.

On Palm Sunday the Rector presented four candidates to the Bishop for the rite of Confirmation.

Through the columns of this paper, the clergy and members of St. Paul's Church extend to the Principal and staff of Chooutla School their prayerful thought for them, in the loss of the school by fire, recently.

WHITEHORSE — With this issue, the Rev. Alexander Anderson returns to the Diocese and takes over the dual responsibilities of the rectorship of Christ Church, and the editorship of this little paper. Mr. and Mrs. Anderson spent the winter in Ireland at the former's home, after their marriage in Vancouver last August. While there Mr. Anderson did six months' deputation work for the Colonial and Continental Church Society, telling something of the work not only on the Canadian prairie, but also of what our Church is doing in this northern land.

The new rector and his wife arrived in Whitehorse on May 6th. The
MOOSEHIDE—Easter services were attended splendidly, the church being filled for each service. As is usual the villagers had decorated the church in preparation for the festival. In the centre of the frontal was set an Easter banner worked in beads, the gift of one of the Indian women.

On Palm Sunday, April 2nd, the Bishop confirmed two children, and gave to the congregation an extremely helpful address.

FORT SELKIRK—St. Andrew's Mission—The congregation of St. Andrew's Church expresses its sorrow at the destruction of the Choontha Residential School at Carcross. About three-score children from Selkirk have had the advantages which the school so ably afforded and at the time of the fire there were four families represented at the institution. It was most gratifying to learn from the Principal, Rev. H. C. M. Grant, that the children were able to escape from the building and that no casualty had been found for them in Carcross.

Since the beginning of January the missionary has travelled all over his parish—a feat never before accomplished in less than a whole year—by air, land and sea. A trip by dog team was made to Carmacks and Mount Free Gold but the return journey was made by plane as a guest of the Hudson's Bay Company's Fur Commissioner, Mr. R. Parsons. Mayo, Stewart and Dawson were visited before the plane stopped at Selkirk. During Holy Week the missionary visited Whitehorse and held services on Good Friday and the two following Sundays.

Sickness has carried off several of the members of the Parish during the past five months. Unfortunately, the greater number have been children despite all the care and treatment which they were able to receive. The lack of meat for food was probably the deciding factor in each illness, particularly among the younger generation.

As members of the Diocese of Yukon we wish to welcome Rev. W. and Mrs. Valentine and Rev. A. and Mrs. Anderson back to the work in the Northland after their pleasant half days 'outside.'

BRIEFS

The Bishop visited Carcross soon after the fire at the Indian Residential School in April, and was also there in May for a confirmation, while en route to Ottawa to confer with the Department of Indian Affairs on Carcross School and other matters. While 'outside' the Bishop will attend the Rupert'sland Provincial Synod.

The Rev. W. Valentine is to represent Yukon Diocese at this Provincial Synod in June. Then he and Mrs. Valentine are expected to return to the Diocese. They spent the winter in England doing deputation work for the British Columbia and Yukon Church Aid Society.

Two students of the Anglican Theological College, Vancouver, have returned for summer mission work in the diocese. Mr. Joe M. Gillis to Champagne for the second time, and Mr. Frank M. Gilbert to Teslin for the third time. Teslin is an old established Church of England centre of work.
We have been there for over thirty years. The Roman Catholics are building a church at the present time. They have had a varying number of priests in at different times, sometimes three, during the last winter and spring in a proselytising effort. We desperately need funds to provide an all the year round ministry at this Indian settlement.

At the Convocation of Emmanuel College, Saskatoon, on May 3rd, the degree of Bachelor of Divinity was conferred on the Rev. Alex. Anderson, B.A., L.Th. Mr Anderson took his work extramurally while in charge of the Mooshide Mission.

New names appear on the list of workers on page 2. We bid adieu to those who have left, and welcome to the new ones.

MAYO.—The Indian congregation have finished off the interior of their church, St. Mark's, and have painted the ceiling. The interior was lined with Donacinda board, and the ceiling painted white, which has brightened it up a great deal.

The Junior W.A. of St. Mary's have presented the Church with Dee's Prayer Book, in Great Primer type. The former book is now on the Communion Table.

A Men's Discussion Group has been meeting once a week, at the Rectory, through the winter months. Topics of community, national and international interest have been discussed. Interest has been keen, partly at least, because the Group avoided idle debate, and concentrated on subjects that provided opportunities of accomplishing something.

A PHASE OF WORK IN THE DIOCESE OF YUKON

Those who read of the work of the Church in a far-off, lonely, cold place like the Yukon may often picture that the occasional ministrations of the Church are eagerly awaited by our more isolated brethren. This is not true in so many cases. Woodcutters and trappers off by themselves eight or nine months a year; lonely prospectors ever on the search for new finds; telegraph operators walking their lines to find a break; miners working a lone claim get away from the externals of religion. They only come into contact with the Church when they visit the regular settlements. Our Yukon clergy need the prayers of those more favourably situated as they try to break down this indifference, and send these people back to their lonely lives with religion's comforting and sustaining power.

Sir:

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have received your letter of the 13th instant #166-1-5, requesting information regarding new buildings at Carcross, and you will note from the enclosed telegram to Mr. Grant, that I am soliciting his assistance in securing the information desired. As it is likely that he will make a trip to Whitehorse to consult Mr. French, an expert carpenter who has always been engaged to undertake necessary repairs to the school buildings, a week or so may pass before I receive his reply. As soon as I hear from him I will write to you again, and endeavour to provide the information requested.

As you ask me to let you have my opinion with regard to providing living quarters for the Principal in the new building, I may say that in the p.s. to my letter to the Director on June 28th last I stated as follows: "It is assumed that (a) a semi-detached residence for the Principal will be provided in the new school building." This was the united opinion of Mr. Dixon, the Field Secretary of our Society, Bishop Gédés of the Yukon, and myself when we met here on June 13th last to consider matters relating to the building of a new School, and I do not see any reason to alter that opinion. The residence at present occupied by the Principal, and built with Church funds, is in a very poor state of repair. But, apart from this consideration, I have always felt that the policy of having the Principal located in close connection with the main school building was a sound one.
Regarding an estimate of the cost of the two buildings you suggest, I fear it will be difficult for us to calculate the same until we have plans and specifications of the buildings. While the Schools built by our Church at Port George, Aklavik, and Moose Factory were provided at a minimum of cost, the freighting charges on materials from outside were not so heavy as they are bound to be on the White Pass and Yukon Railway from Skagway to Carcross.

While I do not think there would be any difficulty whatever on the part of our Society in undertaking the construction of the two buildings, I will write to you again in this matter after I have received a reply from Mr. Principal Grant to the enclosed telegram. Any delay in the despatch of my next letter to you in this connection will be entirely due to circumstances over which I have no control.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

With further reference to your letter of May 27th last, #166-1-5, and the interview which Mr. Dixon, Field Secretary of our society, had with Dr. McGill on the previous day, I beg to state that Mr. Dixon requested me to send to Dr. McGill as soon as practicable

(1) A statement of what is immediately needed to enable the School to carry on its work in the present emergency quarters.

(2) A full statement of the requirements for a new building.

You will note from your letter of the 13th instant and my reply to the same on the 16th instant, that the subject matter of Paragraph 1 is receiving our careful attention. With regard to Paragraph 2, I beg to state that I have just received the following information from the Rev. Principal Grant.

"In connection with (2) it is noted from your letter to Dr. H.W. McGill, dated June 28th that the question of a new school, its site, type and capacity has already been decided on by the church authorities. There is no question but that the logical place for the school is in the southern Yukon. In addition to the fact that on the present site there is a well developed farm, a barn, two chicken houses, septic tank, Principal's residence, etc., the presence of which would..."
cut down considerably the cost of rebuilding, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that out of the 44 children in residence during the past academic year, 31 were recruited from the southern Yukon and northern B.C., 7 from central Yukon and only 6 from the north. In addition I may say that practically all applications for admission in recent years have been from parents who live in the vicinity of Carcross and Whitehorse.

In connection with (1) though, in addition to the equipment already provided at a cost of $652.31, some provision will have to be made before September 15th for a place in which to store garden produce so that it will be well protected from frost during the winter.

A few days ago Major Sandys Wunsch, R.C.M.P., Acting Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Yukon, passed through Carcross. As he did not stop off about all I could do was to draw his attention to this need. This consists of a building, erected on the foundation of the old Workshop. Before the fire the basement of this building was used for storing vegetables. Major Sandys Wunsch asked for plans, approximate cost, etc. Mr. J.E. French, Builder and Contractor, with whom I had previously discussed this need and who was travelling to Whitehorse on the same train as the Major was introduced and I asked him to give this official of the Department all particulars during this journey. Before the train pulled out Mr. French had the opportunity to inform me that the building needed would cost somewhere between $2,000.00 and $3,000.00. What the result of the conversation was on the train I do not know but Major Sandys Wunsch led me to believe, before he left, that he would try and rush the matter through. He was informed that we had to have some place by September 15th in which to store our vegetables.

The building needed will not only provide a storage place for garden produce but the upper part will give the Farm Instructor and General Assistant some place in which to keep tools, carry out repairs to farm equipment, etc. This is in itself a great need. At the present time repairs can be carried out in the open air but such a practice cannot be followed during the winter.

Before closing two other needs must be mentioned:-

(1) A typewriter for office use. You have already been advised of this need.

(2) A grant of $240.00 to help meet the cost of the services of a Night Watchman during the coming winter. A copy of a letter going forward today to the Superintendent of Indian Affairs, regarding this matter, is enclosed.

A copy of the letter mentioned in Paragraph 2 is enclosed herewith.
With regard to the three immediate needs listed in the above letter, namely, the place for storing the vegetables, a typewriter, and a Night Watchman, there can be no reasonable doubt whatever, and any help you may be able to give in providing the same will be greatly appreciated by our Commission and by our Society.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:-

Re Carcross School:-

With further reference to your letter of the 13th inst., No. 166-1-5, and my reply to the same on the 16th inst., I beg to state that I have just received the enclosed telegram from the Reverend Principal Grant in reply to one I sent to him on the 17th inst. I trust that the information embodied in this telegram along with that set forth in my letter to you on the 21st inst. may serve as a helpful guide to you in fixing the amount required to provide the two essential buildings mentioned in your letter of the 13th inst.

You will note that logs are available for both buildings and that the cost of log construction instead of lumber would effect a saving of $2,500.00.

With regard to Reverend Principal Grant's estimate of the cost of six separate log buildings without concrete basements, and the estimated saving of approximately $14,000.00, I would refer you to the paragraph on Page 2 of my letter to Dr. McGill on June 28th last, where I set forth the unanimous opinion of Bishop Geddes of the Yukon, Rev. L.A. Dixon, Field Secretary of our Society, and myself, that "the adoption of the cottage system would require one separate building for the bigger girls and one for the smaller girls, one for the bigger boys and
one for the smaller boys, a kitchen and refectory combined, a classroom, two separate recreation rooms, a residence for the Principal, a chapel, a laundry and bakery combined, a workshop and tool-shop combined, toilets, etc." My opinion in this matter has not changed and I am convinced that if an attempt were made to get along with six buildings, most, if not all, of the others, would have to be provided at a later date, and that in the end no saving would be effected.

Should you decide to build the dormitories of logs may I suggest that consideration be given to the possibility of building the classrooms in the same way, not merely because of the estimated saving of $500.00, but also to maintain some uniformity of design.

I shall be glad to secure any further information you may require in connection with the buildings in question on receipt of your request.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Dear Sir:

This is an answer to your letter of July 28th, 1939.

1. In your letter you state that you have been wondering where we expect to secure building logs in view of the fact that it has been increasingly difficult to secure wood fuel in the vicinity of the school. In the past we have confined our search for firewood within a radius of approximately six miles from the school. Hauling wood this distance with horses was found by experience to be no easy matter. It was hard on the horses, hard on the Farm Instructor and boys and in the short winter days not much could be accomplished. In view of this situation you will recall that a request was made to the Department for a caterpillar tractor. With this item of equipment larger loads of wood could be hauled in much less time and from greater distances. To haul wood with horses a greater distance than six miles from the school seems to be impractical. This spring I discovered an excellent stand of timber about 10 or 12 miles from the school. When the question of building the new school out of logs arose, I took two men out to see what had been discovered. One was Mr. J.E. French and the other Mr. Wm. Chanteler. Both these men are builders and contractors, the latter being a man who has had considerable experience in constructing log buildings. They were quite enthusiastic with what they saw. Mr. French remarked that in his opinion enough logs could be obtained from that site to build more than one school. Mr. Chanteler remarked that he thought at least 500,000 feet of lumber could be cut there. I understood from what was said that should the decision be made to build the school of logs and should Mr. French or Mr. Chanteler be awarded the contract and they worked together on the project, a small portable saw mill would be set up on this site. With this mill the logs would be squared on three sides and hauled to Carcross by means of a caterpillar tractor. There is quite a good road to this stand of timber. In your letter you refer to the possibility
of rafting the building logs to the old site. This would not be possible as the logs are far removed from navigable water. The only way in which they could be transported to the old school site is by road.

A week or so ago I was introduced to Mr. Rogers, the Vice President and General Manager of the White Pass and Yukon Route. As you know the officials of the W.P. & Y.R. have been wonderful in the help they gave us after the fire. As a matter of fact the range now used in the Kitchen is the property of the company. Apparently Mr. Rogers visited the officials of the Department in Ottawa in order to ascertain if there was anything else they could do to help us out. In the course of conversation the question of a fire-proof building arose and Mr. Rogers told the officials of the Department that there was no such thing. He pointed out, though, that in his opinion the best fire retarding building that could be erected was one made of logs. In a building of this nature, which is cheaper to build than one made out of brick, stone, or concrete, if a fire broke out, the fire fighters would not have to contend with fire inside the walls, which, as you know, is a very difficult thing to extinguish.

2. In the closing paragraph of your letter you mention the use of stone for the walls and partitions of the new buildings. This matter was thoroughly discussed with Mr. French and I cannot do better than to quote what he said:

"There is no regular building stone in the country. Practically all the country stone is limestone which is entirely unsuitable for building purposes."

3. The request for a plan of the two buildings which you state the Government has apparently decided to put up is being given my attention. This will be mailed to you as soon as possible.

Yours respectfully,

(sgd) H.C.M. Grant.

Sir,

Re:- The CHOULTA Indian Residential School-CARCROSS Y.T.

Whilst in Carcross, Y.T., during my return from the inspection of the North End of this Agency, on the 30th of July the Rev. H.C.M. Grant, Principal of the above school was called upon and the Stikine Agency youngsters therein, were seen.

This is the first time a visit has been paid to that point since the old School Building was burnt down, but all the youngsters were about, receiving their schooling, and all in very good shape.

Mr Grant took up the matter of a new building being allowed them, which is sadly wanted as many more in number of children could be sent to that location if such is rebuilt in the future.

He mentioned the fact that it had been suggested that if the school is rebuilt it should be constructed in "community" style. That is to say that several buildings, for their various purposes should be constructed - and not one huge School Building as the old building was.

May I be allowed to add my voice to his for consideration of such a building scheme, without any doubt whatsoever it would be of great benefit to the Indian youngsters in after life. In the building of such school houses the youngsters could find employment and learn a lesson in construction, for their own future use. Also it is found that when these nomadic children leave these huge, and modern, school buildings; and resume normal conditions in the "bush" they are more or less like a fish out of water, and most of them break down, and do nothing for some years after. The extra cost of heating, if any, can be offset against the improvement in health that would come about by using several small buildings instead of one huge affair which in the winter time is filled with compressed foul hot Air.

The Department will no doubt know already the many advantages to be derived from community settlement buildings in the north country, and I can only state that such a scheme used in the construction of the new Chooulta School Buildings at Carcross in the Yukon Territory, would be a great movement towards having the children more fitted to leave school, when their time is up, and resume normal conditions in the bush, than would be, a real up-to-date - fully furnished modern school building, which represents too high a grade for these nomadic children to achieve during their lifetime.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

It was fortunate that Mr. J.B. French, an expert builder and contractor was in Carcross when your letter of the 1st instant was received. He and I discussed thoroughly the points about which information is required, etc., and beg to report as follows:

1. The suggestion that the proposed new school be lined with asbestos or fire-proof board is an excellent one. Mr. French mentioned Gypsum Board which costs $125.00 per M. if purchased in the Yukon. If purchased in Vancouver in any great quantity it would likely be slightly cheaper than the price quoted. Mr. French pointed out that whilst Gypsum Board is fire-proof there may be other boards on the market equally as good. At the present time he is constructing a Government Radio Station in Whitehorse and Gypsum Board is the lining called for in the revised specifications.

2. We can see no object in having the dormitories downstairs especially if the proposed building was built of logs with adequate fire escapes, lined with Gypsum Board and had the heating plant located in a separate building. As a matter of fact having the dormitories downstairs would make, as you state in your letter a very long building. This would be very difficult to heat in the cold weather.

3. Having the heating plant in a separate building is an excellent suggestion but under no circumstances should it be located to the West of the main school building. At least 95% of the wind in Carcross is from the West, South-west or North-west. When the ground plans are being prepared this aspect of the matter should not be overlooked. In the fire of April 17th 1939 if the Workshop had been located West of the old main School building at the same distance or even closer to the school than it was it would not have been destroyed by fire. As a matter of fact a telephone pole
located about two feet from the west end of the old school building still stands. One of the interesting points arising out of the fire shows how careful one should be in ascertaining the direction of prevailing winds before deciding where to place the outbuildings of importance. Having discussed very thoroughly the danger from fire Mr. French and myself would like to suggest that, as a further safeguard the Diesel lighting Plant, Storage Batteries and especially the engine used to operate the water pump be placed in the same building as the Heating Plant.

4. If the heating and lighting plant etc. were installed in a separate building the only chimney that would be required in the Main School would be one for the Kitchen Range. Mr. French and I recommend that this be what is known as a Yukon Chimney. Mr. French stated that brick chimneys have proved to be the greatest fire hazard in the Yukon, adding that in the many years he has lived in Whitehorse practically all the fires have originated from this cause. There is no question but that the fire of April 17th last, which destroyed the old school was caused by a faulty brick chimney. It is Mr. French's opinion that the amount of creosote coming from the wood fuel eats holes in the mortar and I may add that this is also the opinion of others. As in most buildings the brick chimney is encased with woodwork it is practically impossible to inspect it from time to time or carry out any necessary repairs without tearing down a great part of the building. Another great drawback in this country to a brick chimney is the difficulty of getting a good foundation for same. The presence of frost in the ground all the year round causes buildings to heave and such heaving and settling causes chimneys to crack whether they are made of concrete or brick. In his experience Mr. French has known brick chimneys to settle so much that the part above the roof has become detached from the part below and toppled over. I am certain that the fire of April 17th last was caused by the brick chimney in the old school developing a crack where it went through the roof.

5. In closing may I say that Mr. French asked me to mention that as building logs are not kept in stock like lumber they should be cut this fall or next spring, that is if the school is to be constructed and logs and the building program completed by next fall. These cannot be cut during the winter months owing to the depth of snow, short days, and sub-zero temperatures. He added that if the building is to be completed by next fall and nothing can be done this fall, men should be in the woods cutting the logs required not later than April 1st 1940.

The plans you refer to in your letter are in the course of preparation and will be forwarded as soon as possible. Mr. French and I have spent some hours on these and an effort is being made to submit something that will be feasible from a constructional point of view. They will only be of rough nature but will give yourself and the Department some idea of the location of the rooms in the building, etc.
Trusting that the information given and the opinions expressed in the letter will prove to be of use to yourself and the Department,

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

(Sgd) H.C.M. Grant.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

Re: New Carcross School

You may recall that when I spoke to you in Ottawa on the 4th inst. (in Mr. Hoey's office) about the prospects of having the new school built at Carcross next year, to take the place of the one destroyed by fire last April, you informed me that a definite decision in the matter might be reached not later than December next when a draft of the Estimates for the Fiscal Year 1940-41 would probably be completed. It is my recollection that I promised to write to you in the matter, and advise you of the possibility of reaching a decision at the earliest date possible in order that arrangements might be made for cutting the logs out of which the new school building and detached classroom are to be constructed.

I have examined, and am forwarding to the Superintendent of Welfare and Training a rough draft of the plan suggested by the Principal of our Carcross School for the new building, and am writing now for the specific purpose of asking that authority be given to cut during the coming winter, and before the sap begins to ascend in the spring, all the logs required for construction purposes. From information received from the Principal an abundance of logs can be secured at a distance of about 10 miles from the school. Local contractors have examined the same, and have expressed their conviction that all the log material required can be secured from this one location. As the logs should be seasoned as well as possible before actual construction begins, it is important that they be cut in the early future, and it will be duly appreciated if you will give the matter the earliest attention possible, and issue the necessary authority for the cutting of the logs to be undertaken.

I am sending you herewith a number of photos which show the buildings in which the work of the school is being carried on at present. After the main school building was burned the buildings in the pictures, some of which belong to our Church, some to the White Pass and Yukon Railway, and some to local residents of the village of Carcross, were placed at the disposal of the school management, and occupied only 24 hours after that tragic event. While the principal of the School and his staff did to be commended for the prompt and vigorous way in which they faced the critical situation, it is obvious that they should not be expected to carry on their work under existing conditions any longer than can possibly be helped. I would therefore most earnestly request that a very special effort be made to have the new school provided next year, and that authority be given at the earliest date.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In keeping with the promise made to you during our conversation here yesterday, I am sending you under separate cover the plan for the proposed new school building at Carcross, as prepared by the Rev. Principal Grant.

The attached letter came with the plan and I am forwarding to Mr. Grant today a copy of the plan and with it the suggestions for improvements in the same on which we agreed yesterday.

It is my understanding that a two-room classroom will be erected as a separate building with a furnace and accommodation for vocational training in a full sized basement underneath, the basement to have an outside entrance.

It is also my understanding that the heating and lighting plant for the main school building will either be fully or semi-detached from that building.

You will note that the plan submitted by the Principal provides accommodation for himself and family at one end of the main school building on the main and second floors. I have always felt that the semi-detached plan for the Principal's accommodation was the best one and would recommend if at all possible that it be adopted in this case. On Mr. Grant's plan, no provision is made...
for a bathroom on the main floor and this could be installed if the Principal's quarters were semi-detached.

The lack of any indication of the location of the chimney is due to the fact that the heating plant is to be located in either a detached or semi-detached building. This will necessitate so far as I know, the installation of either a hot water or steam heating system.

I trust that the plan, which the Principal has undoubtedly taken great pains to prepare, may be sufficiently complete to enable your architect to proceed with the design and specifications to be followed. Should he require any further information we will gladly endeavour to provide it with as little delay as possible.

In connection with the enclosed copies of communications which are going forward to the Minister of Mines & Resources today, I would direct your special attention to the suggestion made in the closing part of Mr. Grant's telegram that the Principal's residence be semi-detached from the main school building.

I earnestly hope that the Principal's request for an immediate advance of $1,500.00 be authorized, so that the cutting of the logs may be taken in hand at once. I also earnestly hope that the items of equipment mentioned (one tractor, four sleighs, one wagon) may also be provided so that the logs can be hauled to the school site during the winter.

I suggested to the Principal that if the logs were dressed at the school, the slabs would furnish a good deal of the wood fuel required from year to year.
As the School management should not be expected to carry on their work under prevailing conditions beyond next summer, I trust it may be possible for action to be taken in the immediate future along the lines suggested in the Rev. Principal Grant's telegram.
