Dear Sir:-

Shortly after the fire which destroyed the Main School Building and Workshop on April 17th last you visited Carcross and gave authority to rent three buildings from Mr. Matthew Watson @ $25.00 per month. It was felt then that these three buildings and the Church of England Rectory would provide sufficient space for the staff, pupils, etc.

1. The Rectory is used as a Girl's Residence and Playroom. Two bedrooms in this building provide accommodation for two lady staff members.

2. One of Mr. Watson's houses is used as a Classroom.

3. Another of Mr. Watson's buildings houses the boys. In this building there is only one bedroom and that is used by Miss J. Wright the Boy's Supervisor.

4. The third building, owned by Mr. Matthew Watson, is used as a Kitchen, Children's Dining Room, Staff Dining Room and sleeping quarters for two male staff agents who have to share a room. The other bedroom is occupied by Miss E. Hewer, Kitchen Matron.
As you can understand it took some time to reorganize things after the fire and then it was found that more buildings were needed. The particulars of these needs are as follows:

1. Store House for food supplies, etc. For a month after the fire these were stored in an old Chicken House and part of the barn on the old school site. Apart from the inconvenience in having our food supplies stored in two buildings approximately two miles from our Kitchen and Dining Room, the unsanitary conditions arising from using a Chicken House and Barn as a store place for food, made it necessary to find another building for a Store House. Consequently arrangements were made with Mr. W.L. Phelps, K.C. of Whitehorse to rent one of his buildings as from May 17th 1939 at a rental of $5.00 per month. It might be mentioned that we have only two shipments of food supplies come in in a year and as a result considerable storage space is needed.

2. Staff Residence. At the time of the fire there were seven members on the staff. It was found necessary in the process of reorganization to increase the staff by one. In order to have accommodation for this extra worker, have some place where the staff could congregate when off duty (this place being known as the Staff Sitting Room) and provide some room where the School Nurse could attend to sick Indians and school children, it was found necessary to rent another building from Mr. Matthew Watson. This was taken possession of on August 1st 1939 at a rental of $25.00 per month. In this building there are three rooms (1) The Living Room is used as the Staff Sitting Room (2) the bedroom as quarters for the school nurse (3) the Kitchen in which the nurse carries out her professional duties.

3. Principal's Residence and Office. From the time of the fire until September 1st 1939 the Principal tried to fulfill
his duties and still live in his residence on the old school site. He used an out-building near his residence as an office. It was found well nigh impossible to keep in touch with what was going on and maintain discipline with these quarters approximately two miles from the school. Moving over to town and occupying this present building, with only one bedroom, has made it very difficult for Mrs. Grant and myself. Two of the boys sleep in part of my office, two girls in the Kitchen and two children in our own bedroom. It was a question though, in renting a building for the Principal's Residence and Office, not of our own comfort but the welfare of the school.

4. Laundry. Several months after the fire it was possible to dry the washing outside. When winter came it was an impossibility. The two Supervisors were, from the start of the winter up to December 14th 1939, trying to dry clothing for 45 children by hanging the various garments around the residences. Apart from this inconvenience, the nurse pointed out to me how risky it was from a health point of view for the children having wet clothing hanging on and around their bunks. The only solution to this problem was to rent from Mr. Ross Peebler of Atlin, B.C. a house he owned here for which he charges a rental of $15.00 per month.

I must apologize for not reporting on these matters sooner but felt that it was better to find out for sure exactly what buildings were needed before writing about same. Even though we are still handicapped in not having a Playroom for the Indian boys and being crowded somewhat in the quarters used by the writer and his family I feel that we can carry on with what facilities we are now using until a new school etc. is constructed.

Feeling sure that the Department you represent
realizes the difficulty under which we are trying to carry on the work here and will sanction the necessary expenditure to cover the rental cost of the extra buildings,

I remain,

Yours truly,

H.C.M. Grant, Principal.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

Re: Construction Carcross Indian Residential School.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 29th ult., dealing with the important matter indicated above, and to state that when I presented it to our Commission at a meeting held on the 7th inst., under the Chairmanship of the Archbishop of Rupert's Land (Rev. L.A. Dixon, General Secretary of our Society, was also present) the members instructed me to let you know that they were deeply conscious of the many difficulties which the circumstances of war and the dissolution of our Dominion Parliament have created for you and the various departments of government. They desired me to assure you that they would faithfully endeavour not to add to these difficulties, and I have much pleasure in conveying this assurance to you.

In view of the fact, mentioned in your letter, that no provision was made in the departmental estimates for 1939-40 for the building of the school in question, and in view of the urgent need of this building, I was instructed to say that our Commission would purchase immediately the caterpillar tractor, sleighs and wagon required for hauling out the logs, and pay the Indians for cutting the same, provided you could give an assurance that the total amount thus expended would be refunded to the Commission at an early date after the estimates for the fiscal year 1940-41 had been passed by Parliament.
The total sum required immediately, as stated in my letter to you on Nov. 13th last, is $4,845.20, and is made up as follows:

- Tractor f.o.b. Carcross ....... $2,495.20
- 4 sleighs ....................... 600.00
- 1 wagon ......................... 250.00
- Wages for cutting, etc........... 1,500.00

$ 4,845.20

You will understand that if the logs are to be brought out this winter, action must be taken immediately. As I gathered from recent letters received from the Principal that the rental charges for the buildings now being used for school purposes will total approximately $1700.00 per year, it would seem to be a good policy to take the earliest steps possible to eliminate the necessity of meeting so heavy an annually recurring expenditure.

I commend the Commission's offer to your careful and sympathetic consideration, and beg to remain,

Yours very truly,

Secretary of the Commission.

Reverend Sir:

This Branch is in receipt of a letter from Mr. T. V. Sandys-Wunsch, agent for Indian affairs in the Yukon Territory, which reads in part as follows:

"On 2-5-39 you approved my action in renting temporary accommodation at Carcross as under -

3 houses @ $25.00 each per month - $75.00

and later approved repairs to another house and roofing of a store-room.

"On 18-1-40 I received the attached letter and accounts from the Reverend H.C.M. Grant, Principal of the Carcross school, from which it appears that he has raised in addition to the above, two houses at $25.00 each per month - $50.00

one store-house at $5.00 per month - 5.00

one laundry at $15.00 per month - 15.00

Total - $70.00

"The Principal had no authority from me for this action but I attach his letter of explanation. I cannot see how I can recommend the payment of accounts of this nature".

It is scarcely necessary to state that I was disturbed to learn of this additional commitment at Carcross. No provision was made in the 1939-40 estimates for the payment of rental charges at Carcross, nor has any provision been made for such rental charges in the 1940-41 estimates, prepared and sent forward to the Treasury a few weeks ago.

In view of the extraordinary conditions now confronting us, instructions have been issued that the estimates in this branch and in a number of departments of the Government cannot exceed the estimates of last year. This means the abandonment of some equally worthy service if the rent at Carcross is to be paid. We do not extend to our Indian agents or inspectors in any section of Canada the right to commit the Government to expenditure without first securing regular authorization from the head Office and you can readily appreciate how difficult it would be to administer our 80 residential schools if principals had the right even in exceptional circumstances to commit the Department to expenditures without first submitting the proposed expenditures to the officials here.

I am not at all disputing the need for the expenditure -

Reverend H. C. M. Grant,
Carcross Indian Residential School,
Carcross, Yukon.
expenditure at Carcross. A full and complete explanation is contained in your letter to the Indian agent. However, I feel sure the Treasury officials will challenge our right to make these payments until the need for the payments is carefully reviewed and approved.

The annual rental at Carcross now amounts to approximately $1,700, or a sum almost equal to the interest charge on capital outlay of $80,000. This appears to be a rather high rental charge for the accommodation and instruction of 40 pupils. I am, however, wholly unfamiliar with local conditions and consequently somewhat helpless in any attempt I might make to render advice. If the buildings are sufficiently close to a reserve or if buildings close to a reserve could be secured, attendance of day pupils might be encouraged. If it is impossible to secure the funds necessary to construct a school at any time in the immediate future, would it be wise to proceed with the construction of the two classrooms, if money were available for such construction? You might make a careful survey of the conditions at Carcross and let me have any comments you may care to send forward.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:-

Re 166-1-5.

One of the things I would like to do in replying to your letter of March 19th 1940 is to apologize to yourself, as I did to the Indian Agent, for not obtaining authority from the Department before renting the three additional buildings mentioned in your letter. It was felt though, that in view of the exceptional circumstances which had arisen and the need of these buildings I was justified in acting as I did. I will, however, in future, be very careful to secure regular authorization before incurring any expenditure in the name of the Department.

In the closing paragraph of your letter you mention the 'high rental charge'. In an effort to have this reduced I spoke to Mr. Matthew Watson, the owner of five of the buildings which have been rented and he, realizing the value of the work being done here stated as follows:-
"If the Department will pay the rental on three of my houses the school can have the use of the other two without charge until a new school is erected or the Department are in the position to pay for rental of same."

In your letter you state as follows: "If the buildings are sufficiently close to a reserve or if buildings close to a reserve could be secured, attendance of day pupils might be encouraged." In this connection I may say that the buildings we are using are situated quite close to the Carcross Indian Village but only 9 out of the 44 children in residence have their homes in this village. Having these 9 as day pupils would not help a great deal. The other 35 pupils come from many points a long distance from here. For example, I may say, that the parents of two of our girls are at present residing in Fort Macpherson, N.W.T.

With regard to the construction of two classrooms near our present quarters I do not think this would be a wise policy. When the new school is erected these would be of no use to us at all. It is understood that the old school site is to be the location for a new school. This site is approximately two miles from Carcross Village. Such a journey for the teacher and children to make, especially during the winter months and in the mosquito season would be very arduous. Then having the classrooms so far from our present quarters would destroy the attempt that has been made to centralize our work as much as possible.

Trusting that the information given in this letter will prove to be of help to yourself and the Department you represent,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

H.C.M. Grant,
Principal.

H.C.M. Grant, Principal.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Carcross Indian Residential School

At the time the above-mentioned school was destroyed by fire, April 17, 1939, the R. C. M. P. Constable proceeded immediately to the school and authorized the purchase of the articles shown on the attached account in order that the school might continue in operation in temporary buildings that were available.

When the account was forwarded to us last fall it was returned as it was not properly prepared for consideration. It has recently been sent back to us.

While no specific authority was given by this Branch for the purchase of the articles shown on the attached account I feel that the Acting Indian Agent acted in good faith in authorizing immediate local purchase as the equipment was necessary and the articles are those that are usually supplied.

The Carcross School is operated under the auspices of the Church of England and I should appreciate it if the Minister would approve payment of this account funds for which are available in the current year's appropriation.

Director.

Ottawa, December 13, 1940.

Re: Carcross Residential School

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 10th instant, in which you seek information with respect to the rebuilding of the Carcross Residential School and to any provision that may have been made in the 1941-42 estimates for the construction of this building.

I regret to state that we found it impossible to make provision in next year's estimates for the construction of Indian day or Indian residential schools anywhere in the Dominion. A few months ago the Bishop for the Yukon discussed this matter with me, personally, and it is my understanding that he later visited the office of the Minister and discussed the project with the officials there.

It is scarcely necessary to add that should conditions change at any time in the immediate future, the building of the Carcross School and one or two other schools recently destroyed by fire would have the first claim on the funds that might be available.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Sir:

It would be appreciated if you would ask the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, to supply our school, during the present fiscal year, with the following item of equipment:

1 - Only, No. D8 Diesel Caterpillar Tractor - 50" gauge Model.
Top Seat;
13" Heat Treated Semi-Skeleton Shoes;
Snow Sprickets;
Front Pull Hook;
Front Bumper;
Hood Doors;
Electric Lighting System - F.O.B. Carcross $2,495.20

The Northern Commercial Company, Whitehorse, Yukon, which quoted the aforementioned price, has assured the writer that this caterpillar is particularly suitable for operation in northern climates.

Since my appointment to this school in 1930 approximately 2,500 cords of wood have been cut in the vicinity of the school. This means that each year we have to go further afield in order to obtain the 250 cords of wood required each year. The trouble with which we are faced now is not getting the wood cut but getting it hauled. Last winter our teams had to haul wood a distance of 7 miles over bad mountainous trails and the most that could be hauled in one load was approximately one cord and a half. As the years go by the length of haul becomes greater and the time has arrived when it is practically impossible for the wood hauling to be done by horses.

In the past we have more or less avoided cutting wood along the shores of the lakes in the vicinity of Carcross. In the first place hauling wood here with a team of horses any distance over a lake in winter is a hard and cold undertaking not only for the horses but also for the teamster and his helpers. We tried it one year with the result that the horses played out and it was all the teamsters could do to face the cold and biting winds. In the second place we have avoided cutting wood out on the lake shores because of the short time in which the ice is really safe. Some years there are only three months in the winter in which hauling on the ice can be safely undertaken. Making allowance for the number of days when the inclemency of the weather makes it
impossible to send teams out on the lake, it is easily seen that a team hauling a cord and a half per trip per half day cannot get all the wood hauled before the break-up.

The wood situation here now may be summarized as follows:

(a) All areas with six or seven miles from the school from which wood can be hauled along roads sheltered from the wind, have been cut out. Wood can be obtained by going further inland but this would mean too long a haul for horses especially on short days during the winter months.

(b) There is practically an unlimited supply along the lake shores which for reasons given cannot be hauled by a team.

(c) With a Caterpillar tractor it would be possible to haul on the lake, wood from a distance of ten or twelve miles from the school and get it hauled in a comparatively short time. This method of hauling has been put to the test. On one occasion we were allowed the use of a caterpillar tractor, the property of the Northern Airways, Limited. In one half day ten cords were hauled on the lake ice in one trip from a place about four miles from the school.

Would you please inform the Department that this is a pressing need and recommend that authority be given for this purchase to be made before the winter of 1941-1942 sets in.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) H.C.M. Grant

Principal.
On the 11th instant, while in Carcross on matters pertaining to the Yukon Administration, I inspected the Indian Residential School and Barn, and was able in this way to become familiar with conditions that the Reverend Grant, Superintendent of the School, has to contend with in the management and supervision of this institution.

The Reverend Grant made representations respecting the usefulness that a small type caterpillar tractor would be, particularly in securing yearly supplies of wood for the school.

A considerable quantity of wood is used yearly, and I find that this has to be secured now at a considerable distance from the school. A small type tractor would be a very useful item of equipment.

I asked the Reverend Grant to write me a report respecting the type of caterpillar required, and to furnish an estimate re cost landed, and when making his report to explain the situation in detail for the information of the Department. I enclose a copy of his letter, and I would recommend that favourable consideration be given to his request to be supplied with this equipment.

Sir,

Your File 165-1-5

I refer to your letter of April 7th last, having reference to the renewal of Leases of buildings rented for the Indian Residential School, Carcross, Yukon Territory.

On the 11th instant I was in Carcross on business in connection with Yukon Administration and took the opportunity while there of inspecting the buildings rented in connection with the Residential School and in connection with these I would like to report as follows:

The one building rented from Mr. W.L. Phelps is a small building and appears to be used for storage and supplies for miscellaneous purposes.

One Building is rented from Ross R. Peebler. This building appears to be in good condition and is satisfactory.

The former lease represented that three buildings were rented from Matthew Watson at a cost of $75.00 monthly. I find as a matter of fact that five buildings are being supplied by Matthew Watson. The rental of $75.00 per month is satisfactory for five buildings, provided two of these buildings be improved immediately at the close of the school term. The building used for class room purposes I find to be a log building; the interior unfinished. The teacher reported to me that the building was cold in the winter time, and it did not present a bright and attractive appearance for a class room for children.

One other building rented from Matthew Watson is used as a barn. It is said I find it also to be badly in need of repair, the walls being covered with old torn paper and in such condition that they could not be kept clean. I interviewed the owner of these two buildings, Matthew Watson, and insisted that both buildings be lined with insulating board, walls and ceiling, and this he has agreed to do.

Leases have been prepared by Reverend Grant, and I enclose one copy for the Department of each lease completed by the Reverend Grant. I spoke to Reverend Grant respecting the Matthew Watson Lease, since it only mentioned three buildings, and five buildings were being supplied, and he stated the facts respecting this were known to the former Indian Agent.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt of Welfare and Training,

Dear Mr. Warren:

Thank you very much for all the trouble you went to in finding out from my parents about "the natural state of the beast", and also for your advice in the matter.

It seems that every time that I write to you, it is always to ask a favour. This time I am asking you a favour which, I suppose, will be like the last one, of no benefit to us. It is about the purchase of a caterpillar-tractor for this school by the Government; a machine, may I say, that is of a great necessity here in our Indian Residential School at Carcross.

At the present time, some of our pupils, who were out on holiday, have not returned, owing to the fact that during the summer vacation they have told their parents about our wood-haul. I know myself that it is very dangerous, much too dangerous a haul to ask any boy in this school to be responsible for handling a team of horses in such a place. You know yourself of my experience in the logging-camps of Ontario, and that I would not make such a statement to anyone if it were not so. In the past, we have tried to persuade the Government to supply this school with a tractor; but apparently they think it would be a luxury! If any of the Members think it a luxury to provide a tractor for this northern school, I would advise them to put on a pair of overalls and gloves and come up here for a year or two, then they might realize that such a machine is not a luxury but an absolute necessity. This is the reason why the parents do not want to send the pupils back to school, thinking it too dangerous a job.

The haul that I speak of is of around four miles. I should say that two miles and a half of this is done the side of a mountain. The equipment that we have here now is of little use to us in such a haul. We have to depend upon rough-logs or chains on the runners, not very substantial when you are coming down the side of a mountain lickety-split and happen to hit a stone. The result is that away goes Mr. Rough-log and sends you to the bottom a whole lot faster than you would otherwise expect. The road, as you could imagine, on the side of a mountain, is not very straight, and unless you are an expert horseman you don't make the first turn you come to. Instead, you hit for the best opening that Mother Nature has provided in the woods. Sometimes these openings are feet and feet between. The first thing you know, you are piled up in the bush, which I don't think is a very safe thing for any boy of thirteen or fourteen years of age. If he does happen to make the turn,
the next calamity I suppose would be the load upsetting. Our wood being cut in four-foot lengths and piled on the sleigh over four feet high is a very tottlesish thing rounding the curve at such a pace. The Government is trying to cut down expenses as much as possible and are wondering why some of our boys have to spend quite a period of time in the hospital at Whitehorse, forty-four miles away. This is the reason why I say that a tractor is much more a necessity than a luxury for a good many times if a boy is hurt in the winter a plane has to be chartered to take the boy to the hospital for the simple reason that trains are few and far between.

Another expense that I believe the Government has to deal with is the equipment. You know yourself that in a haul of this kind that horse-equipment is far too light, resulting in new equipment being bought every few years. With a caterpillar-tractor and proper tracked sleighs, the outlay would amount to a good deal I know on the stock basis as you can see for yourself from my description of the haul, it would be much cheaper in the end. With the freight rates being so high here, I would say, in a few years' time the equipment needed for horses would pay for a tractor.

Not only would a tractor help in the wood-haul, but if this school is ever re-built and a log-building erected, there is suitable timber in this country not too far away, so that a person could get at it with a tractor. This, in my mind, would be much cheaper to do than to build a frame-building, the lumber for which in the Yukon would run to about ninety dollars per thousand. I am not looking out for comforts for myself or for the school, but trying to point out the savings that this machine would render in the years to come.

With mining opening up in Atlin, it means that a lot of heavy mining equipment is being brought in during the winter, which is of course the most suitable season for its transport over the ice. Therefore tractors are the only logical method for its transport. Here is where the school may be able to get the odd trip which would help to supply the money for the tractor's up-keep. I would say that about a three-ton Diesel tractor would be the proper size for our purpose.

If this is going to go through at all I would appreciate it very much if you would let me know as soon as possible.

Trusting that this is not too much trouble and that it will meet with some approval, I remain,

Sincerely yours,

Ross Kilbey.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

I am going to enclose a letter which I have received from Ross Kilby, formerly of Golden Lake, but now of Carcross, Yukon.

I know this fellow very well, as he had been pestering me at the beginning of the war to help him get into the Navy or Air Force. Two years ago he signed a five-year contract to manage this farm in connection with an Indian Residential School. Recently I had a letter from him, again pleading for assistance to get into the Navy.

I visited this boy's parents and found that there would be no chance whatever of his being accepted in either services, so advised him to stick on the job where he is, rather than pay his own way out, as there would be practically no chance at all of his qualifying physically. I might add that Kilby's two sisters are both in Indian Residential Schools, one at Sioux Lookout and the other one at some more distant point.

He is a fine young man and I do not think would ask for anything that would not be beneficial in the work he is doing.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Warren:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 7 and also communication received by you from Mr. Ross Kilby, of the Carcross Indian Residential School, enclosed therewith.

The Carcross Residential School is operated by the Anglican Church, in co-operation with this Department. The school building itself was destroyed by fire about two years ago, and I regret that the funds at our disposal have not enabled us to erect a new building. However, a residence, suitable for classroom work, and a limited amount of dormitory accommodation was secured immediately following the fire. The school has at this date an authorized enrolment of 40 pupils and a per capita grant of $50 per annum is allowed by this Department.

It has not been the policy of the Department at any time to provide tractors at Indian residential schools. A large majority of the schools use horses for their farm work and for the hauling of their fuel supply. The use of horses provides valuable training for the senior pupils. Few tractors are used by Indians on the reserves, and the purchase of a Caterpillar Diesel tractor, in a critical period such as this, could scarcely be justified for a school with an enrolment of 40 pupils.

When money is available for the construction of a new school at Carcross, consideration will—

R. M. Warren, Esq., M. P.,
House of Commons,
OTTAWA.
will be given to the desirability of securing a site near to an adequate wood supply.

I should add that Dr. Westgate, Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, visited the Department a few weeks ago, and at that time the needs of the Indian residential schools operated by the Anglican Church were very carefully reviewed by the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch. Dr. Westgate did not however request a tractor for the Carcross School. He was no doubt of the opinion at that time that there were other supplies more urgently needed at a number of the schools operated by his Commission.

MONTHLY REPORT
Stikine Indian Agency - January 1942.

CHOOUTLA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, Carcross, Y.T.

Although this school does not come under the jurisdiction of this Agency there a few pupils from this Agency attending and as the return trip from Atlin was made via Carcross the school was visited while there. The principal was interviewed and the buildings, seven in all, being used until a new school can be constructed, were inspected. The danger from fire in these old buildings is always present and very little fire-fighting equipment was in evidence. Water has to be carried by bucket from a river about 75 yards distant. However, the buildings could be quickly evacuated in case of fire as they are all one story and the windows are close to the ground. Some of the buildings were not particularly clean but considering the circumstances under which the school operates it is probably as clean as could be expected. The attendance was 33 and the children's health good. School work seems satisfactory.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Even though I should have dispensed with the services of our Night Watchman on March 31st 1942 it has been necessary to keep him on and one should be filling that position as long as there are United States' Troops stationed here.

On three occasions soldiers, coloured and white, have attempted to gain entry into the Girls' Residence. It was only the vigilance of our Night Watchman which prevented a possible serious crime from being committed. One episode took place a few nights ago. Mrs. Davis awoke from sleep about 1.30 a.m. and saw a negro attempting to get into her room through the window. He had removed the wire screen, raised the sash and lit a candle. It was the light which awakened Mrs. Davis. She immediately called out and the negro disappeared. It seems likely that this negro and possibly others who were in hiding near the Girls' Residence were watching the movements of the Night Watchman. He was having his lunch at the time but fortunately was within calling distance. If a man had not been up and around I hate to think what might have happened.

To give you some idea of the gravity of the situation here I may say that when the negro troops now stationed here were in Skagway one of them raped a woman over 50 years old during the absence of her husband. It is also reported that another case of rape, this time a girl of 9 years old, took place in Whitehorse. Even though we have 2 Mounted Policemen in Carcross and certain military police they have quite a time dealing with approximately 1,500 men. The woman on the staff of our school have stated on several occasions what a relief it is to have a Night Watchman who can give the alarm if anything happens.
The present Night Watchman (Mr. T. Brooks) told me that he can promise to remain on the job until the end of June. Likely after that date, if necessary, we can get someone else.

Seeing that the Department pay for the services of a Night Watchman up to March 31st 1942 only it would be appreciated if you would advise what can be done about paying Mr. Brooks. At the end of this month he will have 2 months' salary coming.

Yours respectfully,

(sgd) H. C. M. Grant.
Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

You may recall that during my recent visit to Ottawa I spoke to you about the urgent need of continuing the services of the Night Watchman at the Carcross School. This need is quite fully set forth in the enclosed letter from the Rev. Principal Grant, and it will be appreciated if your Department will authorize the continuance of the services of the present Night Watchman (Mr. T. Brooks) until the end of June at the rate allowed for him during the winter months, namely $40.00 per month.

The question of the need of the services of a Night Watchman after the end of June will depend on the decision of the Government regarding the transfer of the staff and pupils of this school to Dawson, and the continued presence in Carcross of the troops mentioned.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir:

Your letter of the 3rd instant, addressed to Dr. McGill, has been referred to me.

Yours truly,

WINNIPEG, MAN. February 4, 1943.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

Re:- Carcross Indian Residential School

In Departmental letter dated July 13, 1939, the suggestion was made that the new Carcross School building might be constructed of logs, and while we realise that capital expenditure for this purpose may not be available in the immediate future, it would be helpful to our Commission and our Society in formulating our plans if your architect could furnish us, for consideration in advance, with a design of the main and subsidiary buildings which you consider would meet the requirements of a pupilage of not less than 80.

The opinion of our Commission, with regard to the type of building to be erected, to take the place of the one destroyed by fire was set forth in my letter to the Director of your Department on June 28th, 1939, and with my letter to the Superintendent of Welfare and Training on October 27th, 1939, I enclosed a sketch of the new building as drawn by the Rev. Principal Grant. Departmental replies to these letters were dated Ottawa, July 13, 1939, (#166-1-5) and Ottawa, November 3rd, 1939, (#166-1-6).

As our Society stands greatly in need of other Indian Residential Schools in the remoter parts of Canada, namely, one to take the place of the Mackay School destroyed by fire some years ago, and another to take the place of the Fort George School recently destroyed by fire, in addition to new school buildings at Whitefish Lake and Wabasca, the design adopted for the new Carcross School might serve for the others as well.
This information will help you to understand why I consider it important that careful attention be given at the earliest date possible to the adoption of an approved design for these various institutions.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

TBRW*WS

Secretary of the Commission.
Ottawa,
February 10, 1943.

Will you please refer to your memorandum of the 10th instant, file 166-1-5, in which you enclosed a copy of a letter received from the Rev. Dr. Westgate.

The Minister agrees with your views, namely that it would not be wise at this time to give Doctor Westgate any encouragement that either in the near future or after the war we will be able to enter upon any large program of building new residential schools.

Ottawa, February 22, 1943.
Ottawa,
February 23, 1943.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant in which you review the places where you feel that new residential schools should be erected and requesting that a plan be prepared.

Due to the fact that no funds are provided in the current year's appropriation for the erection of new residential schools and the further fact that we have not received any assurance whatsoever that funds for this purpose will be provided in the immediate future, I thought it advisable to submit your request to the Minister's office. The opinion has been expressed that it is not advisable, at the present time, to give you any encouragement that either in the near future or after the war we will be able to enter upon any large programme of building new residential schools. Under these circumstances we feel that there is no necessity for preparing any plan.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Re: Carcross School

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have just read your letter of November 3rd, #166-1-5, with great surprise, and regret that at the moment I can add nothing to the information given by your Indian Agent at Dawson. It is most disconcerting, however, to learn that the Department has not been aware of the desire of our Church to have this school rebuilt. The matter was presented to the Director by the Bishop of Yukon and myself on September 18th, and it has been my understanding that the Bishop returned for a full consultation a few days later.

I may say that the closing of this school was reported to the Executive Committee of our Missionary Society on September 7th, and the feeling was then strongly expressed that everything possible should be done to have it reopened without delay. The Bishop of Yukon was called into consultation and after hearing from him, the Executive Committee passed a motion affirming the conviction that the work begun by Bishop Bompas must be continued at all costs, and appointed a Committee to deal with the matter. It was understood that this Committee would send a delegation to Ottawa, after obtaining the authority of General Synod to incur any necessary expenditure. The decision of the Department not to rebuild the school until after the war, was in mind, but it was hoped that some financial assistance might be available, either from the unexpended allocation or in lieu of rent being paid up to now for temporary quarters. It was the judgment of Bishop Geddes and Principal Grant that buildings could be erected on the old site of such a nature that the full quota of pupils could be cared for until the permanent school is built, and could later serve in a permanent way as manual training shops or residences. It was hoped that if
the Department did not feel able to erect such units of the complete school plant at this time, it might approve of the Church doing so, and give some assurance of reimbursement of the cost later on.

The Committee later secured the desired authority from General Synod, and Bishop Geddes and I were deputed to proceed to Ottawa and advise the Department of our desires. As the Sarcee question had also arisen, the House of Bishops asked the Bishop of Ottawa to accompany us in that connection. You will recall our conference in Dr. McGill's office on a Saturday morning and it must have been after you had withdrawn that the discussion passed on to Carcross. The Director was sympathetic but felt that the question of possible expenditure should be referred to the Minister. When it was found that Mr. Crerar was out of the City, an appointment was made for the following Tuesday and Bishop Geddes arranged to return to Ottawa after spending the weekend in Montreal. As the matter was thus deferred for a couple of days and its presentation left in Bishop Geddes' hands, I did not discuss it in my subsequent conversation with you.

I am afraid that my knowledge ends at this point. Having arranged to visit Moose Factory, I was compelled to leave Ottawa before the Bishop's return and I have received no information as to what transpired. On reaching Winnipeg, I was disappointed to learn that he had returned to the Yukon by air and that no word had been received from him. I wrote for information but have as yet no reply, and have concluded that the Bishop is on one of his journeys in the north. It may be that he has been waiting to secure alternative plans and costs, and that we shall be hearing from him before the meeting of our Missionary Society's Executive in Toronto on November 23rd. A few days ago, I wrote to our General Secretary, Canon Dixon, in regard to the matter and asked him to endeavour to obtain some information by telegraph.

I regret the length of this letter, but it seemed necessary to state the facts fully, seeing that by some inadvertence you have not been informed of what has transpired. I hope to be in a position to deal with this matter more intelligently when I see you on the 26th.

Yours sincerely,

N.A. Elderwood

Secretary.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Further to my letter of the 9th, I have just received from our Head Office in Toronto a copy of telegram received from Bishop Geddes in the following terms:

"OTTAWA ASKED US TO SUBMIT DEFINITE PLANS OF PROPOSED BUILDING AND COST OF SAME. SINCE MY RETURN HAVE BEEN WORKING ON PLANS IN CONSULTATION WITH PRINCIPAL GRANT AND AM NOW AWAITING INFORMATION FROM VANCOUVER AS TO COSTS. WHEN THESE RECEIVED WILL FORWARD THEM TO YOU FOR SUBMISSION TO OTTAWA"

In view of our message to the Bishop, I am sure he will do everything possible to obtain the necessary estimates so that we may be in a position to discuss the matter intelligently with you. Meanwhile, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

This is in reply to your letter of September 26th 1943 with regard to accounts submitted by me covering rental of buildings for the month of July 1943. It is noted that the Department of Indian Affairs would not pay rent after June 30th, 1943.

In the first place as I was informed by the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission that the Indian Department had approved the closing of this school on June 15th and re-opening it on August 15th I could not inform the owners of these buildings that no rent would be paid after June 30th, 1943. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Carcross School.

I have just received word from Bishop Geddes that the material for this building has arrived at Carcross and that the construction should be completed in less than a month. Bishop Geddes is giving personal supervision to this work in conjunction with Archdeacon Grant, who will be the Principal of the School when it is opened. I am advised that already twenty applications for admission to the School have been received without any attempt at recruiting and the Bishop is confident that a full enrolment will be secured.

The Bishop writes about several pieces of equipment which he feels the Department may be able to secure, possibly through some reciprocal arrangement with the American Government. I think it well to quote from his letter—"There are two items of equipment that we need that I think the Department at Ottawa should supply. One is a small Caterpillar Tractor and the other a lighting plant. The U.S. Army have many of both of these pieces of equipment in the country and already are beginning to ship them out. Do you think you could persuade Mr. Hoey to secure these for us? A tractor would be of far more value to us than the two teams of horses that we formerly had. A truck could also be used if it were obtainable, but the first two mentioned are the more essential. The U.S.E.D. began this week on a shipment of 6000 pieces of equipment from Whitehorse to Skagway and thence back to the U.S. It will probably take them two or three months to get this shipment out of the country and there will be other such shipments to follow. Most of the construction work of the U.S.E.D. will be completed by September, so unless we secure these this summer it may not be possible to do so another year. Then too there are some buildings at Carcross that could be turned into a warehouse for our School. I wonder if Mr. Hoey would try to get one of these for us."

I trust that it may be possible for some of this equipment to be secured, seeing how difficult it is to obtain at the present time. We endeavoured to secure some of the buildings that have been in use but were informed that they could not be erected again after having been several times taken down and moved. Unfortunately this
has necessitated a heavier cost for building and we appear already to have incurred an expenditure of some eighteen thousand dollars.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Replying to your letter of May 5th (1946-1-5) I beg to advise you that the schools at Carcross and Fort George are now under construction and that there is every possibility that both will be in readiness for opening at the close of the summer.

At Fort George, building operations were commenced last summer and the main structure was closed in before the winter commenced, so that a good deal of interior work went on without interruption. The Bishop of the Arctic has personally planned and directed this project and intends to proceed to Fort George by the first boat this season and possibly to spend a month there. I am advised that the building is 101'6" by 65' and is an excellent building in every way. There has been considerable difficulty in securing the necessary materials but matters are now well advanced and there should be no difficulty in completing the work this summer.

At Carcross, the situation also is most hopeful. We are holding in mind the intention of the Department to construct a permanent building in place of that which was destroyed by fire in 1939. In view, however, of the fact that the rented buildings in the village of Carcross were condemned by medical authority and that our children could not otherwise be provided for, our Missionary Society decided to go ahead with the construction of temporary buildings to serve until such time as the Government school can be rebuilt. Attempts were made to secure suitable used buildings in the territory but in the opinion of Bishop Geddes this was not possible. It was also found impossible to secure labour for log buildings or all the necessary lumber for a frame structure. We have, therefore, taken the only remaining alternative and have secured from Vancouver three prefabricated buildings, each 24' by 72' which will be constructed in the form of the letter H. These are good buildings and will be well finished within and painted on the exterior. They are built to stand the winter conditions of the Yukon and careful plans have been prepared so that the school may operate with maximum efficiency. My latest information was to the effect that all the material had arrived on the school site and that a local contractor with much experience in erecting such buildings was preparing to undertake the work. By this time it should be well in hand and there should
be no difficulty in reopening the school at the end of August, as much of the former equipment is in storage at Carcross. I understand that applications are already being received and we are hopeful that 50 pupils may be accommodated.

Trusting this information will meet your requirements,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Dear Sir:-

In reply to your letter of the 10th instant the following is a detailed report respecting damage done by the United States Army and Construction Companies to the telephone line between Carcross and the Carcross Indian Residential School:-

Prior to the advent of the United States Army and Construction Companies into the Yukon there was in operation a telephone line between Carcross and the Carcross Indian Residential School a distance of approximately 2 miles. This line crossed two roads in Carcross and the Government Bridge. For a distance of approximately one mile it was attached to the poles running parallel to the White Pass and Yukon Railway. It then cut across country and at one point crossed the road that leads from Carcross to Tagish. The damage done to this line is as follows:-

1. Trucks operated by the Betchel-Price-Callahan Company broke the line where it crossed the two roads in Carcross. These breaks were not repaired.

2. When a Flying Fortress was salvaged recently from Lake Bennett it was necessary for the Government Bridge to be opened. This occasioned the telephone line being cut and it is still broken.

3. Some years before the war the school obtained permission
to affix this line to the poles along the White Pass and Yukon Railway for a distance of approximately one mile. A short time ago the Hatfield Electric Company installed new poles and lines along this railroad. The old poles and lines were removed but our line was not replaced on the new poles. I might add that when our line was removed the White Pass and Yukon Railway was, and still is, being operated by the United States Army.

4. The 93rd Engineers in building the road between Carcross and Tagish broke the line where it crossed the road. This part of the line and quite a stretch on either side is missing.

Yours truly,

H. C. M. Grant.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have just returned from a lengthy visit to All Saints' School, Aklavik, and our new buildings at Carcross, Yukon. I am hoping to send you some report with my impressions and suggestions, but meanwhile desire to bring to your attention one pressing matter. The question of securing necessary equipment from the American Military authorities has been raised on several previous occasions. When I last discussed it with you in Ottawa, you kindly referred me to Mr. Viaume, and he promised to do his best for us, although he declared there were considerable technicalities to be overcome. I understand that Bishop Geddes has discussed this matter fully with your Agent in the Yukon, Mr. Gibbon, and that he already sent in a list of the items desired. All of these are available in the disused American camp near Carcross, and have been inspected by the Bishop and Agent, and found satisfactory for use in the school. We understand that many of these items are now being sold locally, while on the other hand train-loads of equipment are continually moving towards the coast, and items which we cannot obtain are being shipped out of the country. The school building is well advanced towards completion and there is no doubt that it can be opened at the beginning of September, with a full enrollment of pupils, if the remaining items of equipment can be secured. Such items as the lighting plant, cooking range, heater and boiler, are, of course, essential, and all the equipment listed is really necessary for the efficient operation of the school. May I plead that this matter may be given special attention in view of the shortness of time and that every effort may be made for some common-sense arrangement whereby the material now on the spot may be secured for this school?

Thanking you, and with kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:-

Re 166-1-5.

This is a reply to your letter of December 27th 1944.

Sixty cots were supplied to us by the United States Army. The officer on duty at the time we went to Whitehorse to pick up these and other goods instructed those under him to deliver this quantity to us. Apparently an error has been made but I can assure you that with an expected 50 pupils in residence most of these cots will be put to good use.

With regard to flannelette blankets these were handed out in unbroken case lots and those making delivery no doubt thought that these cases contained what was requested. As far as the school is concerned single blankets are more serviceable than pairs.

Reference your letter of the 3rd instant Re: Fuel wood for Carcross Y.T. Indian Residential School, I wish to report as follows:

In June 1945 Mr. F. H. R. Jackson, Timber Inspector for the Whitehorse District found a Mr. Lowe cutting 250 cords of green wood on the south side of the Carcross-Tagish road between M 7 and M 8 out of Carcross. Mr. Jackson reports that this timber was being cut right on the road leaving slash which increased the fire hazard. Mr. Lowe, on being questioned, stated that he had no permit but was cutting for the Indian School at Carcross. He was warned regarding the cutting of timber so close to the road and later moved to another area on the North side of M. 12.

Mr. Jackson states that he interviewed Rev. H. C. M. Grant, Principal of Chootle Indian School at Carcross with regard to timber permit. Mr. Grant declared that he had not previously been required to obtain a permit but would write to his Head Office concerning the matter. Up to the date of your letter no permit had been requested by him at this office.

Mr. L. Higgins, former Timber Agent for the Whitehorse District covered Mr. Jackson's inspection trip to Carcross and his (Mr. Jackson's) interview with Mr. Grant, in this office letter to you dated December 13, 1945.

Owing to forest fire hazard Mr. Jackson had been unable to provide transportation for myself to Carcross, prior to May 25th on which date I took this matter up with Bishop Geddes who arranged for Mr. Grant to call at this office May 28th.

At the interview with Mr. Grant and Bishop Geddes in this office the situation was made clear and Mr. Grant made application for a free permit to cut 100 cords. It was explained that the school required an average of 225 cords per annum for heating purposes and the request was made that the free permit be extended in this case to include that amount.

It is therefore recommended that the Indian School at Carcross be granted a free permit to cut 225 cords annually with the understanding that they use only dry wood which in turn will help reduce the forest fire hazard.

Further to your letter of March 20, re the preparation of Annual Estimates, and our reply of March 25, please be advised that many of the sheets included in a complete set of Welfare Estimates do not refer to your agency. The Indians of Canada are divided into two classes; Treaty Indians and non-Treaty Indians. Your Indians belong to the latter class and are not entitled by treaty terms to issues of Ammunition, Nets, Snare-wire, Triennial Clothing, etc.

In the three Prairie Provinces, the Northwest Territories and remote areas where Indians are located long distances from source of supplies, Agents estimate their relief requirements food, soap, etc., each year in advance. These supplies are purchased on contract from wholesalers and shipped in to departmental warehouses, from which they are distributed weekly, or monthly, to aged and indigent Indians who have no other source of maintenance.

In the other parts of the Dominion and your agency, assistance is supplied by direct purchase from the merchant. However, if your Indians can be taken off direct relief by the issue of nets, ammunition, snare-wire or seeds the Branch is prepared to give sympathetic consideration to any representations you may care to make. In fact, it will be in order to include items in your 1947-48 Estimates covering requirements in tent duck (Allotment 12-421) canoe canvas (09-632) ammunition, twine for nets and snare-wire (02-229).

Insofar as Indian Education is concerned, it is not necessary to estimate for desks, supplies, rents and teachers' salaries. These are all included by the Branch in a bulk amount, based on part year's requirements and new commitments.

However, it will be necessary to include estimates for:

(1) Repairs required to government-owned buildings; and

(2) New buildings required.

If you will please let us know your requirements for biscuits, we will put these amounts in our order which goes to the manufacturers on May 15. To assist you in estimating requirements, it is suggested that you allow for 6 lbs. per student in average attendance, e.g., if average attendance is 20 - then ask for 120lbs of biscuits for that particular school.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

On Saturday, November 8th, I proceeded to Carcross Residential School, accompanied by Dr. E.H.J. Smyth, Northern Mobile Medical Clinic, and Miss Parr P.H.N., both of Edmonton. An improved aspect was immediately noted throughout the whole school. The last time the school was inspected was in company with Major C.A.F. Clark, on May 29th, 1947. I do not imagine that the school made a good impression on our educational supervisor.

Being a Saturday, classes were not in progress. A more detailed examination of the various buildings was undertaken. There are at present two main buildings, both of wooden construction. The main section contains dormitories, laundry, kitchen, dining rooms, offices, etc. The other building is the class room, food storage, and scout hall. A number of outside buildings contained farm equipment, dwellings for staff, etc. These buildings were erected as a temporary measure after the disastrous fire which destroyed the original school on April 17th, 1939.

While the main building may be satisfactory for several more years, I wish to point out that the schoolroom itself is not in good condition. This is not a reflection on the present staff who have worked hard and improved conditions noticeably, but the schoolroom was not a good building to begin with, and the exterior is becoming weatherbeaten.

I am in receipt of a report from Dr. Smyth, which I quote:

"A very interesting and pleasant visit was paid to the Anglican school at Carcross, in company with Mr. Meek and Miss Hackett. There were 45 pupils in school and we were struck by their happy demeanour, and by the accomplishments they were being taught. After lunch a troupe of girl guides was called in and gave some good part-singing - a show which would have done credit to any white school-children of similar age. One was struck by the complete absence of shyness. We then turned to the medical side of things and got down to some physical examinations of the new admissions and of a number of children who were suspected of being sick for one reason."
Miss Beanland, a trained nurse, is on the school staff and would, I understand, be willing to handle drugs for the Indians of Carcross village, as well as for the school-children, but that she feels herself at the present subject to the limitations described above.

In the dormitories, the former crowded conditions have been somewhat improved, though not very much. In this connection Dr. Smyth observes:

"The school buildings are certainly very unserviceable; they were put up as a makeshift only after the fire some time ago. Major Clark examined them and found the space per head just half the prescribed amount. The school-room building, said to be the property of the Department of Health and welfare, is extremely ramshackle with large holes in walls and floor. There is no separate storehouse so that in the event of fire everything would be lost at once. However this matter has no doubt already been drawn to the attention of those who should take the matter up."

No doubt the Branch is aware of conditions at Carcross School through the visit of Educational Supervisor Clark. Suffice to say, conditions have improved considerably, but the building of a proper school room should be given consideration.

(R.J. Meek)
Indian Agent.

Dear Colonel Neary,

In April of 1939 the Chootla School at Carcross, Yukon, (a government owned school) was lost by fire. As the government, due to war conditions, was unable to re-build the structure, the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada erected a temporary building at a cost of $24,000. The building was not sufficiently large for permanent use and it was thought that at the conclusion of hostilities the government would replace the temporary structure erected by the Church with a larger building suitable for permanent use.

The present situation at Carcross is most unsatisfactory. The school is authorized to carry sixty pupils but dormitory and other accommodation allows for no more than forty-five. Staff members are inadequately quartered and the principal is finding it necessary to live in a built-over chicken house. All, staff and children alike, suffer from the cold and drafty buildings during the winter time and there is the ever constant fear of fire from the use of many stoves.

At the moment, the Administration is in the unhappy position of losing the services of an excellent principal unless better accommodation can be arranged for his family before next winter.

Less than one hundred miles from Carcross the Government is constructing a large modern school for the Roman Catholic Church. The Administration feels that our needs for more adequate facilities at Carcross ought to have had prior consideration.

In the light of the above, I would respectfully submit for your consideration the following:

As the Department, due to war conditions, was unable to replace the structure, the M.S.C.C., erected a temporary building at a cost of $24,000. Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Carcross Indian Residential School.

In April, 1939, the above Residential School, at that time Government-owned, was lost by fire. It had an authorized enrolment at that time of 40 pupils. As the Department, due to war conditions, was unable to replace the structure, the M.S.C.C. erected a temporary building at a cost of $24,000.00. The building was not sufficiently large for permanent use and it was thought that at the conclusion of hostilities the Government would replace the temporary structure, erected by the Church, with a larger building suitable for permanent use.

We have now received a letter from Canon Cook of the M.S.C.C., reading in part as follows:

"The present situation at Carcross is most unsatisfactory. The school is authorized to carry sixty pupils but dormitory and other accommodation allows for no more than forty-five. Staff members are inadequately quartered and the principal is finding it necessary to live in a built-over chicken house. All, staff and children alike, suffer from the cold and draughty buildings during the winter time and there is the ever constant fear of fire from the use of many stoves.

"At the moment, the Administration is in the unhappy position of losing the services of an excellent principal unless better accommodation can be arranged for his family before next winter.

"Less than one hundred miles from Carcross the Government is constructing a large modern school for the..."
Roman Catholic Church. The Administration feels that our needs for more adequate facilities at Carcross ought to have had prior consideration.

"In the light of the above, I would respectfully submit for your consideration the following:

(a) That a suitable building for the Principal and his family be constructed this summer at the Carcross Residential School.

(b) That the Indian Department have its engineers visit the site of the Chootla School with a view to their making recommendations to enlarge the school to suitable proportions for adequate accommodation of at least eighty pupils and the necessary staff.

(c) That a sufficient sum be included in the 1949-50 appropriation to allow for the renovations or rebuilding recommended by the engineers."

In view of the representations made above by Canon Cook, it is recommended that the following action be taken:

(a) That a Prefabricated Bungalow be ordered from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, of Vancouver, B.C., for shipping to Carcross by July 15. Mr. Indian Agent Meek advises that a prefabricated building of this type would be satisfactory and the Principal of the School will also accept such a building. If you concur in this recommendation, we attach a requisition covering the purchase of this building.

(b) That approval be given to having one of the officials of the Lands and Development Services Branch visit this school with a view to making recommendations concerning the enlargement, as mentioned by Canon Cook.

Director.

Memorandum

Re: Carcross Indian Residential School, Carcross, Yukon.

In reply to your marginal notation dated June 14th, appearing on Mr. Hoey's memorandum of the 11th instant, in connection with a lighting plant for the above, we make the following comments.

It is apparent from the correspondence and tenders forwarded with Mr. Hoey's memorandum that the Missionary Society of the Church of England has decided to change the electrical system from alternating current to storage battery direct current type of system.

This type of system is suitable to the electrical loads and will supply a source of power without operating a generating unit whenever power is required, and should, if care is exercised in operating the equipment, provide a more economical means of power supply. It is pointed out, however, that changes will be necessary to many appliances and possibly to radios used to make them suitable on direct current. The batteries should be housed in a location where they will not be subjected to extreme temperatures, and before ordering this equipment space requirements should be obtained from the supplier and provision made for them.

The information supplied by the Principal in his letter dated May 10th last is not complete in that the individual loads and the time of operation of each per day is not noted. We have taken the total wattage in each building and have estimated the probable daily watt hour demand. From this, we suggest that a 56 cell storage battery of 360 ampere hour capacity should be provided, which will allow approximately three (3) days between charging periods.

To charge this battery a shunt wound generator of approximately 4 K.W. capacity with voltage range of 115 to 145 volts D.C. should be provided. The control panel, in addition to an ammeter, voltmeter, field rheostat and fused line switch, should be provided with automatic over-charging protection for the battery. All wiring necessary between generating unit, switch board and batteries should be provided along with complete detailed instructions for the installation, maintenance and operation of the plant in conjunction with the batteries to insure maximum efficiency and life of the lighting plant.

We suggest that Hoffars Limited of Vancouver be contacted to determine if their generating unit offered, which is rated at 4½ K.W., 110 volt D.C., can give the voltage range desired, which is important to enable the proper safe current charging rates for

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
the battery and the proper volts per cell required for efficient operation of the lighting plant. The automatic over-charge protection is essential when the charging equipment is non-automatic.

It is realized that a plant as outlined above would be more costly than that offered, but it is considered that installation will prove more satisfactory from the standpoint of service and economy.

It is strongly recommended that a qualified electrician be engaged to install the plant and to check on the distribution system to make sure that the line losses are not excessive, and that the fuse protection at each building is satisfactory.

We are returning herewith tender forwarded with Mr. Hoey's memorandum for transmission to Indian Affairs.

Chief Engineer.

Having reference to your letter of the 6th October last, File No. 12367-2, with regard to the Anglican Mission School at Carcross, Y.T., I beg to report that I visited Carcross in conjunction with work for this Department at Whitehorse, Carcross and Prince Rupert.

The Indian Agent at Whitehorse, Y.T. drove me to Carcross and I made a complete survey of the present buildings owned by the Anglican Mission. The land, I understand, is Indian Reserve.

I might say that the present set-up of operating a Mission and School in the present buildings is far from satisfactory.

All the buildings belonging to the Anglican Mission, with the exception of the new Log Garage and Root House, recently built, are in bad state of repair.

All the buildings used by the children, including the Army Hut used as a school and Club Room, are heated by oil drum wood stoves, piped with stovepipes into the regular Yukon safety chimneys. The method of heating these buildings is very unsatisfactory, as it is impossible to get the heat properly distributed and, during cold weather, these stoves have to be kept on at full blast, which I consider is dangerous and a grave fire menace.

The Main Building, of which I am enclosing a blueprint showing the layout, is heated with nine (9) stoves distributed about the building.

I noticed one great loss of heat, which I pointed out to the Principal and he is having it rectified. The trap door in the ceiling in the hall is kept open and the heat rushes up into the hall like a cyclone. The reason it was kept open, I was informed, was to keep the water storage tank from freezing. All the pipes are on the underside of the ceiling. Therefore, I recommended that a false ceiling and walls be built over the tank and the trap door to allow the heat to circulate only around the tank and stop the rush of hot air going out through the roof, which is open the entire length of the building at the eaves.

The ceiling and walls of the Mission Building are insulated.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
The Main Building consists of three (3) lockstave prefabricated buildings, placed in an H position, as shown on the plan, with the center building joined on the Ground Floor at each end.

The roof of the Main Building is gabled and not connected, except by a board nailed at the eaves of the two wings, which makes a flat valley between the buildings with no way of getting rid of the snow, except by shovelling out from between the buildings.

The roofs are in bad condition and leak all over. The paper, which is a two-ply rolled roofing, is almost weathered clean of asphalt and is badly in need of re-roofing. The wind was fairly strong the day I was there and the roofing was lifting in places.

I realize the building was built as an emergency and a temporary measure and has no doubt served its purpose during the last four years. However, if these Indian children and Staff are to continue as a unit, a new building should be provided at the earliest moment.

The exterior boarding is badly warped in places, knots have fallen out and generally is in a bad state of repair.

The whole of the exterior needs painting. Steps and landings require replacing.

There are forty-six (46) children living in this building and the Principal informed me that there were about sixty (60) more children outside, of whom they could take care if they had accommodation.

The interior is in just as bad a state of repair as the exterior. In fact, it has never been completely finished. In several places the base has been left off and many of the panel strips are missing. Some rooms are not painted but were left bare. The whole of the walls and ceilings are covered with tentest wallboard and in many places holes have been punched through both walls.

All the woodwork, walls and ceilings are in need of cleaning and two (2) coats of paint.

The floors are badly worn and, in some places, where the traffic is heavy, are worn down to the tongue, making them very dangerous and almost impossible to scrub, due to so many splinters. These floors should be covered immediately with tempered masonite, which I consider would be the cheapest and most satisfactory covering. It would be impossible to cover them with linoleum without replacing large sections of flooring.

The lavatory accommodation is inadequate - one washroom to each section of boys and girls. Each washroom has one bathtub, one toilet and one common sink to wash in, all in one room. This accommodation is not sufficient for forty-six (46) children, housed day and night.
The Staff has one bathroom with three fixtures.

There is no room for any child who happens to be sick and it is considered there should be a room with toilet facilities for any ailing child.

The lighting is by an old electric light plant, operated by a gasoline engine. The building is lighted by drop lights, which can only be turned on when the electric light plant is working. Generally, the building is very poorly lit.

There is a good supply of water pumped from an enclosed well to a tank in the ceiling and supplied by gravity to the fixtures.

The sink in the Kitchen requires replacing, as also do the drainboards and kitchen fixtures. The cook stove is badly worn and needs replacing, being worn through from the firebox to the oven, which has been patched up with brickwork.

An old Army Hut, not painted, is being used as a School Room, Play Room, Club Room, Workshop and dry storage space. The rooms are heated by drum stoves.

There is an old house which houses the Indian family. The man is the Night Watchman and his wife is the Cook. This building is old and in bad state of repairs.

The Log Building with concrete foundations and concrete floor with basement for vegetable storage and car storage above, is a new building and in good state of repair.

The present house, in which the Principal lives, is an old barn, converted into a dwelling and is in bad state of repair. A new house is being built at the present time for the Principal, which should be completed in about one month and a half.

Old Army Prefabricated Hut .................. 1,250.00

TOTAL - Value of Buildings .... $19,539.00

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Purchase of Carcross Residential School

Included in our Main 1948-49 Estimates is the sum of $30,000.00 for the purchase of the Carcross Residential School from the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada.

Arrangements were made with the Department of Public Works for the valuation of the buildings at this school. You will find attached a copy of the report submitted by the Chief Architect of the Department of Public Works after his district resident architect had visited the school and made an inspection and valuation.

Immediately this report was received from the Chief Architect, we wrote to the M.E.C.C. requesting their assurance that the five building mentioned in the Department of Public Works reports were the buildings which they wished to sell to the Department and that they are their property.

We have just now received a reply from the M.E.C.C. advising that these are the buildings which they wish to sell to the Department and that all of them are the property of the M.E.C.C. The delay in replying to our letter was due to the necessity of referring our enquiry to both Carcross and Toronto.
Could you please advise whether it will be in order to have a draft Order-in-Council prepared covering the purchase of these buildings as planned.

Director.

BFN/AM
APPENDIX A.

CARCROSS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This school was destroyed by fire in 1939 and replaced by temporary and prefabricated buildings by the M.S.C.C. As you are aware, we are purchasing these buildings and the Indian School Administration of the M.S.C.C. has specifically requested that we erect new buildings to accommodate the children now in attendance and others for whom no educational facilities are provided.

I would therefore recommend that an Educational Survey Committee be established to visit the various Indian reserves and schools presently operated for Anglican children in the Yukon and report on the following:

(1) The educational facilities which should be provided for Indian children of the Anglican faith in the Yukon.

(2) If the provision of day schools is recommended, where should these be situated and of what type?

(3) If a residential school is recommended, where should it be located and what pupil accommodation should be provided?

(4) Other specific facts and comments concerning the educational facilities presently provided and recommendations concerning co-operation with the Yukon Territorial Council schools.

I would recommend that this committee be composed of the following members:

(a) C.A.F. Clark, Educational Survey Officer, Indian Affairs Branch.

(b) Ronald Hulland, Superintendent of Schools, Yukon Territorial Council.

(c) An Anglican Missionary appointed by the M.S.C.C.
Insofar as funds are not provided in our appropriation this year for the construction of a school or a unit of a school at Carcross, I feel that this educational survey could be carried out in September, 1949.

Dear Major Mackay:

Re: Purchase of Carcross Residential School.

Your letter of the 15th February 1949 re the above subject is before me.

For the first four buildings on your list you propose an evaluation of $18,289.00. While your estimate for the three smaller buildings is satisfactory, we feel that the estimate for the main building - $15,889.00-is low. Even though it is not in first class condition, we feel that on the basis of present day replacement value, $20,000 for this building, making a total of $22,400, would be a fairer figure.

With reference to the old army prefabricated hut which, as you have indicated, has not been included in the evaluation, I would point out that while the material was supplied by the Government, the labour for its erection and the extension which has been added, were provided by the school management.

A letter was sent to the Principal at Carcross, on 11th February 1949, asking for a list and evaluation of the Church owned furniture and equipment in the several buildings. This will be forwarded on receipt.

With reference to the land on which the buildings stand, we are informed that it is the property of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Re: Carcross, Y.T. - Indian Residential School - Valuation

Please refer to your letter dated March 30. This matter was referred to the District Resident Architect, Victoria, who made the inspection and report of valuation on the Indian Residential School buildings at Carcross. I am now in receipt of his reply and I quote, in part, as follows:

"In making my valuation, I definitely took into consideration the condition of the building. As I pointed out in my report, this is a wartime erected prefabricated hut, and I do not consider the building is worth more than the valuation I placed on it. As far as replacements are concerned, this building could not be replaced even for the amount they specify, namely, $20,000.00.

I consider the cost of replacing a building of this size, with a proper up-to-date frame building, with concrete foundation, would be approximately, $39,835.00.

However, I was not making a report on replacements, but merely making a valuation of the present building and condition."

You will note from the above that the District Resident Architect in making his valuation of the buildings took into consideration the present condition of the structure.

It should be noted in the closing paragraph of the District Resident Architect's report that he states: "A new building should be erected in this area as soon as possible, as the present building was only a temporary measure due to the original building burning down."

Trusting this information is what you require,

Yours very truly,

C. Gustave Brault,
Chief Architect.

Mr. R.J. Meek,
