Re: Carcross Indian Residential School

With reference to the erection of the Principal's residence at the above school, it is regretted that there has been such a delay in handling the accounts. However, as the expenditure was much higher than we had anticipated, we were obliged to obtain funds in the 1949-50 appropriation to complete the building, and these funds have only recently been authorized.

We now have what we consider a sufficient amount to pay the outstanding accounts, and arrangements are being made to forward by airmail a cheque for $358.00 in favour of Rev. J.W. Ellis, in payment of your Voucher No. 20 covering the cost of meals for carpenters and helpers.

As you are aware, no official has the right to engage a contractor without first obtaining the Minister's approval. Consequently, when the prefabricated building was supplied and you applied for an accountable advance, we inferred that you were proceeding with the erection of the building by day labour, as you did not submit the name and address of any contractor for approval.

When we received your Voucher No. 19, it was presumed to be a Credit Voucher for the amount advanced to you. The main payment for which you requested credit was in connection with a payment to Robert Campbell.
Building Contractor. The first item on the account read "Labour 1190 hours" in an amount of $1,937.75. Acceptance of this Credit Voucher has been discussed with the Treasury Branch, but they simply will not recognize it as we have no contract signed with Mr. Campbell.

We do not wish you to infer that we consider that Mr. Campbell has not paid the men who worked on the job, but from the information on our files, it appears both to us and the Treasury Branch that he was simply the foreman, and consequently, for auditing purposes a mere statement to the effect that a sum of money was paid out to him is not sufficient. We are obliged to have receipted paylists signed by the men to whom the money was actually paid. At this point we feel it advisable to bring to your attention the fact that government auditing regulations are very exacting, and the Auditor General requires receipts showing that monies paid out have been received by those to whom payment is due. This is to avoid any subsequent claim against the government.

We attach the covering Voucher which you forwarded. It should have read "Credit Voucher in favour of R.J. Meek (In Trust)". The top of your Voucher read "Pay to Robert Campbell". This was not necessary, as he had already been paid by you from the accountable advance forwarded to you. Consequently, to settle Voucher No. 19, we will have to have a new covering Voucher reading in the correct manner, and we will have to receive a certified paylist as mentioned above, covering the labour in an amount of $1,937.75.

What has been said above regarding Voucher No. 19 applies also to Voucher No. 55. We will have to have a receipted paylist for the expenditure of $1,099.10 -- the first item on the Voucher.
We will also require an explanation of the reason for the 10% charge on the account attached to Voucher No. 55. If Mr. Campbell was engaged as foreman at a certain rate plus 10%, it should have been brought to our attention in the first place and authority received before proceeding. However, if you give us an explanation of the matter, we will endeavour to have the account accepted by the Treasury.

Regarding the item of $72.50 on Voucher No. 55 for meals for workmen, we desire to know the exact date for which meals are charged. This is in accordance with auditing regulations, so that the Voucher on our files will show that there has been no duplication of payment.

Regarding Voucher No. 156, we note that there is a surcharge of 10%. This is similar to the one mentioned in connection with Voucher No. 55, and an explanation is required. We also wish to know the dates and the rate per hour for which there is a charge of 32 hours for labour. We cannot understand why it was necessary to have Mr. Campbell purchase the supplies if he expected 10% of their cost, as we believe that the materials could have been bought by yourself, and thereby save this extra charge. An explanation would be appreciated.

With reference to Voucher No. 157, we require to know the exact dates for which Mr. Campbell requests payment of an amount of $19.50 for meals.

An early reply would be appreciated in order that the matter may be settled.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Memorandum:

MAJOR D.M. MACKAY

Re: Carcross Indian Residential School

During the early war years, this residential school burned, and naturally the Department was not in a position to replace it then. Therefore, the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada purchased a large prefabricated building, and with changes and alterations to the small buildings left standing, proceeded to operate a residential school with a reduced pupilage of 60 children.

Naturally the Society has been pressing for the re-erection of this building, and we have written to Canon Dixon of the M.S.C.C. suggesting that a dormitory block similar to that erected at the Wabasca C.E. Residential School, might be acceptable also at Carcross. Our idea was naturally that it would be relatively easy to prepare the plans and specifications of another dormitory building for Carcross, if it were similar to that successfully being used now at Wabasca.

It is our intention to include a sum of $175,000.00 in our 1950-51 Estimates for the erection of this dormitory block. Major Clark has visited the school and recommends that the present prefabricated building be converted for classroom use, for which it will be quite satisfactory. As we have recently erected a good Principal's residence, this should place the Carcross Residential School in a good position for the continued education of some 60 Indian children.

Bernard F. Neary,

Carcross Indian Residential School

With reference to your letter of 14th instant, file 940-5 (El). May I first remind you that the Yukon Agency has been more or less dormant for a number of years during which no building has taken place; there was, therefore, no precedent for the sort of project I was asked to undertake. I consulted Part X (Construction and Engineering) of Indian Agent's References and Regulations, but apparently did not interpret Para. 192 (Financial) aright. The Director's letter of June 2nd, 1948, file 166-1-5 (E) stated that funds had been provided for the purchase of a prefabricated house, and I assumed, whether rightly or wrongly, that construction costs had been provided for in the Estimates by Headquarters.

Robert Campbell of Whitehorse is the Yukon Agent for Prefabricated Structures, the firm supplying the house, and it is only natural that I referred to him for the erection of the Principal's Residence. As this was a departure from the usual construction in the Yukon, being the first one erected, Mr. Campbell would not give me a firm estimate. He stated he would superintend the construction of the building for cost of wages and materials purchased by him, plus 10 per cent. I regret to say, owing to my very frequent absences in the field during the summer months, I did not report this to you, but was under the impression I had done so. This error is the crux of the unfortunate subsequent happenings. There is no written contract with Robert Campbell.

You will please note that at no time had I assumed responsibilities for which I had no authority. All of my vouchers in connection with work performed by Robert Campbell quote as authority file 166-1-6 (E) dated July 7th, 1948. This was actually the Accountable Advance of $500.00 with which I paid for excavation of basement and carpenter work including building materials.

In explanation of my voucher 19 of Jan. 8th, 1949; of the total of $2513.06, I paid Robert Campbell $24.16, being the balance of my Accountable Advance. The sum of $2488.90 is still payable to Robert Campbell. However, I am attaching hereto amended voucher submitted in accordance with your instructions and also paylist receipted by...
members of Mr. Campbell's crew, amounting to $1937.75.

With reference to your 7th paragraph and my voucher 55, I am attaching duly receipted paylist in the amount of $1099.10. Also Item for $72.50, meals at Carcross, has been receipted, with exact dates shown.

Your paragraph 8. My explanation of Mr. Campbell's 10 per cent charges is given in second paragraph. The 10 per cent covered his outlay in payment of wages, materials and supplies. While it is apparent that a savings would have been effected if all purchases had gone through this office, I could not guarantee to Mr. Campbell nor to the Department the time necessary to consummate such transactions during our short and extremely busy summer, though in the wintertime I am in a much better position to devote my attention to building projects. As you may imagine Mr. Campbell is in an excellent position to obtain lumber and building supplies, and knows all the methods of circumventing shortages and expediting material. To give you a complete picture, I could not ask Clerk MacDonald to spare any time on this project as probably 95% of his time is taken up with Family Allowance matters.

Regarding your tenth paragraph and my voucher 156. Item "32 hours labour - $57.60" is for carpenter work, with broken time, between February 15th and February 20th, at the rate of $1.80 per hour.

It is unfortunate that until receipt of your letter at this office on Nov. 16th, 1949, I had no specific knowledge of incorrect procedure. I sent telegrams to you dated March 29th, April 18th, June 7th, July 18th and August 8th, concerning payment of vouchers, receiving a reply on August 8th.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, while visiting Whitehorse, kindly consented to review the case with Robert Campbell and myself, with the result that I wrote to you on September 22nd, 1949, my penultimate paragraph showing that I was unaware of any irregularity.

I attach also a letter from Robert Campbell addressed to the Branch explaining his inability to receipt paylists.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent

Sir:

I have the honor to refer to Departmental letter dated September 26th, 1929, No. 166-1-10 in which certain children including three by the name of Anderson were permitted to enter the Choontia Indian Residential School, Carcross, Yukon Territory, as pupils from the Stikine Indian Agency, B.C.

From Information furnished by Mr. Agent Harper Reed, the two Anderson children (the third having died) were allowed the usual summer vacation and their parents have positively refused to have these children return to the School. It appears that the death of the third child has prejudiced the parents against the School. Although the Agent has intimated that the cost of sending these children back to Carcross School will be about $75.00, he thinks it may be as well for the children to be allowed an extended vacation over the coming winter. The principal of the School, however, cannot agree to this as when the parents took the children on vacation they were assured by the principal that they would remain out of School only for the period of the holidays. The principal also believes that these cases should be dealt firmly with in order to avoid advantage being taken of the leniency by other Indian parents to the detriment of the school next summer.

In addition to the Anderson children two children of Indian Pat Mcclusky (Stikine Agency) of Telegraph Creek, are similarly truant pupils of Carcross School and the parents refuse to return them. The environment of these children is said to be anything but good, the father being a drunkard and the mother having gone off to live with a white man leaving the children with other Indians.

The sending of the Mcclusky children would be an additional heavy charge upon the Department. In view of the fact that the children would have to have an escort, the expenses of the latter would also have to be met. There being no constable attached to the Stikine Agency, a special officer would likely have to be commissioned by the Indian Agent.

In view of the heavy cost of having these children conveyed as truants for so great a distance and at so large an expense, I have deemed it advisable that the circumstances be reported upon to the Department and its instructions obtained before incurring the cost of the necessary procedure.

Kindly wire advise in this connection in order that I may communicate with Agent Reed before he leaves Atlin.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:-

An Indian boy from the Pelly River (Billie Johnnie) has been in the hospital at Whitehorse for a year suffering from a tubercular ankle joint. When I was in Whitehorse last September I visited the hospital and found that the boy could get about very well on crutches and in other ways appeared to be normal. A suggestion was made to Dr Wride that the boy might be sent to the Carcross Indian Residential School thus saving the expense at the hospital (over $100.00 per month).

I beg to report that this has now been done, the boy arrived at the school on October 20th. This boy's home being at Ross River where there is no mail service during the winter it is impossible to get the regular form or application for admission filled up by his parents. In view of the foregoing I wish to ask the Department to make the usual per capita grant for this boy until opportunity offers to get the regular form filled in.

It would appear only just that the school authorities be allowed the usual grant as they will have to feed, clothe and give him necessary attention. The cost of keeping him at the school is considerably less than the hospital charges. It is hoped that this will meet with favorable consideration by the Department.

Sir,

Re: Long Jim Dease, Children to Carcross School.

I beg to submit, herewith, Admission Forms, in Duplicate for three of the above Indian's children, Viz: Howard age 13, Willie age 12 and Ethel, age 11, to the Choctaw Industrial School for Indians at Carcross, Y.T.

A record of the family is also attached, which goes to show that this is a special case, and deserving.

Last winter the family were out from Liard trapping, but made very little in fur. During the winter, Long Jim goes off with Eva, the step daughter, and a complaint was laid against him, by his wife Nellie. Inspector Munsch of the R.C.M.P. cleared the matter up, by sending the wife and her family to here, and keeping Long Jim at Liard to trap. It is understood that he will also pay in to the Inspector, value for the up-keep of his family this spring.

Since last Fall the family have been on the nation Sheet of this Office, as they are destitute. Nellie the wife is a fine Indian woman and doing all she can to bring them up correctly. The two lads, especially are now at the age when they will either go good or bad, and should certainly be taken away from this very bad half-breed town, where morals are not considered.

Therefore, it is thought correct to take these two boys over to Atlin, when my visit is paid there, in about a month's time, and see them safe under the care of Mr Grant of the Carcross School.

The Girl Ethel, with it is hoped two other girls, can be placed in this school, next spring when it is possible to get them over to Carcross, but the papers for her admission are submitted now.

Both parents are most desirous that their children go to this School, and the matter has been under way for nearly two years, but it is a hard job to get parents to allow their children to go so far away.

All of which, Sir, it is hoped meets with your approval with the assurance that the cost to all concerned is of course much less, over the winter trail, than if they were sent during the summer time, per coast wise U.S.A. boats.

I am,

The Secretary.

Sir,

Re :- Lillian (Nellie) Mc Clusky -age.9.

I beg to submit the undermentioned facts and data, so that a ruling may be obtained for future reference; three Indians are involved, their history sheets being as follows.

Mary WARD. Age 33. Mother of above child. One of the troublesome Paddy ward Family of Atlin, all given trouble but can't help it. Mary lived with Billy Fan years ago, and Lillian is their daughter. Later Mary went to live with Pat Mc Clusky, taking Lillian with her. Children by Pat are three - two boys, and one girl. Mary states that Billy Fan never really supported Lillian and therefore her girl. This girl cause of untold rows, so to settle the matter, Mary requested that she be sent to Carcross School with others going in 1929, which was done. In spring 1930 Mary and Pat went to Wrangell, S.E. Alaska and worked in a cannery. Pat returned for Guide on Big Game Hunt, leaving Mary down there. Mary then ran away with a Phillipino, leaving the two boys in Wrangell, and taking her young daughter with her. She is still on the coast, and claims to be a U.S.A. Citizen. Immigration Authorities advised both sides of the line, but at that the matter died.

Billy FAN. Father of Lillian. age 53. Always by himself and makes good money, never in debt. He is one of the old sort, does not believe in schools or Indian Trap Lines. Is connected with the "Joe Colburn" bunch of Indians and of The Allied Tribes Assoc. Affair. Best Big Game Guide we have. Now lays claim to Lillian and demands her release from School, also that her name be changed to Nellie Fan. Says she will be "no good" if she stays there. wants her to be returned so that she can look after his camp and his old Mother. Inclined to get very "uppish" over the matter. Has offered to make "will" (what of is not know) in her favour.

Pat Mc Clusky. age 46. Husband of Mary, father of three children by her, two boys, and one girl. He is a wild unsettled Indians always drunk when possible, and troublesome but one of the best worst men around. After Mary left him down at Wrangell, he went there and took his two boys to Carcross School, under proper papers Etc. However in Fall of 1931, after a lot of trouble with Law Authorities, he called at the School and got hold of his Boys, and hit the bush and has been out ever since. Matter taken up with Indian Commissioner Victoria, but expenses involved considered far too much for action to be taken.

The above long detail is rendered as it is thought the matter might again come up for attention, in the future.

May a ruling be given, as to if the girls name may be altered to Nellie Fan, and to whom, and also when, the Girl should be allowed to leave the School. A sample of her work is enclosed.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,

Dear Mr Reed,

With regard to Lena and Jeffy Williams I would like to say how pleased I am that they have been admitted to the Indian school at Carcross. A father of two myself, the plight of these two destitute waifs rather got under my skin. The little girl's condition will improve considerably under institutional treatment - and only with such supervised treatment. As for Jeffy I thought he was a particularly bright and healthy little chap and I'm very glad he is in a place where he will not be subjected to the various maladies to which he undoubtedly would succumb were he to remain with only his father's or some indifferent person's care. In my opinion the only chance these Indian kiddies have of keeping good health is to be placed in a school as early as possible.

With kindest regards I am,

With further regard to Frank Williams children who were going to come to your care. Upon return to Atlin Frank came in from the Taku River. As stated his wife with another child have died this winter, so he is certainly up against it. I have passed the two children through the local doctor here and you will see what he says but I think the younger of the two is really too small to be taken in charge by yourself.

However I have instructed Agness Crew, who is new in charge of the two kiddies to report to you, and what you decide goes. Agness Crew is also destitute, being the sister of Frank Williams wife, and her only relative living being the Johnston family in Carcross, to whom she is now going and staying with till the Spring sets in good.

If you turn down the youngsters or only one they will have to go and live with the Johnston family, in care of Agness till Springtime.

It would be advisable for Dr Wride to look into the matter and between you two settle what is best, and let me know.

When doing this please return the papers as they have to go to Ottawa for final admission.

Also ask Dr Wride to look over Agness who he is well acquainted with, as I think there is something the matter with her, he will do this of course, and she could be sent for when needed.

This is all I can do in the matter now.

Yours very sincerely,

Harper Reed
Indian Agent.

P.S.

The Johnston family also are destitute - drawing Ration - reason head of family just out of hospital. They lost a youngster also last fall - Summer should see this man working again.

Family's History Sheet. Members Church of England.
Husband. Frank. WILLIAMS Atlin Band. 29 years
Wife. Clarah. -- 34 died on Taku River Winter 1931.
Billy -- age 9. Attending Carcross Sch.
Jessie. -- 7. ditto
Lena -- 5½ now at ditto
Jeffy. -- 3 ditto

The Father is an intelligent and hard working Indian, and lives with his family at the lower end of the Taku River. His trapground returns are not large, whilst wages now received due to the drop in Silver, is hardly sufficient for their needs. Clarah, the last never recovered good health, after the last child was born, and this last Fall the younger daughter died, and later on the Wife passed away. This left the Indian with two youngsters and a baby on his hands, with only his wife's half sister, who also had a baby, to care for his family's affairs, which was too much for him to carry on with.

He arrived in Atlin at the same time as I returned from the Carcross School, and humbly requested that the above two children, may be admitted to this school, so that he could get away for a Beaver Hunt, and make some money.

As he really has no other place to send his children, and that two were already there, he was told to go on to Carcross, and interview the Principal, Mr Grant.

To this end the necessary papers were made out, and are herewith attached, with also some correspondence that has passed over the matter.

All of which, Sir, is humbly forwarded with the hope that this hard case will meet with your benevolent consideration, and that the action taken, ore correct authority had been received, will be excused on the grounds that great delay and some little expense would have been incurred, had that authority been first requested.

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith statement of expenditures with vouchers attached.

Regarding the refund to the Rev H.C.M. Grant for the return of two truant pupils I beg to report that these two boys ran away on Sunday morning, July 3rd. Following the usual custom the pupils were all sent into the school grounds after breakfast for fresh air and exercise, the two boys very calmly walked off and were not missed until the muster for service. A search for the boys was instantly started but no trace of them was obtained until Monday morning when they were reported as having arrived at the section house at Cowley on the railway some 32 miles from the school. While arranging for them to be put on the train about due from Whitehorse they overheard the plans that were being made over the telephone and again disappeared. A wire was then sent to the R.C.M.P. and the Rector of Whitehorse to keep on the look out for them, they were caught by a constable of the R.C.M.P. about five miles from Whitehorse and taken into the town and kept at the barracks until the arrival of the principal to escort them back to the school.

In the case of Chappie Sam, he was brought up from Carmacks by the Bishop of Yukon to Whitehorse to be examined by Dr Wride. This boy was certified as being unfit to enter the Carcross school therefore he was returned to his parents.

No accountable cheque having come to hand from the Department to meet these expenditures they were paid by me from personal funds.

Sir:-

I have the honor to enclose herewith application of George Sydney for admission to the Carcross Indian Residential School. George is a member of the Carcross band.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of dated August 5th, file No. 164-1-10, in reference to the statement of expenses recently made by me, with returned vouchers enclosed.

In reply I beg to say that I am forwarding herewith revised statements of expenditures made from personal funds on behalf of the Department. It is hoped that these will be found in good order.

Referring to the transportation charges of pupils going to and from the Carcross Indian Residential School I may say that the school now has the full complement of pupils in residence, the only travelling expenses which may possibly occur are, in cases of necessity, sending pupils to the Whitehorse hospital, we are hoping these may be as light as those of the past year. The principal has been notified of the Department's policy in regard to pupils travelling expenses.

I have the honor to enclose herewith the application of Jessie Williams of Atlin.B.C. for re-admission to the Carcross Indian Residential School.

Sir,

I beg to submit, herewith, the office file on the case of Lillian Mc Clusky - No 087 Carcross Indian Residential School, for your consideration and necessary instructions.

Rev.H.M.C. Grant Principal of the above school, with also myself have come to the conclusion that perhaps it would be better to release this Indian Girl from the school now, rather than allow her to learn more knowledge than will be of any use to her, in her native home.

The Mother's Family- the Paddy Wards of Atlin claim the girl, indian fashion, but the family is one of great trouble, and their girls of no use.

As the attached file will show, the Mother is now in S.E. Alaska, and is likely to stay there, and therefore out of the question as to the returning of Nellie to her.

The Father Billy Fann, really wants the girl, and will no doubt give her all the attention that is necessary, and has consistently requested that she be returned to his care.

The Step Father Mc Clusky is not interested in the affair at all, and is keeping away in the woods with his two boys.

Therefore may instructions be received to return Nelly to her Father Billy Fann, and if granted he has promised to fetch her from the school with his Dog-team next Fall.

I am.

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Harper Reed
Indian Agent.

OTTAWA.
Ottawa, September 1st, 1933.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo, with reference to Lillian McClusky. The June quarter return of the Carcross Indian Residential School shows that this girl is only eleven years of age and I note from your correspondence that you suggest that she return to her father and keep house for him. The Department is inclined to feel that it is hardly fair to this girl to require her to take over such duties at her age. It is felt that it would be in her best interests to remain in the Carcross School for another year or two. Even though she does not make rapid progress in classroom work, she would, no doubt, receive considerable domestic training which would be useful to her in later years. However, if you consider that she should be discharged at the present time, you may again write the Department.

The file which you forwarded is returned.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated September 1st in regard to the Indian Girl - Lillian Mc Clusky now at the Carcross Indian School, and who, it was thought could be returned to her people.

The matter has been gone into with Mr Grant the Principal of the Carcross School, and we agreed that perhaps in this case it would be best to return the girl to her people, as she was backward in her studies, and it was thought better to do that than allow her to learn so much that when she returned to her nomadic way of life she would not be an "outcast".

This girl was really sent to the school for protection, not on her ability for school work, and the life she will have to return to will be of the wildest, and were she to learn so much as to cause her to "look-down" on her own folk, they would turn around and wreck her life. She will not be keeping house for her father so much as helping around the camp, and generally growing up to the life she will have to live in the bush.

There is a case of a returned school girl, back from the Le Jack R.C. Mission of British Columbia, down at Liard Post, who has grown out of the ways of the wild bush, and her life at present is hardly worth living, she is looked down upon by her own folk. However she is making the best of the matter and perhaps after a while will fit into place. This routine has now stopped, and the mission at Mc Dames Creek is doing good school work, at the same time keeping the children in their own ways of life.

Therefore it is sincerely thought it would be better to allow Lillian to go home now than at a later date, as it would be better for her in the long run. She will suffer no hardships and shall be supplied such books etc as might be of help to her from this Office.

I am,

J.D. Sutherland, Esq.
Act. Supt Indian Education.

Sir:

Attached hereto you will find copy of a telegram it was felt advisable to send you today. We trust that this boy's immediate discharge will be looked upon favourably by the Department of Indian Affairs.

This boy's father, Mr. George Sidney of Carcross, recently returned home from the General Hospital at Whitehorse. The writer has been informed that his heart is in a bad shape and that for him to do any strenuous work would be going contrary to medical advice. The discharge of this pupil has been talked over with Corporal Blatta here who agrees with me that under the circumstances, seeing that his father has a trap line out and cannot attend to same, his immediate discharge is advisable. It is more than likely that if this boy is retained at school his parents will have to receive relief from the Department of Indian Affairs. With Pete home such should not be necessary.

As far as the school is concerned I may add that this boy's discharge from the school will be welcomed for during the past few months he has not been a good influence over his associates and has given us considerable trouble.

Dear Sir:

1. Richard Martin called at my office today and expressed a wish to have his two daughters, Jane and Alice, return home from the School this summer.

2. Mr. Martin stated his wife was in a poor state of health and unable to do much housework, which explained his wish to have his daughters return.

3. I believe Jane Martin is 16 years of age and Alice only 14 years. I suggested to Mr. Martin that it would be much better to leave Alice to continue her education and let Jane return home to help in the housework; however he stated that from letters he had received from them they did not want to be separated, and if one left the school the other would want to leave also, and the eldest girl would obtain domestic employment in Dawson and the youngest assist at home.

4. I informed Mr. Martin I would communicate with you and let him know your views on the matter; as he expressed a wish to have the girls come down river at the time Bishop Geddes came. Sir:

I believe that the Department of Indian Affairs grant diplomas to pupils of Indian Residential Schools who remain at school until they are 18 years of age and who during their time of residence have had a creditable record and who were regularly discharged. Such being the case I request that the following pupils be granted diplomas and have no hesitation in recommending them for same:

2. James Tizya - No. 69. This ex-pupil remained at the school until he was 18 years of age and was discharged in 1933. Since that time he has been regularly employed on the staff of the school and his work has given every satisfaction.

3. Fred Pelly - No. 55. This ex-pupil remained at the school until he was 18 years of age and was honourably discharged in 1924. Since that time he has been employed mainly on the staff of the school and has proved to be an efficient worker.

In connection with James Tizya I may say that application would have been made at the time of his discharge (1933) for his diploma if I had then been aware that such was granted by the Department of Indian Affairs. Barlow although maybe at that time it was not the practice of the Department of Indian Affairs to grant diplomas to graduating pupils.

Sir:

re:- Bessie Grace Simon and Mary Eva Simon, Applicants for admission to Carcross Residential School.

1. Attached hereto please find application for admission to the Carcross Residential School made on behalf of the above named two girls.

2. I cannot recommend that these girls be admitted to the school and my reason for so doing is on the grounds that these girls are not in a condition of health to warrant their admission.

3. It will be noted that Dr Nunn in his report of medical examination states that they are fit for admission, but states that there is an unhealthy family history in connection with both these girls.

4. From my personal knowledge of this family I would state that the father is suffering from tubercular disease and is in very poor condition, also that within the past three months two of the younger children of this family have died from tubercular disease, and that from my observation of these two candidates I am not satisfied that their health is such that they should go to the residential school and mix with the other pupils there.

5. Keeping in mind the result of an Indian girl, Alice Simple, having been sent from a family practically the same as the Simon's, to the school at Carcross and that she was only there for a few months when she had to be removed to the General Hospital at Whitehorse where she had to be kept for over a year, I am of the opinion that to send these two Simon's girls to the school would only be a cause of considerable expense to the Department in the very near future.
6. I might state that I had the opportunity to take this matter up with the Principal of the School, the Rev Mr Grant, when he was in Dawson recently, and he saw these girls and he is of the same opinion as myself that they, in view of the family history, are unsuitable to be admitted to the school.

7. I would ask that I be informed if you agree with me in regard to the unsuitability of these girls for admittance to the school.

Your obedient servant,

G. Binning, A/Supt.
Dept Indian Affairs.

Sir:

I beg to submit, hereunder, a Report covering the month of August 1936.

Upon my arrival in Carcross, Rev. Grant, in charge of the Indian Residential School, located there, turned back to my care the two Dease boys who return to their mother at Telegraph Creek. The two lads are fine examples of what is possible, if the right kind of Indians are selected for this expensive schooling. They were very much admired during the long journey home, by all who met them.

Reaching Skagway it was with much difficulty that passages were arranged abroad the U.S.A. S/ship Northwestern, to carry us to Wrangell.

Tourist traffic this year especially, has been very heavy and a Canadian or for that matter anybody, is not allowed to travel from one U.S.A. Port - to another, on a Canadian Boat. As is usual the American boats pick up freight at every point possible and we were aboard this boat for six full days. The two Indian lads took the opportunity, at each port of call, of speaking to all the Indian Curio workers about the quantity of moose hides to be had in the Cassiar, and it is hoped that their mother will reap a benefit from some future sales.

Harper Reed,

Sir,

1. Referring to the letter of the Chief, Training Division, dated September 1st 1937, I beg to state that I have taken this matter up with the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Carcross Y.T. and the following are the facts of the case.

2. In regard to the request made by John Semple, Indian of the Peel River tribe, but now residing at Moosehide Y.T., in which he asks that his son Alfred Semple be returned to him from the school at Carcross, the boy referred to is undoubtedly the pupil Alfred Semple, Register No 112, and whose name has appeared on the last twelve quarterly returns for the School.

3. It is noted that in the letter written by the father he states that the boy is 18 years old, this is not correct, if the father gave the correct age of the boy at the time the Application for Admission forms were prepared.

4. These forms were dated January 2nd 1934 and the age given at that time by the father was thirteen, so it would appear that the age of the boy now is 15½ years, not 18 years as stated by the father, and I am of the opinion that this is purely in keeping with the practice of the Indians in the Yukon when they want to get their children out of the school, the age they give is not in keeping with the age given at the time of admission, this is the cause of considerable trouble and I am of the opinion that the age given at admission is the one which should govern at all times.

5. In any event, according to the Indian Act, this boy is due for discharge in 1938, and I do not see any reason for his discharge before the finish of the present academic year, in the first place the father, John Semple, has been convicted for intoxication three times in the past two years and also has a conviction for assault registered against him in that time.

John Semple's wife has left him and is now living with another Indian, and for this family upheaval, he is, in my opinion, after hearing both of their stories, entirely to blame and under all the circumstance I do not consider him to be a fit person to have charge of the boy at the present time, he is well aware of my views in this matter, as I had already informed him that the boy could not be allowed out of the school until he had completed his full course and also that I expected to see an improvement in his, John Semple, conduct before the boy was entrusted to his care.

G. Binning, A/Supt.
Dept Indian Affairs.

Philip Phelan, Esq.
Chief, Training Division.
Dept Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of November 9th with reference to Alfred Semple, No. 112, of the Carcross Indian Residential School.

In view of the information contained in your letter, the Department is not prepared to approve the discharge of this boy from the Carcross School at the present time and you should so inform the father.

I have also noted the information that you give in the last paragraph of your letter. Before application is made for this boy's discharge next June, you should advise the Department if the father's conduct has improved. If not, it might be necessary to keep the boy in Carcross for a longer period. Of course, every endeavour should be made by the Principal to make his training as practical as possible.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I am in receipt of a request from the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Carcross, that one of the pupils Register No 112, Alfred Semple, be not discharged from the School this year.

There has already been correspondence in regard to this boy, your file 166-1-10, and the reason that the principal objects to his discharge is because during the past year this boy has been unruly, going to town without a pass and smoking all because he expects to be discharged this year. The Principal is of the opinion that if he is kept in school for another year that it will be an example to the rest of the older boys and let them see that they cannot disobey orders in their last year.

In my previous report regarding this lad, I spoke of the father, this man has been in the Blackstone country for the winter so that I cannot say whether there is any improvement in his behaviour or not, or whether he is yet fit to have charge of this lad.

The Principal also informs me that he has had a request from the parents of Register No 0115, Mabel Sidney, that this girl be kept in the school until she reaches the age of 18 years. This girl was not admitted to the school until the fall of 1935 and consequently has not had a great deal of schooling, this is the reason her parents wish her to remain at school for a longer period.

I would be pleased if you would notify me in regard to the wishes of the Department as to these two pupils.

Dear Sir:

During the past winter the staff and myself have had a great deal of trouble in dealing with and trying to make amenable to discipline the following children:

Register Number 096 - Ada Johns.
Register Number 125 - Arthur Dawson.
Register Number 0119 - Hilda Dawson.

After making every effort without any apparent success the staff and myself are convinced that in the interests of the other pupils and the school in general these children should be given their immediate discharge. The attached statement, signed by every member of the staff shows that they have given this matter careful consideration and are unanimous with regard to what should be done to remedy an unfortunate situation.

These three children can be put into the category of agitators and not only are they a disturbing influence amongst the other pupils but are causing a spirit of dissatisfaction amongst certain Indian families in the southern Yukon. I have it on good authority that not long ago Register No. 096 - Ada Johns - made the following statement to her father, Johnnie Johns of Carcross - "The floor sweepings are being fed to the children". Needless to say such a statement is absurd and entirely false but has done a great deal of harm. Mr. Johnnie Johns as a result
has been saying that he is going to take Ada out of the school because the floor sweepings are being fed to the children. A few years ago, shortly after this girl was admitted to school, her father, who is very conscious of the fact that he has more money than other Indians, wanted his daughter given special food which he said he was prepared to pay for. It was only with great difficulty that he was persuaded that such a course of action would not be wise and could not be followed in the school. He seemed to resent the fact that his daughter would not be accorded different treatment from the children of other poor Indians.

Last Fall two children were admitted to this school, Register Number 123 - Arthur Dawson and Register Number 0119 - Hilda Dawson. During the past winter Mr. Geo. Dawson of Whitehorse visited his children at the school and on his return to Whitehorse stated that he was going to take his children out of school because his children said "it is too strict, have to get up too early, work too hard, not enough to eat and have to eat dog rice." Naturally such an absurd statement which apparently Mr. Geo. Dawson believes and is propagating is creating a spirit of dissatisfaction amongst certain Indian families in and around Whitehorse.

Having these three dissatisfied children in the school is creating a spirit of dissatisfaction also amongst the other children and makes things very difficult for the staff. Both Mr. Johnnie Johns and Mr. Geo. Dawson are fairly well off for Indians and because they have money think that their children in the school should be treated differently from other children. Possibly in an effort to impress their financial status upon the other children in the school they are constantly sending their children expensive clothing and presents which is not a good thing and arouses quite a feeling of jealousy. As Mr. Johnnie Johns and Mr. Geo. Dawson are well able to provide for their children and very critical of our efforts I feel that it would be only a just thing for their places to be filled by children who haven't such 'wealthy' parents and who really need the food, clothing and attention the school provides.

Yours respectfully,

H.C.M. Grant,
Principal.
Dawson Y.T.

Sir:

Attached hereto please find a letter and petition signed by the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Carcross Y.T. and also signed by all members of the staff of the school.

In regard to the recommendations of the Principal as to the discharge of three pupils from the school, would state that I concur in this and would recommend to the Department that these three children should be discharged from the School immediately.

In regard to Register No. 96, Ada Johns, would state that the Principal has complained to me previously about this girl but it was agreed to try and see if she could not be made more amenable to discipline, but apparently this has been found impossible, would state that her father Johnnie Johns is a licensed guide in the Yukon and consequently is able to earn quite a little money by taking out hunting parties, he considers himself superior to the other Indians in the Carcross District.

I do not know Mr Geo Dawson or his circumstances but concur in the Principal's recommendation for the discharge of his children from the school.

Should you decide to uphold the Principal in this matter, would you please notify me by radiogram so that these children could be discharged at the earliest possible moment.

29th July 1938.

Dear Sir,

I beg to report that when paying Treaty to the Louchoux Band No.7 at Fort McPherson on the 7th instant an Indian by the name of Alfred Bonnetplume No.25 of the above mentioned Band made enquiries about his two girls in the Carcross Anglican School.

Apparently Bishop Sovereign recruited Bonnetplume's two daughters Jessie and Sarah in the year 1933, on a call he was making at Fort McPherson. According to the Indian the Bishop promised the discharge of the two girls in 1940 but nothing was said about the transportation of the two girls back to McPherson.

Bonnetplume would like to know next Treaty time (1938) what arrangements are going to be made either by the department or mission authorities for the return of his two daughters in 1940. If no arrangements are made it is his intention to start for Carcross in the fall of 1939, in order that he himself may bring his girls back in 1940.

This would appear to be an early enquiry but with the time it will take the department to communicate with Principal H.C.M.Grant of the Anglican Mission school, Carcross, and forward word to me a long time will have elapsed.

I would think and trust the department will see the way to relieve the Indian of the long trip and expense of getting his children. It would appear that when these Indian children are recruited for their schools and taken by them, that the onus of the return of the children should rest with the missions.

Awaiting the information requested.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

W.P.B.F.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Philip Phelan Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Canada.

Dear Sir:

Re 166 - 1 - 10.

This is in reply to your letter of the eight instant in connection with Dr. J.P. Harvey's report about the children of Alfred Bonnetplume - No. 25 - member of the Louchoux Band No. 7.

It would seem that this Indian did not give Dr. Harvey a true report regarding the admission of his children to this school. They were not recruited at Fort Macpherson by Bishop Sovereign. At the time their Application for Admission Papers were signed Alfred Bonnetplume was residing in Moosehide, a small Indian village a few miles out of Dawson, Y.T. This is verified by the signatures on their Applications for Admission. Alfred Bonnetplume's signature was witnessed by the Rev. C.H. Jenkins, then Missionary - in - Charge at Moosehide and The Rev. John Hawkeley then Indian Agent for the Yukon signed these papers. I was speaking to The Rt. Rev. W.A. Geddes, D.D., now bishop of the Yukon about this matter a few days ago and he stated that Bishop Sovereign was never in Fort Macpherson during the time he was Bishop of this Diocese.

Then with regard to the promise that Alfred Bonnetplume said was made to him by Bishop Sovereign that his children would be discharged in 1940
is one I feel can be questioned. I have no knowledge of such a promise being made and doubt very much whether Bishop Sovereign would speak on an issue which is clearly one for your Department to decide. The present Bishop of the Yukon assured me a few days ago that no Bishop has the authority to say how long an Indian child is to be in school, so I question very much whether Bishop Sovereign made the promise he is credited with making.

I have had a great deal of correspondence from Alfred Bonnetplume and his wife about these children. To put the matter mildly he is anything but consistent. On May 3rd 1937 he wrote me from Fort Macpherson stating that he only promised to leave his children here for five years. On July 24th 1937 he requested the Rev. Alex. Dewdney - Missionary at Fort Macpherson - to write to me about the discharge of his children. In this letter Mr. Dewdney credits Alfred Bonnetplume with the following statement:

"He says he didn't make any definite promise as to how long he would leave them but reserved the right to take them back when he wished."

To add to his inconsistency it may be said that these children were admitted to this school in the year 1933. According to Dr. Harvey's report Alfred Bonnetplume states that Bishop Sovereign promised the discharge of the two girls in 1940. This would make their residence in school extend over a period of seven years.

In dealing with all the correspondence, including a telegram, received from this Indian I have repeatedly told him that when he placed his children in school and signed the Application for Admission Papers he agreed to leave them here "under the Guardianship of the Principal for such a term as the Department of Indian Affairs may deem proper". He has also been advised that, according to the Indian Act, unless some very good reason for an early discharge was given to your Department, all
Indian children were required to remain in school until they were sixteen years of age. Working on this basis he was informed, that, according to the ages given on Admission, Jessie Bonnetplume would not be able to leave until 1941 and Sarah Bonnetplume until 1943. I told him that if he wished his two girls to leave at the same time the Department of Indian Affairs might agree to Jessie remaining here until she was eighteen years of age which would be in 1943 the year Sarah Bonnetplume reaches the age of 16 years. This plan commends itself to me, besides being in accordance with the Indian Act, by the fact that the Rev. Alex Dewdney in his letter to me of December 9th 1937 writes as follows:

"He (Alfred Bonnetplume) is not very well and has quite a large family to support."

As an alternative plan I would be quite prepared, if your Department agrees, to apply for their discharge in 1941 even though the younger of the two girls will then be only 14 years of age.

As to where these two girls be sent on discharge I would suggest that they be sent to the place they were recruited from, viz., Moosehide, Y.T. Alfred Bonnetplume could be advised in plenty of time so that he could be there to meet them. It would seem as if he at one time figured that they would be sent to Moosehide on discharge for on June 18th 1937 he wired me from Aklavik as follows:

"Please send my daughters Jessie and Sarah Bonnetplume to Moosehide in time for me to get them first boat next spring reply collect."

As I am bound to have further correspondence from this Indian I would be pleased to
advised which of the two plans commends itself to you. It seems only the humane thing to do to let both these girls go at the same time, that is, if they are to be sent to Moosehide, Y.T., for the journey from Fort Macpherson to Moosehide is a long one of approximately 500 miles.

As an afterthought, in view of the fact that there are many Applications for Admission to this school on hand, which cannot be considered for lack of accommodation, I must admit that the plan of letting both these girls go in 1941 is the one that commends itself to the writer more strongly than the one of keeping the older girl here until she is 18 years of age.

Yours respectfully,

H.C.M. Grant,
Principal.

Dear Sir,

Re your letter of Sept. 8, 1938, file 166-1-10. It would appear from Mr. Grant's letter that the Indian Bonnetplume is indeed inconsistent. It was while on the treaty trip and staying with Mr. Dewdney, the missioner at MacPherson, that the requests were made to me. There was no mention made at the time of Moosehide nor of his correspondence with the school.

With the facts before me, I think as you do that the two girls be kept until the end of June 1941 and then be returned to Moosehide Y.T. where their father can meet them.

If this is satisfactory to you, I will advise Bonnetplume through Mr. Dewdney, that he can meet his girls there at the above mentioned date.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, Your File 166-1-10, having reference to certain expenditures incurred in connection with the transportation of Indian children to and from the Carcross Indian Residential School, and also in connection with the purchase of school supplies and freight charges on school material, in connection with Indian Schools in the Yukon Territory.

Until recently any expenditures connected with the Carcross Indian Residential School, and the conduct of the Indian Day Schools in the Territory, were paid directly by the Department at Ottawa, the expenditures made through this Office being confined to the relief of sick and destitute Indians.

It would be much more satisfactory to me if the former arrangement were adhered to. I believe it would be much more satisfactory to this Office if directions re the payment of accounts were received directly from the Department, and not as you suggest through the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Carcross.

Yours truly,

G.A.T. Jeckell
Controller.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt of Welfare and Training,

Dear Sir:-

Re 166-1-10.

In reply to your letter of April 17th 1940 this is to advise that No. 001 Lily Johnson was given her discharge before the close of the quarter ending March 31st 1940. She became 16 years of age on March 28th.

On April 9th 1940 No. 0100 Hannah Smith was permitted to go home. Her age on the March quarterly return was given as 15½. This was an error and should have read 16½.

I gather from your letter that when a child reaches the age of 16 years it is necessary that an application be made to the Department for either his or her discharge or a recommendation that the child be kept in school for a longer period. The procedure followed here in the past has been to discharge all children who have reached the age of 16 years and who, in our opinion, should not be kept in school for
longer period, without making a formal application to the Department. In future, unless I hear from you to the contrary an application for discharge will be made in all cases.

Would you therefore please authorize the discharge of the following children all of which will or have reached the age of 16 years this year. The first four were listed in your letter to which this is an answer.

No. 089 Mary Davis,
No. 0104 - Esther Roberts
No. 0105 - Annie Roberts
No. 0112 - Rowena Baum,
No. 0108 - Jessie Williams
No. 099 - Alfredda Ellis
No. 107 - George Sidney
No. 108 - Wilfred Edwards
No. 125 - George Henry

Except in the cases of No. 099 - Alfredda Ellis, No. 107 - George Sidney and No. 108 - Wilfred Edwards, whose homes are in Carcross, these children who live quite a distance from here could not be discharged until navigation opens. This would be sometime in June. Such being the case it is felt advisable to keep them in school until the close of the present academic year. As No. 099 - Alfredda Ellis, No. 107 - George Sidney and No. 108 - Wilfred Edwards do not reach the age of 16 years until after the end of June I would recommend that they remain in school until June 30th 1940.

I regret that an error has been made in the ages of some of the children on the quarterly returns. In preparing these returns the ages of the children have been taken from the Classroom Register. These have been carefully checked with
those given on the Application for Admission and corrections that are necessary have been made. In closing I might add that occasionally the parents or guardian give the incorrect age when a child is admitted and a correction has to be made after the child has been in school a few years.

Yours truly,

H.C.M. Grant, Principal.

Dear Sir:

Re: George Henry - Indian Child -
Use of plane.

This in reply to your letter of June 29th, 1940.

On June 8th, 1940 Register No. 125 - George Henry - a pupil at this school, met with one of the worst accidents that I have seen in my ten years at this school. He was driving one of the school teams down a hill. The wagon wheel hit a stone and the rack, of heavy construction, came off the rear bulk. The horse became unmanageable and the boy fell off. The rear of the rack, which was dragging on the ground went over him and cut his head open from the left eye to almost the top of his head. The cut was very deep and exposed a considerable portion of his skull. There was quite a lot of bleeding. After consulting the school nurse the doctor was called. As soon as he saw the injury he said he would have to take the boy to hospital and give him a general anaesthetic before any stitching could be done. Whilst transporting the injured boy to the plane the doctor remarked that there was a possibility an hour after the accident severe haemorrhage might occur.

Apologizing for not reporting the details of this accident to you at an earlier date.

I remain,

Yours truly,

H.C.M. Grant, Principal.

Dear Sir:-

On October 7th 1938 - Re 166-1-10 -
you wrote me as follows:-

"With further reference to your letter of August 24th regarding
the children of Alfred Bonnetplume the Indian Agent, Dr. J.P.
Harvey, has written to the Department and states that he
considers it would be satisfactory to keep these girls until
1941 at which time they should be sent to Moosehide. The
Department approves of this arrangement on the understanding
that the father will be notified sufficiently ahead of time
to enable him to be at Moosehide when the girls arrive."

I have just received a letter from Alfred
Bonnetplume in which he states that he would like his girls
to be sent to Mayo, Yukon instead of to Moosehide. He plans to
be at Mayo on or about March 20th 1941. In connection with
this matter I beg to state as follows:-
1. If his children are to be at Mayo, Y.T. on the date specified it would be necessary for them to travel by 'plane from Whitehorse, Y.T. The cost of the 'plane trip for the two girls would be $100.00. The railway fare from Carcross to Whitehorse for the two girls would be $8.60. As the 'plane trip from Whitehorse to Dawson (Moosehide) would be $120.00 a saving in transportation would be effected in sending them to Mayo.

2. Apparently Alfred Bonnetplume intends to take his girls from Mayo to Fort Macpherson by dog-team. If the children had to wait here until navigation opens this would not be possible.

Requesting from you authority to send these girls by 'plane from Whitehorse to Mayo, Yukon next March,

I remain,

Yours truly,

H.C.M. Grant, Principal.
Ottawa,
July 29, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant regarding the children of Alfred Bonnetplume.

From information on our file it appears that this man is travelling around the country to a considerable extent and there does not appear to be any reason why, during the next six or seven months, he could not pay a visit to the Carcross School and take his children home without any expense to the Department. Our funds are so limited that it is impossible to consider allowing the amount that you mention would be required to send the two girls to Mayo.

At any time that he comes to the school the discharge of the girls may be granted.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant I am returning the account which you forwarded. Please prepare another account for the transportation of the child requiring hospitalization.

With regard to Harry Davis it is noted that he was discharged from the Carcross School last year. We can only consider payment of transportation home from a residential school when the pupil proceeds home immediately after his discharge. When over a year has elapsed since his discharge the question of paying transportation is a matter for the Welfare Branch to deal with and in consulting the officials of that Branch I am informed that owing to lack of funds it is not possible for them to consider paying transportation of able-bodied Indians. Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 25th ultimo, the following information will I trust explain why it was necessary on November 2nd, 1940, to have the White Pass and Yukon Route transport by plane from Carcross to Whitehorse, boy-pupil Robert Jackson.

1. On November 1st it was necessary to wire Dr. F.B. Roth in Whitehorse, as follows:
   "Feel advisable wire you school boy appears be quite ill difficulty in breathing pain left chest temperature during last twenty-four hours maximum one hundred and two minimum one hundred and one."

2. In about fifteen minutes the following reply was received:
   "Advise mustard poultice every four hours aspirin grain five same intervals Stop Will talk you phone nine A.M. tomorrow".

3. At 8:00 A.M. next morning, November 2nd, I advised Dr. Roth that there was no change in the patient's condition. If anything he appeared to be worse. Arrangements then had to be made for the doctor to see this pupil. The only way this could be done was for the Doctor to come from Whitehorse to Carcross by plane. On arrival he examined the boy and the diagnosis was pneumonia. The patient was taken by the doctor in the plane to Whitehorse for hospitalization.

4. As to the seriousness of this pupil's illness I may say that he has been in hospital over a month. I am pleased to be able to report though, that, according to the latest report, he is making satisfactory progress and expected back in residence in the course of a few days.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) H.C.M. Grant,
Principal.

Dear Sir:-

This is in reply to your letter of the 5th instant.

Not knowing when the birthdays of the majority of pupils are we followed the practice for some years of advancing the age of each pupil one year on the first of January. This meant that as we do not usually discharge pupils until June 30th the names of children who become 16 years of age in any given year were shown on two quarterly returns (Jan. - Mar. & Apr. - June) as being 16 years of age. On April 17th 1940 you wrote me as follows:-

"The March return shows the undermentioned pupils as being over 16 years of age:"
No. 089 Mary Davis
" 0104 Esther Roberts
" 0105 Annie Roberts
" 0112 Rowena Baum.

Please let me know if it is your intention to apply for the discharge of the abovementioned girls at the end of June next. If not, you should state definitely why you desire them to remain in the school after that date."

In order to avoid having children, aged as 16 years, shown on the quarterly returns for the first two quarters it was felt advisable to advance their ages one year on the 1st of August and have such shown on the quarterly return for the quarter ending September 30th.

This accounts for the fact, referring to your letter of the 5th instant, why the children listed are shown on the March return as being only 15 years old. In connection with this list may I point out that the birthdays of No. 0109 Marjorie Smith and No. 106 Frank Miller are not known. The birthday of No. 122 William Smith is given on his Application for Admission as being on March 21st and that of No. 0100 Pauline Ellis as being on December 27th.

On my report for the fiscal year ending March 31st 1941 the following children were shown as being eligible for discharge this year:

No. 106 Frank Miller
No. 108 Wilfred Edwards
No. 122 William Smith
No. 0100 Pauline Ellis
No. 0106 Jessie Bonnetplume
No. 0109 Marjorie Smith
No. 106 Wilfred Edwards was discharged on May 1st of this year. Authority for doing so was given in your letter of April 24th 1941.

I am rather perplexed to know what to do with No. 0106 Jessie Bonnetplume. There has been quite a bit of correspondence with your department over this girl and her sister No. 0107 Sarah. Your last letter, dated July 29th 1940, in connection with these pupils reads as follows:

"I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant regarding the children of Alfred Bonnetplume. From information on our file it appears that this man is travelling around the country to a considerable extent and there does not appear to be any reason why, during the next six or seven months, he could not pay a visit to the Carcross School and take his children home without any expense to the Department. Our funds are so limited that it is impossible to consider allowing the amount that you mention would be required to send the two girls to Mayo.

At any time that he comes to the school the discharge of the girls may be granted."

Up to the present Alfred Bonnetplume has not put in an appearance. I should imagine, in view of the expense in sending these children to Fort Macpherson, which journey from here would have to be either by aeroplane (charter trip) or Via Edmonton, you would wish, even though No. 0106 Jessie Bonnetplume will be 16 years of age this year, that she be kept here until her father or someone appointed by him calls for this girl and her sister.

Dear Sir:

This is in reply to your letter of the 30th ultimo regarding the Bonnetplume children. A day or so after your letter was received I had a letter from the Rev. Alex Dewdney of Fort McPherson, N.W.T., which reads in part as follows:

"Just a few lines about the Bonnetplume children. Their mother and father are very worried about them, because they do not really know where they are. We believe they are in Dawson and I have assured them over and over that either the mission or the government will see that the girls are looked after until they can get home but still it is natural for them to worry. We have been after the agent here to try to have them sent all the way home, but no results so far. Alfred is talking of going to Dawson after Christmas, but he should not really make the trip. Neither he nor his family are in the physical condition to stand it. They have lost several children with him in the last few years. Can you send us some definite information as to their whereabouts and who is looking after them? Also whether you know of any plan for their return here? I would be glad if you could send a wire as we have no more mails till December."

In reply to the above I sent Mr Dewdney the following wire which I feel will give you the information required:

"Jessie and Sarah still at Carcross School stop. In nineteen thirty seven Alfred wired me to send the girls to Moonshade near Dawson stop Department of Indian Affairs said this could be done in nineteen forty one stop Last year Alfred wrote me asking girls be sent to Mayo in March before navigation opened stop Department would not sanction cost plane trip from here to Mayo and advised that as Alfred appeared to be travelling around country to a considerable extent he should come to Carcross for children stop In May this year I informed Department Bonnetplume children still at school stop Reply stated that if father does not call for them within next six months Department was to be advised."

Yours truly,

Dear Alex:

A few weeks ago Jessie Bonnetplume stated that instead of going home in the near future or as soon as the Department of Indian Affairs or her parents make it possible for her to do so she would like to continue on with her schooling.

Jessie is a very promising pupil and from an

Sir:-

This is in reply to your letter of January 27th, 1943. The practice followed at this school in past years and one that met with the approval of the one who was Indian Agent at the time I was appointed Principal was to bring pupils into the school before their Applications for Admission were approved by the Department. The reason for this is that if a parent wished to place a child in school in the fall and the school management had to wait for official approval which sometimes takes several weeks, navigation by that time would be closed and the child in question would have to wait until the following year.

Last fall, working under this plan I recruited pupils numbered 134, 135, 137 and 0131. On October 1st I mailed you their Applications for Admissions. On October 14th you returned them to me as a condemnation of the buildings by the doctor raised the question of the possibility of the school being closed. The solution as you know to this problem was settled by the Department agreeing to a reduction in pupilage. Amongst those discharged were numbers 134, 135, 137 and 0131. Consequently their Applications for Admission were not sent to you again. As we had these children in residence for a certain length of time it was felt that even though their admission was not officially approved we should receive for them the usual per capita grant for the time they were in residence.

Albert Jackson, No. 136, whose death was reported on the September quarterly return, was, at the time of his disease, in the same category as numbers 134, 135, 137 and 0131. As he was not officially a pupil of the school it was thought the the procedure followed in the preparation of a Memorandum (Form 414) would not be necessary.

Yours truly,

"H.C.M. Grant," Principal.

Dawson, Y.T.,
June 25th, 1943.

I am enclosing herewith accounts covering transportation of the school children from the Residential School at Carcross to their respective homes at Carmacks, Selkirk, Mayo and Teslin. The Residential School closed on the 15th instant.

Boat transportation only was authorized but the cheapest method was used throughout; for instance it was cheaper to send David Charlie to Mayo by plane, the boat fare from Whitehorse to Mayo being $60.00 plus tax, while the plane fare was $50.00 plus tax.

It is to be noted that Reverend Mr. Grant used his own truck for transportation from Carcross to Whitehorse, and from Carcross to Teslin. Train transportation might have been used between Carcross and Whitehorse, but this would have cost more than the method used. The only way to get to Teslin from Carcross is by plane or highway.

J.E. Gibben,
Indian Agent.

This is an answer to your letter of the 15th instant with which was enclosed a copy of a letter you received from Mr. Phelan. In his letter it is noted that the Department is under the impression that the transportation, for which a charge of $160.00 has been made, was furnished by the 'School Truck'. Would you be so good as to inform Mr. Phelan that the school here does not own a truck or any other motor driven vehicle.

On more than one occasion during the past 14 years I have tried through our Head Office in Winnipeg and through your office to have the Department supply this school with a truck. No success has attended our efforts.

After the fire in 1939 the school occupied various houses in the village of Carcross and the farm situated on the old school site about two miles from Carcross was kept in operation. Four times a day the school boys who assisted with the farm work had to be transported from Carcross Village to the farm and under such circumstances a truck was a necessity. Consequently out of personal funds I purchased a new Ford V8 One Ton Truck which cost me in the neighbourhood of $1500.00.

During the past five years this truck has been used almost entirely for the benefit of the Indians and for most of this service no charge has been made. In the winter of 1942-43 it was necessary on several occasions to transport sick Indians from here to the Whitehorse Hospital and for each of these trips the Department paid me $20.00. To give you some idea of the extent of the service rendered to the Indian School here and to the Carcross Indians during this five year period I may say that my truck has covered over 35,000 miles. Almost every day now this vehicle is used in the school yard hauling wood to the various buildings and when not so engaged used to haul supplies, etc., from the Carcross Station to the school. For such services I am not receiving any remuneration.

As you know there have been times in the past when the railway has been out of commission on account of slides, etc., and there are days when no trains are scheduled to run. On such occasions if a child or a Carcross Indian is seriously ill the only other alternative to a car or truck to get such person to hospital is to charter a plane and the cost of such service is greatly in excess of $20.00. In view of this there have been occasions when my car and truck have saved the Department a considerable sum of money.

In view of the facts stated above it would be appreciated if you would ask the Department to reconsider the payment of the account for $160.00 and regard favourable other accounts which were mailed to you at a later date.

Yours truly,

H. C. M. Grant (Sgd)
Ven. H.C.M. Grant

Ottawa,
December 8, 1944.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

We have received several accounts recently from Reverend H.C.M. Grant, Principal of the Carcross School, for transportation of pupils and transportation of equipment for the school by truck. We were under the impression that the truck was owned by the M.S.C.C. and, as it is customary for residential schools to truck supplies and transport children in their own vehicles without cost to the Department, payment of these accounts has been refused.

Information to the above effect was sent to Reverend Mr. Grant and in reply he states that the school does not own a truck but that the truck being used was purchased by him from his own funds and since the time of the purchase he has had it operated for the school.

We wish to be fair in our treatment of any school, but it is unusual for the Principal to personally own a truck and then set his own rate for its use. For instance, the accounts submitted indicate that he expects 20¢ a mile for its use. I realize that operation is more expensive in the Yukon than in the more settled parts of Canada, but at the same time the rate requested by the Principal appears to us to be excessive. We would like to reach some basis equitable to all parties concerned and on the suggestion of Mr. Hoey I am submitting the matter to you and would appreciate having your views.

Yours truly,

Rev. H.A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission,
M. S. C. C.,
164 Alexander Ave. East,

December 15 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Transportation at Carcross.

I have to acknowledge your 166-1-10 of December 8, in regard to accounts for transportation by truck submitted by Principal Grant of the above school.

We have carefully noted what you say and have at once written to our Principal to ask further information about this matter. I may say that this is the first information we have received that a truck was being used at the school. We endeavoured for some time to secure such a vehicle, together with other items of equipment, from the American camp near Carcross. To the best of my knowledge this was not possible, and I know that there are no horses at the school, and it has undoubtedly been necessary to make some arrangement to bring supplies from the village some miles away. I shall write again as soon as we hear from Mr. Grant.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Department of Mines and Resources,

Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter no. 166-1-10 of the 8th of December 1944. We are now in receipt of further information from the Principal of our Carcross school re. use of truck for transportation of supplies and pupils and beg to submit the following explanation.

Mr. Grant appears to have been under the impression that as his local Indian agent forwarded the accounts to your Department, he certified them and thereby gave his approval to the rates inserted. Conditions since the destruction of the school by fire, have been most difficult. The necessity for housing pupils and staff in more than one building, making adequate arrangements for feeding them and the unforeseen arrival of strange troops caused many complications which made the task of administration by the Principal an unenviable one.

The uncertainty as to whether the school should be rebuilt on the former site, transferred to Dawson or temporarily suspended were questions which required serious consideration. As you will remember there was at one time a suggestion that the school should be reopened at Dawson, and that another principal might be appointed to replace Mr. Grant who would assume more responsible Missionary duties under the Bishop. These suggestions were however eventually discarded and it was decided to rebuild the Chootla School on its former site with Mr. Grant remaining as principal. It was assumed by the Commission that all these questions would be considered by the Bishop in consultation with Mr. Grant and that he also would be advised to the necessity of using Mr. Grant's truck for transportation purpose along the new highway.

In view of all these involved and difficult circumstances the Commission would greatly appreciate your most generous consideration of all these points and submit their views for your decision.

Yours faithfully,

Assistant Secretary-Treasurer.

RMH.
