Maggie Chitzi is an Indian woman in the Old Crow district who is separated from her husband. The latter is presently living at Macpherson, N.W.T. Mrs. Chitzi has three children: Lily, Margaret, and Eileen. I do not know the exact ages of these three children, but the youngest is under seven, and the other two are between seven and twelve years of age, I understand.

Bishop W. A. Geddes approached the writer this morning with the request that authorization be obtained for the admission of the two younger children to the Carcross Residential School. Apparently the mother is hard put to support these children and has indicated her desire to have them looked after in this way.

Reverend Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Ellis, Missionaries at Old Crow, are coming out this summer by the first boat, which, at the present time, is the only boat which is definitely scheduled to go to Fort Yukon. It was thought that they could bring the Chitzi children with them, and give them safe conduct right to Carcross. This would mean that the children would reach there about the first of July. The full term does not start until September, but there is no other boat connection unless the last White Pass trip in September goes through to Fort Yukon. If the children waited for this boat, they would have to come unattended, and would be at least a month late for the school opening.

Will the Department authorize the admission of these two Chitzi children into the Carcross Residential School (assuming that applications in proper form will be submitted) and also authorize boat transportation for them in manner indicated from Fort Yukon, Alaska, to Whitehorse?

J. E. Gibben,
Indian Agent.
Dawson, V. T.,

Dear Sir;

I understand that little orphan girl May, illegitimate daughter of deceased Mary Louis of the Lansing Creek Band, in Mayo, is being sent for schooling to the Anglican School of Carcross,Y.T.

I beg to call the attention of the Officials of the Branch on the following facts concerning the girl:

1.-Little Orphan May is a catholic Indian child, born of a Catholic Indian mother, and baptized by the catholic missionary in Mayo.

2.-After the death of her mother shortly after her birth, she was adopted by the catholic indian band of Lansing Creek, to which Mary Louis belonged; then, she was partly supported by her presumed white father, Mike Tomoff, who later on was married before me to another Catholic Indian woman, Layza Lightning, who is herself a catholic of the same Lansing Creek Band.

3.-After the death of Mike Tomoff, which occurred some time last fall, I received a letter from Father J.Plaine O.M.I., the catholic missionary in charge at Mayo, stating that Layza Tomoff, wife of deceased Mike Tomoff, was not only willing but anxious to keep with her little orphan May, but that certain people in town insisted that "this bright little girl" be sent to a school outside of Mayo.

4.-Actually little May has just arrived by plane from Mayo, and is in the local hospital in Whitehorse for treatment previous to her being sent to the Anglican School at Carcross.

I kindly ask you to investigate, near the proper authority who have arranged with the Branch for the transfer of the girl to Carcross, why she is being sent there against all regulations of the Indian Act regarding such matters.

Personally, I do not see any urgent necessity to take this little girl away from Layza Tomoff and the other members of her band, who are well to do and well able to look after her, at any rate much better than the Anglican School of Carcross, which does not even have a teacher on their staff since last September.

If, however, for some urgent reason unknown to me, little May has to be taken away from the band and sent to an Indian Boarding School, I insist, in the name of the rights granted to us by the Indian Act, that arrangements be made by the Branch for her transfer to one of our Catholic Boarding Schools, as soon as she leaves the local hospital. She could easily be sent, by the local bus, to the care of the Sisters at Fort Saint John Hospital, wherefrom the local Indian agent could arrange to have her accompanied either to Grouard or to Joussard Residential Schools.

Yours sincerely,

J.L.Coudert O.M.I., Vicar apost.of Whitehorse
Ottawa, January 7, 1946.

Dear Sir:

It has been brought to our attention that the orphan girl May, illegitimate daughter of deceased Mary Louis of the Lansing Creek Band, in Mayo, is at present in the local hospital at Whitehorse, Yukon, and that it is intended to later place her in the Carcross School.

Our correspondent supplies the following information regarding this girl:

"Little orphan May is a Catholic Indian child, born of a Catholic Indian mother, and baptized by the Catholic Missionary in Mayo.

"After the death of her mother, shortly after her birth, she was adopted by the Catholic Indian Band of Lansing Creek, to which Mary Louis belonged; then she was partly supported by her presumed white father, Mike Tomoff, who later on was married before me to another Catholic Indian woman, Layza Lightning, who is herself a Catholic of the same Lansing Creek Band.

"After the death of Mike Tomoff, which occurred some time last Fall, I received a letter from Father J. Plaine, O.M.I., the Catholic Missionary in charge at Mayo, stating that Layza Tomoff, wife of deceased Mike Tomoff, was not only willing but anxious to keep with her little orphan May, but that certain people in town insisted that 'this little girl' be sent to a school outside of Mayo."

From the above information, it is evident that
this girl is not eligible for admission to the Carcross Residential School, and in this connection I would refer you to Subsection 2 of Section 10 of the Indian Act.

Please let me know when this girl expects to leave the hospital, so that arrangements can be made to have her placed in either the Grouard or Joussard Residential School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

Referring to our conversation of last May and to my letter of June 22nd to the Director of the Branch regarding the urgent need of a Catholic Residential School in the Yukon or close to the Yukon border, I beg to call your attention to the fact that recently more and more catholic children are being admitted to the Anglican School at Carcross.

As I remarked to you recently such an abnormal situation will not be able to be remedied unless the Government grants to our Catholic Indians the Residential School they are entitled to in the Yukon.

I already sent you a written statement from Mrs. Billy Johnson (Martha Sam) protesting against the fact that she is obliged to send her children to the Anglican School of Carcross, but she had no alternative and under the present circumstances I had to allow her to do so against all church regulations; this is the case also for the children of Bill Hall, those of Dick Bean Charley and several others, who have begged me time and again for the past five years to open up a Boarding School for Catholic Indian Children in the Yukon and Northern B.C.

For your information and in order that you may check with the School Forms of Admission to said school, I am herewith sending to you some of the Baptism Certificates found in our local Registers. According to the testimonies of Mrs. Billy Johnson and Mr. Bill Hall all their children would have been baptized in the Catholic Church but I was unable to trace the records previous to my time.

Hoping that the above information will prove valuable to the Officials of the Branch and convince them of the urgency of our request for an Indian Boarding School in or near Teslin,

I remain,

Dear Mr.Phelan;

Re: Catholic Children in the Anglican Boarding School of Carcross,Y.T.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated January the 14th regarding some of our Catholic Indian Children admitted in the Anglican Boarding School at Carcross,Y.T.

In this connection,I beg to call your attention to the exact purpose of my letter of Dec.31st ultimo,in sending you the Baptism Certificates of some of the children admitted in the Carcross School.

In so doing I did not intend to have said children removed at once from said school,because,as I pointed out,those children are there by the authority of their parents and with my own permission,since they have no other alternative under the present circumstances,our catholic boarding schools being located thousands of miles away from the Yukon and being actually crowded to their full capacity.

The purpose of my communication of Dec.31,if you read it carefully,was evidently twofold,and if you kindly refer to it again,you will see it very clearly,viz.

1.-The first purpose was to corroborate our conversation of last May and my letter of June 22nd to the Director of the Branch regarding the urgent need of a Catholic Residential School in or near the Yukon.

2.-The second purpose of my letter is found in the fourth paragraph where I stated that I send you those Baptism Certificates"for your own information and in order that you might check with the School Forms of Admission in the Carcross School.

May I add now some explanation concerning the cases brought to your attention ..

a.-Catherine Johnson.-Catherine Johnson is the same as Kathleen Johnson;Kathleen is the Irish translation for Catherine,and must have been substituted either by the Indian Agent or the Principal of the School who are ignorant of the real name of the girl;but our registers are clear on that score and bear the name"Catherine".-Moreover I am positiv that Billy Johnson and Martha Sam did not have twins on that same day of March 17th,1937,of whom,Would have been baptized under the name of Kathleen in the Anglican church,and another one under the name of Catherine in the Catholic Church.-I know the family well and they are all catholics;I even
have stated previously, in my report of June 22nd to the Director of the Branch, that it was under protest that said family was sending their two children Gracie and Catherine (or Kathleen) to the Carcross School; the mother sent, along with my letter of June 22nd, a duly signed protest stating that "they were Catholics and would like to have their children sent to a Catholic School in the North, but because there was no Catholic School in the North, they had to send their children to the Anglican School."

That is the reason why, pending the time we shall have our own Catholic Boarding School in the North, I allowed them to do so.

The fact, therefore, that Kathleen or Catherine is registered on her form of admission as belonging to the Church of England is an evident deceit on the part of the authorities of the School at Carcross; Mr. Grant, the Principal, knows perfectly well that said Kathleen is a Catholic.

I may add that Gracie Johnson, her older sister, born of Billy Johnson and Martha Sam on June 20, 1932, is also in the Carcross Anglican School and her case was brought to the attention of the Branch at the same time as Kathleen's case, in my letter of June 22nd ultimo.

b.-Bill Hall's children.-I also wish to state that Bill Hall has asked me times and again for the past five years to have a Catholic Boarding School opened in the North, because he did not want to send his children to the Anglican School of Carcross; Bill Hall is a Catholic and has always insisted to have all his children baptized and brought up Catholic.-Owing to the unfair delay of the Branch to allow us to open up a Catholic Boarding School in Teslin, I had to allow Bill Hall to put his children in the Anglican School.

According to the testimony of our local missionary in Carcross, three of Bill Hall's children were at Carcross School last year, and I reported also their case to the Director of the Branch in the same letter referred above, viz., John Douglas, Teddy John and Isabella. The Baptism records of John Douglas and Isabella, however, being in the Register of Atlin, and having no missionary resident in Atlin at present, I was unable to secure the Certificates of Baptism for John Douglas and Isabella; Teddy John was baptised in the local hospital in Whitehorse and I had no difficulty in finding his record.

The case of those children being identical as that of Billy Johnson's children, I think that they should be allowed to stay in the Carcross School until the Branch provides a Catholic Boarding School for them in the North. The parents are justly reluctant to have their children sent out thousands of miles away for schooling; moreover, our Catholic Boarding Schools of Alberta and B.C. being actually filled up to their full quota, I do not feel inclined to ask either Bishop Langlois or Bishop Jordan to keep our children of the North free of charge in their already crowded school, unless the Branch makes a special provision for them.

c.-Margaret and Jacky Charley.-The same applies to Margaret and Jacky Charley, unless the parents are willing to send their children to one of our Catholic Boarding Schools "outside", and the Branch arranges for their support.
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

d.-Orphan May Tomoff's case.-In the case of orphan May Tomoff's case brought to your attention on January 23, conditions are very different, because the said child is altogether an orphan, and as such comes entirely under the responsibility of the Branch.- The Branch should see, therefore, in her case that subsection 2 of Section 10 of the Act be strictly observed, and that such a child be sent to a Catholic Institution; even if our Catholic Boarding Schools of Alberta and B.C. have already their full quota of boarders, it is the duty of the Branch to provide for the support of such a child and see that the necessary grant be given to the School willing to accept her.

I suggested Grouard School and already wrote to the Principal to announce the coming of May Tomoff, since some 18 children of the Vicariate of Whitehorse are already staying there, and means of communication between the Yukon and the Grouard School are very easy over the Alaska Highway.

Hoping that those lengthy explanations will clarify all the cases brought recently to your attention, I count on the spirit of fairness of the Officials of the Branch to see that a Catholic Boarding School be granted without any further delay to the Catholic Indians of our Vicariate in the vicinity of Teslin.

Yours sincerely in Christ

Dear Sir:-

Re Margaret CHARLIE.

This is a reply to your letter of the 15th instant.

On October 16th 1922 the Deputy Superintendent General wrote the General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada a letter which reads in part as follows:

"The opinion of the Department of Justice is that a Protestant child is one born of Protestant parents, or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Protestant school, or a school conducted under Protestant auspices. A Roman Catholic child is one born of Catholic parents or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Roman Catholic school, or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices. In other words, the father has a right to direct and regulate the religious faith in which his child should be brought up, and his wishes must be regarded unless there is some strong reason for disregarding them.

"In accordance with this view, if a Protestant parent wishes his child placed in a Roman Catholic school and brought up in the Roman Catholic religion, or a Roman Catholic parent his child in a Protestant school and brought up in the Protestant religion, he may do so, but for the protection of the Department, we demand in such cases an affidavit to that effect by the father. Such affidavit must be made before a justice of the peace, Indian Agent, or other person authorized to take affidavits, and the person who takes such affidavits must certify that the statements set forth in the affidavit were read over or interpreted and explained to the deponent who thoroughly understood the same. In cases of bona fide adoption, the religion and wishes of the foster father will be recognized by the Department."

In view of the above ruling it would seem that if Dick Bean Charlie, an ex-pupil of this school and the father of Margaret CHARLIE, is willing to take the necessary affidavit it would be in order for his children to be admitted to this school. Please advise on this point.
It is noted in your letter that no mention is made of this girl's brother, Jackie Charlie, who is also in residence here. I presume that whatever course of action is followed with regard to Margaret would apply equally to her brother.

Yours truly,

H. C. M. Grant (Sgd.)

.....With regard to the
With regard to the last four mentioned children, these are really in destitute circumstances, and it is suggested that the Department be responsible for all transportation costs from Old Crow to Carcross.

As a matter of interest, I would point out the predominance of Biblical Christian names in these Indians. I am advised that some years ago Archdeacon McDonald prepared a translation of the Bible into the Old Crow Indian dialect, and the Indians of that area have a better than average acquaintance with Scripture. When the child Phares was brought for Baptism, the Mounted Police and the officiating clergyman were under the impression that the child was to be called "Paris" and endeavoured to dissuade the parents in the matter of their choice of names. The father, however, was quite definite in the matter, and produced his well-thumbed copy of Scriptural translation to indicate that the name Phares had been taken therefrom. I regret that I am not able to quote chapter and verse.

It would be appreciated if the Department would let me have a decision in this matter as soon as possible, as there are only two more boat connections with Old Crow, and arrangements will have to be made without delay.

Further to my letter of 15th instant re opening of Day School at Whitehorse, and particularly with regard to second paragraph dealing with children taken away from Carcross Residential School.

I have interviewed Archdeacon H.C.M. Grant, Principal of the Carcross Residential School who informs me that the following children have been taken away by their parents: Lena Sam, Russell Sam, and Agnes Jackson. Rev. Grant stated that he was in full accord with their leaving, as for many years it has been a source of trouble when parents called for their children from Whitehorse, and did not return them after the holidays.

The following children have also been taken away from Carcross: Grace, Douglas and Harry Smarch of Teslin. Vera Takamatsu of Little Atlin. Grace Smarch was sick at the time, and there is reasonable excuse for her being in the care of her parents. As to the other, Rev. Grant states they are now out of school without permission. I am communicating with the Family Allowances to recommend that allowances remain suspended.

In the meantime I am endeavoring to get several children from the more inaccessible areas to take the places of those who have left. Does permission from your Department have to be applied for before any children are sent to Carcross Residential School?

R.J. Meek
(R.J. Meek)

Ottawa, February 4th, 1947.

R.J. Meek, Indian Agent, Whitehorse, Y.T.

We have your letter of the 17th inst., with reference to several children who have left the Carcross Residential School.

The discharge of Lena Sam, Russell Sam and Agnes Jackson is approved.

As the principal of the Carcross School, Mr. Grant, states that Grace, Douglas and Harry Smarch and Vera Takamatsu were not given permission to remain away from school, every effort should be made to have them returned to the Carcross School at an early date.

It is usual to have the Department's approval before children are admitted to Indian Residential Schools. However, in isolated places we realize that this is sometimes difficult and you may find it necessary to place children in Carcross School before receiving formal permission from the Department. In all such cases you should make certain that they are eligible for admission.

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, February 26th, 1947.

Mr. R.J. Meek, Indian Agent,
Whitehorse, Y.T.

We have your letter regarding the proposed admission of Jimmy Drugan and Evelyn McGunday to the Carcross Indian Residential School. It is noted that the application form states that Evelyn is a Catholic. Under Section 10 (2), of the Indian Act, this girl is not eligible for admission to the Carcross School. Evidently both children have already entered the school.

If you feel satisfied that these children should be recognized as Indians we are prepared to approve the admission of Jimmy Drugan to the Carcross School but for the reasons stated above, we cannot approve the admission of Evelyn McGunday to this school.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, March 10th, 1947.

Mr. R.J. Meek, Indian Agent,
Whitehorse, N.T.

We have your letter of the first instant with reference to the discharge of Lawrence Sam from the Carcross Residential School. It is noted that this boy will be sixteen years of age on May 21st.

It has never been our practice to approve discharges immediately a pupil reaches sixteen. It has always been understood that they should continue in the school in which they are in residence until the close of the academic year. Consequently, Lawrence Sam should remain at Carcross until the end of June, 1947, on which date his discharge from the school is approved.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

On Saturday, March 8th, I visited the home of Vera Takamatsu, in company with R.C.M.P. patrol, to Little Atlin, some 25 miles from Carcross, and about 40 miles from Whitehorse. Vera Takamatsu is living with her mother, an Indian, who was formerly married to a Japanese. Mr. Takamatsu is now dead, and the widow is living with a white man named Matthews.

Mr. Matthews is looking after all the children of Mrs. Takamatsu, and wishes to have the children regarded as white. He does not wish the girl Vera to return to Carcross Residential School, but wishes to move the family to Whitehorse and enter her in the Whitehorse Public School. None of the children of Mrs. Takamatsu are registered at this office as receiving Family Allowances, and I infer that they are regarded as of white status.

Archdeacon H.C.M. Grant writes in part as follows: "With regard to Vera Takamatsu and the Smarch children I am not at all anxious to have them back. The non-return of Vera Takamatsu will not deprive her of a schooling for I understand that her mother Mrs. Jessie Takamatsu, and the man who is living with (Mr. Matthews) are now residing in Whitehorse. No doubt a place for this girl could be had in the Rev. H.I. Lee's School."

It would appear to the best interest of all to have Vera Takamatsu officially discharged from Carcross Indian Residential School.

Dear Sir:

This is a reply to your letter of the 19th instant regarding Jimmy Drugan and Evelyn McGundy.

With regard to the eligibility of Evelyn McGundy's admission to this school I think it could be covered by the following ruling, such ruling being embodied in a letter the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs wrote to the General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada on October 16th, 1922:

"The opinion of the Department of Justice is that a Protestant child is one born of Protestant parents, or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Protestant school, or a school conducted under Protestant auspices. A Roman Catholic child is one born of Catholic parents or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Roman Catholic school, or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices. In other words, the father has a right to direct and regulate the religious faith in which his child should be brought up, and his wishes must be regarded unless there is some strong reason for disregarding them.

"In accordance with this view, if a Protestant parent wishes his child placed in a Roman Catholic school and brought up in the Roman Catholic religion, or a Roman Catholic parent his child in a protestant school and brought up in the Protestant religion, he may do so, but for the protection of the Department, we demand in such cases an affidavit to that effect by the father. Such affidavit must be made before a Justice of the Peace, Indian Agent, or other person authorized to take affidavits, and the person who takes such affidavits must certify that the statements set forth in the affidavit were read over or interpreted and explained to the deponent who thoroughly understood the same. In cases of bona fide adoption, the religion and wishes of the foster father will be recognized by the Department."

In view of the above I could, if the Department so desires, write to the mother (Mrs. Pat Henry, who is now living in the U.S.A.),
and get her to mail me the affidavit referred to above.

In dealing with this case I feel it is worth noting that Mrs. Pat Henry is a Protestant or was when she was a pupil of this school. She was then known as Doolah McGundy. As Evelyn is illegitimate, I presume that the religious faith of the father would not determine the religious faith of the child.

Yours very truly,

(signed) H.C.M. Grant.
Archdeacon. Principal Carcross School.

Early in July I received a letter from L.H. Phinney, Stipendiary Magistrate, Dawson, Y.T., concerning Albert James Joe, a pupil of Carcross Residential School. It appears that the father of the boy, Tanana Joe, of Dawson, an elderly man of about 73 or 74 years, makes his living by cutting logs and rafting them downstream to Dawson. With advancing years he is not now capable of handling a raft of logs, and requested Mr. Phinney to make representations to have Albert returned to Dawson.

Not knowing the custom in this Agency, I communicated with Archdeacon H.C.M. Grant, Principal of Carcross Residential School. He replied that it has been the custom in the past for children from the northern Yukon to remain at the school all summer. I thereupon replied to Mr. Phinney that it could be assumed that Albert would not be returning to Dawson for the summer.

Albert Joe is 14½ years, there is no doubt he would be a great assistance to his aging father. In a conversation with Mr. Phinney today he states that there is now a school at Moosehide to which Albert may attend. It may also be a case, if Tanana Joe receives no assistance in his work, for him and his wife to seek indigent rations. Mr. Phinney who is conversant with the case, recommends that consideration be given to having Albert returned to his parents.

May this application for discharge of Albert Joe receive your earliest attention. In view of the above information I would recommend that discharge be granted.

R.J. Meek
(R.J. Meek)
Indian Agent.
Copy sent to Principal of Carcross.

Ottawa, August 27, 1947.

Mr. R.J. Meek, Indian Agent, Whitehorse, Yukon.

It is hoped that Albert may continue his studies at Moosehide as mentioned in your letter.

Chief, Training Division.

On August 17th it was reported to me by Mr. Grant, Carcross Residential School, that two Indian pupils, Billy Peter Johnnie, age 15, and Peter Isaac, age 12, had left the school the previous day and had not returned. It was thought that they had run away and were endeavoring to return to their parents. Billy Johnnie's home being at Dawson, and Peter Isaac's quite a number of miles up the Felly River.

I immediately informed the police and several other people who might see these boys. On August 20th it was reported that these two boys were down the Yukon River at the south end of Lake LaBerge, endeavoring to float downstream on a raft. The Lake and river are much too dangerous for youngsters.

Rev. J. Ellice was in Whitehorse at the time, he is the recently appointed Principal of the Carcross Indian Residential School. I conferred with him and it was decided to let Billy Johnnie return to Dawson, he being a big boy and becoming a bit troublesome at the school; I understand he ran away once before. We further decided that Peter Isaac should be returned to the school. I contacted a Mr. G.W. Grady who was going downstream by outboard motor and gave him letters of authority to the purser on the boats to take these boys to their respective destinations. I also arranged for transportation at the head office of the B.Y.N. Co., Whitehorse.

On August 25th Peter Isaac returned to Whitehorse, I took him to the train for Carcross the following day, and he was returned to the school. Billy Peter Johnnie returned to Dawson where he will be able to attend the Moosehide Day School.

(R.J. Meek)
Indian Agent.

On Sunday, September 14th, Freddie Johnston, Indian of Teslin came to this office regarding his daughter Cecilia, born October 20th, 1939. He wished to place her in Carcross School, a residential school under the auspices of the Church of England. In fact he had already taken her to the school and at the present date she is still there.

From the information given me by Johnston, there seemed no reason to doubt the acceptance of Cecilia Johnston. Several days later, Rev. J. Ellis, Principal of Carcross School, brought in a form application for Admission, for Cecilia, denoting Freddie Johnston the father, and Lena Johnston (deceased) the mother. Cecilia's religion was given as Roman Catholic. Rev. Ellis had questioned the father on this point who claimed he was formerly a member of the R.C. church but now wished to return to his original belief, as a member of the C. of E.

On the advice of Archdeacon H.C.M. Grant, former Principal of the School, who was familiar with the case, Cecilia's religion was noted as Roman Catholic. I took up the matter with Bishop Coudert, O.M.I., Whitehorse, who stated that Freddie Johnston's status within the Roman Catholic church was "a Roman Catholic in bad standing". He stated he would object on principle to Cecilia's admittance to Carcross School.

At the present time it appears Johnston is a member of the Church of England, he has one child, Isaac, at Grouard Residential School. He stated to me he would not send Cecilia to an R.C. School, as he is not a member of the Church.

In the meantime Cecilia attends school. Rev. Ellis wishes to know if he is in order in maintaining the child there.

(R.J. Meek)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 30, 1947.

Mr. R. J. Meek, Indian Agent,
Whitehorse, Y. T.

We have your letter of the 21st instant with reference to Cecilia Johnston.

You should point out to the Principal of the Carcross School that children whose religious status is doubtful must not be admitted to the school until all facts are placed before the Department and our decision has been given.

If Freddie Johnston wishes his girl enrolled at the Carcross School, it will be necessary for him to forward a statutory declaration indicating that he is not now recognized as a Roman Catholic.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I attach hereto Indian Residential School Quarterly Return for the Carcross Residential School for the Quarter ending September 30th, 1947. Please note that Elizabeth Kodwat 0148, Jackie Kodwat 176, Arthur Kodwat 153, and Fred Kodwat 164, have not returned to Carcross School for the Quarter.

The Kodwat family (including the Charlies who are related) are the problem family of Whitehorse. During the latter part of August a drunken fight at the Kodwat home put the mother in hospital and Dick Bean Charlie, her brother-in-law in jail. As there was no one to look after these children Rev. H.I. Lee placed them in a dormitory he had prepared for a residential school in Whitehorse. They have been continuously maintained by Rev. Lee. Another sister, Annie Kodwat, who has been maintained by a half-breed family named D. Hume, of Champagne, requested that Annie be placed at Rev. Lee's school along with her other brothers and sisters.

The matter has been taken up with Rev. Ellis and Rev. Lee, they are both anxious to do whatever would be in the best interests of the children. In a recent inspection of Carcross School I received the impression that the accommodation is now at capacity. I would suggest the best solution would be the official discharge of the Kodwat children from Carcross School, and their maintenance at the Whitehorse Day School.

(R.J. Meek)
Indian Agent.
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, December 1st, 1947.

Mr. R.J. Meek, Indian Agent,
Whitehorse, Y.T.

We have your letter of the 10th ultimo with reference to the Kodwat children.

We presume from your letter that these children were allowed out on holidays and did not return on the expiration of their leave. We feel that in order to maintain proper discipline the children should be returned to the Carcross School at the earliest possible date provided the Principal is willing to accept them.

We are not prepared to approve placing them in the school conducted by Rev. Mr. Lee. This school has not been recognized as an Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Linda Sam, born October 6th, 1944, Indian of this Agency, was a patient of the Whitehorse Hospital for about a year and since May, 1949, was confined in the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital for the treatment of a childhood lesion. Dr. Meltzer, Medical Director, reports as follows:

"We are now pleased to report that her X-ray films show definite improvement in the disease in both lungs and we consider the disease inactive. We think that this little girl can now go home, or she could go to a residential school. We would recommend the latter as she could be under some control and supervision. She should rest at least two hours every afternoon. We would ask that a new X-ray be taken in two months. We will signal when we are sending this youngster."

The home conditions of Linda are very poor. The father, Albert Sam is not a good provider and appears frequently before the local court on intoxication charges.

I have spoken to Rev. Ellis, Carcross Residential School, about the case, and he is willing to accept Linda if the Department will approve the admission of an under-age child. I would personally recommend this, as I feel it will only be a recurrence of expense and hospital treatment to let Linda return to her home in her condition. Dr. Meltzer gives no probable date for Linda's return.

(R.J. Meek)

I am in receipt of a request from Jimmy O'Brien, Indian of the Carmacks Band, to send his two daughters Audrey, age 11, and Vivian, age 9, to Carcross Residential School. The children are unable to attend the Day School at Carmacks due to living out on their trap-line most of the year.

Authority is requested for Admission of these children to Carcross School, and also for fares from Carmacks to Carcross. Travel by aircraft is the only commercial method of travel. There are occasional trucks which might bring in the children. I might state that the two children of Lets Tommy, who were authorized to fly to Whitehorse from Fort Selkirk, or Minto, came in by truck at no expense to the Department.

The Superintendent, Yukon Indian Agency:

Admission to Carcross Indian Residential School

Goderich Shatoom (m)
Betty Shatoom (f)

You will recall our earlier discussion of these children with the Rev. Canon Cook and the Reverend Principal of Carcross Indian Residential School.

From a conversation with Inspector Spartan, RCMP, yesterday I learned that the police would welcome our taking corrective action with these children. Their father is said to be unable to supervise them, and it is accomplishing nothing to prosecute him further.

The denominational factor requires that the children be assigned to a school conducted under Protestant auspices. As accommodation is not available at the Rev. Mr. Lee's hostel, the nearest available school is Carcross.

Mr. Shatoom has, however, a legal right to challenge this assignment, but he must do so immediately upon your informing him of the decision to assign these children to Carcross. You should tell him that he has that right and inquire whether he wishes to exercise it now by making an affidavit stating that it is his wish that the school to which the children are to be assigned shall be one conducted under the auspices of a denomination other than the one to which he himself adheres. If he wants a Roman Catholic environment for his children, enquiries should have been made to discover where accommodation is available now—not in September.

If Mr. Shatoom is agreeable to the normal and expected procedure, please have admission forms completed, signed by him with an independent witness, and forwarded to Ottawa. As I anticipate approval of this action, please arrange for Rev. Mr. Ellis to take the children into residence forthwith. The other not so recalcitrant tenants of all denominations may be guided by our action.

C.A.V. Clark

Further to my letter of July 6th concerning the Anglican Residential School in the Yukon, I have now received word from Superintendent Clark of Telegraph Creek that there will be ten pupils of Anglican affiliation who are now attending the Carcross Residential School and who could attend a school in the Teslin-Carcross area. There are also a number of pupils at Telegraph Creek with Anglican affiliation but these are now enrolled in the Provincial School at that point so that accommodation is not at the present time required for them. There may, of course, at a later date, be one or two of these because of home circumstances who will have to be taken out of the day school and placed in the Residential school. These could very well attend your school in the Yukon.

Yours respectfully,

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION

Carcross Residential School

Payment of Grants for September, 1950, Quarter

Reference is to correspondence item No. 15181 being a circular addressed to Principals of Residential Schools under the direction of the Anglican Indian School Administration.

There is a minute from Canon Cook to Colonel Neary that indicates that the monetary matters referred to in the circular were a subject of previous discussion and agreement.

The Quarterly Return from Carcross School, however, is probably being audited at a reduced amount that falls considerably short of the amount which the Principal is entitled to claim and has claimed, although he may have to some extent changed the manner of making the claim.

May I suggest that this Division anticipate the receipt of any reproach. Carcross is a small-pupilage school which has fixed administrative expenses and probably operates at a deficit. I recommend that an assurance go forward that the amount to be paid for the September Quarter will more nearly approximate the amount that has been claimed.
